Text

In the middle of [Sedgehill]1-sedgehill , which is in [the middle of [Mershire]2-mershire]281-the middle of mershire , which is in [the middle of [England]3-england]282-the middle of england , there lies [a narrow ridge of high table - land]283-a narrow ridge of high table - land , dividing , as by a straight line , [the collieries and ironworks of [the great coal district]285-the great coal district]284-the collieries and ironworks of the great coal district from [the green and pleasant scenery of [the western Midlands]4-the western midlands]286-the green and pleasant scenery of the western midlands . Along the summit of this ridge runs [the High Street of [the bleak little town of Sedgehill]288-the bleak little town of sedgehill]287-the high street of the bleak little town of sedgehill ; so that [the houses on the east side of [this street]290-this street]289-the houses on the east side of this street see nothing through [their]289-the houses on the east side of this street back windows save the huge slag - mounds and blazing furnaces and tall chimneys of [the weird and terrible , yet withal fascinating , Black Country]291-the weird and terrible , yet withal fascinating , black country ; while [the houses on the west side of [the street]293-the street]292-the houses on the west side of the street have [sunny gardens]294-sunny gardens and fruitful orchards , sloping down toward a fertile land of [woods and streams and meadows]295-woods and streams and meadows , bounded in the far distance by [the Clee Hills]5-the clee hills and [the Wrekin]6-the wrekin , and in the farthest distance of all by [the blue Welsh mountains]296-the blue welsh mountains . In [the dark valley]297-the dark valley lying to [the immediate east of [Sedgehill]1-sedgehill]298-the immediate east of sedgehill stood [the Osierfield Works]299-the osierfield works , [the largest ironworks in [Mershire]2-mershire]300-the largest ironworks in mershire in the good old days when [Mershire]2-mershire made iron for half [the world]301-the world . [The owners of [these works]303-these works]302-the owners of these works were [the Farringdons]96-the farringdons , and had been so for several generations . So it came to pass that [the Farringdons]96-the farringdons were [the royal family of [Sedgehill]1-sedgehill]304-the royal family of sedgehill ; and [the Osierfield Works]299-the osierfield works was [the circle wherein [the inhabitants of [that place]308-that place]307-the inhabitants of that place lived and moved . It was as natural for [everybody born in [Sedgehill]1-sedgehill]309-everybody born in sedgehill eventually to work at [the Osierfield]102-elisabeth , as it was for [him]309-everybody born in sedgehill eventually to grow into [a man]310-a man and to take unto [himself]309-everybody born in sedgehill [a wife]311-a wife . [The home of [the Farringdons]96-the farringdons]312-the home of the farringdons]306-the circle wherein the inhabitants of that place lived and moved . it was as natural for everybody born in sedgehill eventually to work at the osierfield , as it was for him eventually to grow into a man and to take unto himself a wife . the home of the farringdons was called [the Willows]8-the willows , and was separated by [a carriage - drive]313-a carriage - drive of half a mile from [the town]314-the town . [[Its]312-the home of the farringdons lodge]315-its lodge stood in [the High Street]9-the high street , on the western side ; and [the drive]316-the drive wandered through [a fine old wood]317-a fine old wood , and across [an undulating park]318-an undulating park , till [it]316-the drive stopped in front of [a large square house built of gray stone]319-a large square house built of gray stone . [It]319-a large square house built of gray stone was [a handsome house inside]320-a handsome house inside , with wonderful oak staircases and Adams chimneypieces ; and there was an air of great stateliness about [it]319-a large square house built of gray stone , and of very little luxury . For [the Farringdons]96-the farringdons were [a hardy race , whose time was taken up by the making of iron and the saving of souls]321-a hardy race , whose time was taken up by the making of iron and the saving of souls ; and [they]321-a hardy race , whose time was taken up by the making of iron and the saving of souls regarded sofas and easy - chairs in very much the same light as [they]321-a hardy race , whose time was taken up by the making of iron and the saving of souls regarded theatres and strong drink , thereby proving that [their]321-a hardy race , whose time was taken up by the making of iron and the saving of souls spines were as strong as [their]321-a hardy race , whose time was taken up by the making of iron and the saving of souls consciences were stern . Moreover , [the Farringdons]96-the farringdons were of " [the people called Methodists]2976-the people called methodists "[96-the farringdons] ; consequently Methodism was the established religion of [Sedgehill]1-sedgehill , possessing there that prestige which is the inalienable attribute of all state churches . In the eyes of [Sedgehill]1-sedgehill it was as necessary to salvation to pray at [the chapel]322-the chapel as to work at [the Osierfield]102-elisabeth ; and [the majority of [the inhabitants]324-the inhabitants]323-the majority of the inhabitants would as soon have thought of worshipping at [any other sanctuary]325-any other sanctuary as of worshipping at [the beacon]326-the beacon , a pillar which still marks the highest point of [the highest table - land in [England]3-england]327-the highest table - land in england . At the time when this story begins , the joint ownership of [the Osierfield]102-elisabeth and [the Willows]328-the willows was vested in the two [Miss Farringdons]96-the farringdons , [the daughters and co - heiresses of [John Farringdon]97-john farringdon]329-the daughters and co - heiresses of john farringdon . [John Farringdon]97-john farringdon and [[his]97-john farringdon brother]330-his brother [William]98-william had been [partners]331-partners , and had arranged between [themselves]332-themselves that [[William]98-william 's only child]333-william 's only child , [George]99-george farringdon , should marry [[John]97-john farringdon 's eldest daughter]334-john 's eldest daughter , [Maria]100-cousin maria , and so consolidate [the brothers]335-the brothers ' fortunes and [their]335-the brothers interest in the works . But [the gods]336-the gods — and [George]99-george farringdon — saw otherwise . [George]99-george farringdon was [a handsome , weak boy , who objected equally to work and to Methodism]337-a handsome , weak boy , who objected equally to work and to methodism ; and as [[his]99-george farringdon father]338-his father cared for nothing beyond those sources of interest , and had no patience for [any one who did]339-any one who did , [the two]340-the two did not always see eye to eye . Perhaps if [Maria]100-cousin maria had been more unbending , things might have turned out differently ; but Methodism in its severest aspects was not more severe than [Maria Farringdon]101-maria farringdon . [She]100-cousin maria was [a thorough gentlewoman]341-a thorough gentlewoman , and extremely clever ; but tenderness was not counted among [her]100-cousin maria excellencies . [George]99-george farringdon would have been fond of almost [any woman who was pretty enough to be loved and not clever enough to be feared]342-any woman who was pretty enough to be loved and not clever enough to be feared ; but [[his]99-george farringdon cousin]343-his cousin [Maria]100-cousin maria was beyond even [his]99-george farringdon powers of falling in love , although , to do [him]99-george farringdon justice , these powers were by no means limited . The end of it was that [George]99-george farringdon offended [[his]99-george farringdon father]338-his father past forgiveness by running away to [Australia]10-australia rather than marry [Maria]100-cousin maria , and there disappeared . Years afterward a rumour reached [[his]99-george farringdon people]345-his people that [he]99-george farringdon had married and died out there , leaving [a widow]346-a widow and [an only son]347-an only son ; but this rumour had not been verified , as by that time [[his]99-george farringdon father]338-his father and [uncle]349-uncle were dead , and [[his]99-george farringdon cousins]350-his cousins were reigning in [his]99-george farringdon stead ; and it was hardly to be expected that [the proud Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth would take much trouble concerning [the woman whom [[her]102-elisabeth weak - kneed kinsman]352-her weak - kneed kinsman had preferred to [herself]102-elisabeth]351-the woman whom her weak - kneed kinsman had preferred to herself . [William Farringdon]98-william left all [his]98-william property and [his]98-william share in [the works]353-the works to [[his]98-william niece]354-his niece [Maria]100-cousin maria , as some reparation for the insult which [[his]98-william disinherited son]355-his disinherited son had offered to [her]100-cousin maria ; [John]97-john farringdon left [his]97-john farringdon large fortune between [[his]97-john farringdon two daughters]356-his two daughters , as [he]97-john farringdon never had [a son]357-a son ; so [Maria]100-cousin maria and [Anne Farringdon]103-anne farringdon lived at [the Willows]8-the willows , and carried on [the Osierfield]102-elisabeth with the help of [Richard Smallwood]104-richard smallwood , who had been [the general manager of [the collieries and ironworks belonging to the firm]359-the collieries and ironworks belonging to the firm in [[their]360-their father]361-their father 's time]358-the general manager of the collieries and ironworks belonging to the firm in their father 's time , and knew as much about iron ( and most other things ) as [he]104-richard smallwood did . [Maria]100-cousin maria was [a good woman of business]362-a good woman of business , and [she]100-cousin maria and [Richard]104-richard smallwood between [them]360-their made money as fast as it had been made in the days of [William]98-william and [John Farringdon]97-john farringdon . [Anne]103-anne farringdon , on the contrary , was [a meek and gentle soul , who had no power of governing but a perfect genius for obedience]363-a meek and gentle soul , who had no power of governing but a perfect genius for obedience , and who was always engaged on the Herculean task of squaring the sternest dogmas with the most indulgent practices . Even in the early days of this history [the Miss Farringdons]96-the farringdons were what is called " getting on "[96-the farringdons] ; but [the Willows]8-the willows was , nevertheless , not without a youthful element in it . Close upon a dozen years ago [the two sisters]364-the two sisters had adopted [the orphaned child of [a second cousin , whose young widow]366-a second cousin , whose young widow had died in giving birth to [a posthumous daughter]367-a posthumous daughter]365-the orphaned child of a second cousin , whose young widow had died in giving birth to a posthumous daughter ; and now [Elisabeth Farringdon]102-elisabeth was the light of [the good ladies]368-the good ladies ' eyes , though [they]368-the good ladies would have considered it harmful to [her]102-elisabeth soul to let [her]102-elisabeth have an inkling of this fact . [She]102-elisabeth was not [a pretty little girl]369-a pretty little girl , which was a source of much sorrow of heart to [her]102-elisabeth ; and [she]102-elisabeth was [a distinctly clever little girl]370-a distinctly clever little girl , of which [she]102-elisabeth was utterly unconscious , it being an integral part of [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth 's system of education to imbue [the young]371-the young with an overpowering sense of [their]371-the young own inferiority and unworthiness . During the first decade of [her]102-elisabeth existence [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth used frequently and earnestly to pray that [her]102-elisabeth hair might become golden and [her]102-elisabeth eyes brown ; but as on this score the heavens remained as brass , and [her]102-elisabeth hair continued dark brown and [her]102-elisabeth eyes blue - gray , [she]102-elisabeth changed [her]102-elisabeth tactics , and confined [her]102-elisabeth heroine - worship to [ladies of this particular style of colouring]372-ladies of this particular style of colouring ; which showed that , even at the age of ten , [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth had [her]102-elisabeth full share of adaptability . One day , when walking with [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth to [chapel]373-chapel , [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth exclaimed , à propos of nothing but [her]102-elisabeth own meditations , " Oh ! [Cousin Maria]100-cousin maria , [I]102-elisabeth do wish [I]102-elisabeth was pretty ! "[102-elisabeth] [Most people]374-most people would have been too much afraid of [the lady of the Willows]375-the lady of the willows to express so frivolous a desire in [her]102-elisabeth august hearing ; but [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth was never afraid of [anybody]376-anybody , and that , perhaps , was one of the reasons why [[her]102-elisabeth severe kinswoman]377-her severe kinswoman loved [her]102-elisabeth so well . " That is a vain wish , [[my]102-elisabeth child]2977-my child . Favour is deceitful and beauty is vain ; and [the Lord]2978-the lord looketh on the heart and not on the outward appearance . "[102-elisabeth] " But [I]102-elisabeth was n't thinking of [the Lord]2978-the lord , "[102-elisabeth] replied [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth : " [I]102-elisabeth was thinking of [other people]2980-other people ; and [they]2980-other people love [you]2977-my child much more if [you]2977-my child are pretty than if [you]2977-my child are n't . "[102-elisabeth] " That is not so , "[102-elisabeth] said [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth — and [she]102-elisabeth believed [she]102-elisabeth was speaking the truth ; " if [you]2977-my child serve [God]105-god and do [your]2977-my child duty to [[your]2977-my child neighbour]2981-your neighbour , [you]2977-my child will find plenty of [people]2982-people ready to love [you]2977-my child ; and especially if [you]2977-my child carry [yourself]2977-my child well and never stoop . "[102-elisabeth] Like [many another elect lady]378-many another elect lady , [Cousin Maria]100-cousin maria regarded beauty of face as a vanity , but beauty of figure as a virtue ; and to this doctrine [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth owed the fact that [her]102-elisabeth back always sloped in the opposite direction to the backs of [the majority of people]379-the majority of people . But it would have surprised [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth to learn how little real effect [her]102-elisabeth strict Methodist training had upon [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth ; fortunately , however , [few elder people]380-few elder people ever do learn how little effect [their]380-few elder people training has upon [the young committed to [their]380-few elder people charge]381-the young committed to their charge ; if it were so , life would be too hard for [the generation that has passed the hill - top]382-the generation that has passed the hill - top . [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's was one of those happy , pantheistic natures that possess the gift of finding [God]105-god everywhere and in everything . [She]102-elisabeth early caught the Methodist habit of self - analysis and introspection , but in [her]102-elisabeth it did not develop — as it does in [more naturally religious souls]383-more naturally religious souls — into an almost morbid conscientiousness and self - depreciation ; [she]102-elisabeth merely found an artistic and intellectual pleasure in taking the machinery of [her]102-elisabeth soul to pieces and seeing how it worked . In those days — and , in fact , in all succeeding ones — [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth lived in a world of imagination . There was not [a nook in [the garden of the Willows]385-the garden of the willows which was not peopled by creatures of [her]102-elisabeth fancy]384-a nook in the garden of the willows which was not peopled by creatures of her fancy . At this particular time [she]102-elisabeth was greatly fascinated by the subject of heathen mythology , as set forth in [Mangnall]106-mangnall 's Questions , and had devoted [herself]102-elisabeth to the service of [Pallas Athene]107-pallas athene , having learned that [that goddess]386-that goddess was ( like [herself]102-elisabeth ) not surpassingly beautiful , and was , moreover , handicapped by the possession of gray eyes . [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth would have been horrified had [she]102-elisabeth known that a portion of the wood was set apart by [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth as " [[Athene]107-pallas athene 's Grove]2983-athene 's grove , "[102-elisabeth] and that the contents of the waste - paper basket were daily begged from [the servants]387-the servants by [the devotee]388-the devotee , and offered up , by the aid of real matches , on the shrine of [the goddess]389-the goddess . " Have [you]102-elisabeth noticed , [sister]2984-sister , "[108-miss anne] [Miss Anne]108-miss anne remarked on one occasion , " how much more thoughtful dear [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth is growing ? "[108-miss anne] [Miss Anne]108-miss anne 's life was one long advertisement of [other people]2980-other people 's virtues . " [She]102-elisabeth used to be somewhat careless in letting the fires go out , and so giving [the servants]387-the servants the trouble to relight [them]387-the servants ; but now [she]102-elisabeth is always going round [the rooms]2986-the rooms to see if more coal is required , without [my]108-miss anne ever having to remind [her]102-elisabeth . "[108-miss anne] " It is so , and [I]102-elisabeth rejoice . Carelessness in domestic matters is a grave fault in [a young girl]2987-a young girl , and [I]102-elisabeth am pleased that [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth has outgrown [her]102-elisabeth habit of wool - gathering , and of letting the fire go out under [her]102-elisabeth very nose without noticing it . It is a source of thanksgiving to [me]102-elisabeth that [the child]2988-the child is so much more thoughtful and considerate in this matter than [she]102-elisabeth used to be . "[102-elisabeth] [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth 's thanksgiving , however , would have been less fervent had [she]102-elisabeth known that , for the time being , [[her]102-elisabeth protégée]391-her protégée had assumed the rôle of [a Vestal virgin]392-a vestal virgin , and that [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's care of the fires that winter was not fulfilment of a duty but part of a game . This , however , was [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's way ; [she]102-elisabeth frequently received credit for performing a duty when [she]102-elisabeth was really only taking part in a performance ; which merely meant that [she]102-elisabeth possessed [the artist]393-the artist 's power of looking at duty through the haze of idealism , and of seeing that , although it was good , it might also be made picturesque . [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth was well versed in [The Pilgrim]109-the pilgrim 's Progress and [The Fairchild Family]110-the fairchild family . The spiritual vicissitudes of [Lucy]111-lucy ellen , [Emily]112-emily , and [Henry Fairchild]113-henry fairchild were to [her]102-elisabeth a drama of never - failing interest ; while each besetment of [the Crosbie]114-the crosbie household — which was as carefully preserved for [[its]394-its particular owner]395-its particular owner as if sin were a species of ground game — never failed to thrill [her]102-elisabeth with enjoyable disgust . [She]102-elisabeth knew a great portion of the Methodist hymn - book by heart , and pondered long over the interesting preface to that work , wondering much what " doggerel "[102-elisabeth] and " botches "[102-elisabeth] could be — [she]102-elisabeth inclined to the supposition that the former were animals and the latter were diseases ; but even [her]102-elisabeth vivid imagination failed to form a satisfactory representation of such queer kittle - cattle as " feeble expletives . "[102-elisabeth] Every Sunday [she]102-elisabeth gloated over the frontispiece of [John Wesley]115-john wesley , in [his]115-john wesley gown and bands and white ringlets , feeling that , though poor as a picture , it was very superior to the letterpress ; the worst illustrations being better than the best poetry , as [everybody under thirteen]396-everybody under thirteen must know . But [[Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's library]397-elisabeth 's library was not confined to the volumes above mentioned ; [she]102-elisabeth regularly perused with interest two little periodicals , called respectively Early Days and The Juvenile Offering . The former treated of [youthful saints]398-youthful saints at [home]399-home ; and its white paper cover was adorned by the picture of [a shepherd , comfortably if peculiarly attired in a frock coat and top hat]400-a shepherd , comfortably if peculiarly attired in a frock coat and top hat — presumably to portray that it was Sunday . The latter magazine devoted itself to histories dealing with [youthful saints abroad]401-youthful saints abroad ; and its cover was decorated with a representation of [young black persons apparently engaged in some religious exercise]402-young black persons apparently engaged in some religious exercise . In this picture the frock coats and top hats were conspicuous by [their]403-their absence . There were two pictures in [the breakfast - room at [the Willows]8-the willows]404-the breakfast - room at the willows which occupied an important place in [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's childish imaginings . The first hung over the mantelpiece , and was called The Centenary Meeting . It represented [a chapel full of [men in suffocating cravats]406-men in suffocating cravats , turning [their]406-men in suffocating cravats backs upon the platform and looking at [the public]407-the public]405-a chapel full of men in suffocating cravats , turning their backs upon the platform and looking at the public instead — a more effective if less realistic attitude than the ordinary one of sitting the right way about ; because — as [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth reasoned , and reasoned rightly — if [these gentlemen]408-these gentlemen had not happened to be behind before when [their]408-these gentlemen portraits were taken , [nobody]409-nobody would ever have known whose portraits [they]408-these gentlemen were . It was a source of great family pride to [her]102-elisabeth that [[her]102-elisabeth grandfather]410-her grandfather appeared in this galaxy of Methodist worth ; but [the hero of the piece]411-the hero of the piece , in [her]102-elisabeth eyes , was [one gentleman who had managed to swarm up a pillar and there screw [himself]411-the hero of the piece " to the sticking - place "]2989-one gentleman who had managed to swarm up a pillar and there screw himself " to the sticking - place "[411-the hero of the piece] ; and how [he]411-the hero of the piece had done it [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth never could conceive . The second picture hung over the door , and was a counterfeit presentment of [John Wesley]115-john wesley 's escape from [the burning rectory at [Epworth]11-epworth]412-the burning rectory at epworth . In those days [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth was so small and the picture hung so high that [she]102-elisabeth could not see it very distinctly ; but it appeared to [her]102-elisabeth that [the boy]413-the boy [Wesley]115-john wesley ( whom [she]102-elisabeth confused in [her]102-elisabeth own mind with [the infant Samuel]414-the infant samuel ) was flying out of an attic window by means of flowing white wings , while a horse was suspended in mid - air ready to carry [him]413-the boy straight to [heaven]415-heaven . Every Sunday [she]102-elisabeth accompanied [[her]102-elisabeth cousins]416-her cousins to [East Lane Chapel]12-east lane chapel , at [the other end of [Sedgehill]1-sedgehill]417-the other end of sedgehill , and here [she]102-elisabeth saw strange visions and dreamed strange dreams . The distinguishing feature of [this sanctuary]418-this sanctuary was a sort of reredos in oils , in memory of [a dead and gone Farringdon]419-a dead and gone farringdon , which depicted a gigantic urn , surrounded by [a forest of cypress]420-a forest of cypress , through the shades whereof flitted [" young - eyed cherubims "[393-the artist] with dirty wings and bilious complexions]2990-" young - eyed cherubims " with dirty wings and bilious complexions , these last mentioned blemishes being , it is but fair to add , the fault of the atmosphere and not of [the artist]393-the artist . For years [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth firmly believed that this altar - piece was a trustworthy representation of [heaven]415-heaven ; and [she]102-elisabeth felt , therefore , a pleasant , proprietary interest in it , as the view of [an estate to which [she]102-elisabeth would one day succeed]423-an estate to which she would one day succeed . There was also a stained - glass window in [East Lane Chapel]12-east lane chapel , given by [the widow of [a leading official]425-a leading official]424-the widow of a leading official . The baptismal name of [the deceased]426-the deceased had been [Jacob]116-jacob ; and the window showed forth [Jacob]116-jacob 's Dream , as a delicate compliment to [the departed]427-the departed . [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth delighted in this window , it was so realistic . [The patriarch]428-the patriarch lay asleep , with [his]428-the patriarch head on a little white tombstone at the foot of a solid oak staircase , which was covered with a red carpet neatly fastened down by brass rods ; while up and down [this staircase]429-this staircase strolled [fair - haired angels]430-fair - haired angels in long white nightgowns and purple wings . Not of course then , but in after years , [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth learned to understand that this window was a type and an explanation of the power of early Methodism , the strength whereof lay in its marvellous capacity of adapting religion to the needs and use of everyday life , and of bringing the infinite into the region of the homely and commonplace . [We]431-our , with [our]431-our added culture and [our]431-our maturer artistic perceptions , may smile at a [Jacob]116-jacob 's Ladder formed according to the domestic architecture of the first half of the nineteenth century ; but [the people to whom [the other world]433-the other world was so near and so real that [they]432-the people to whom the other world was so near and so real that they perceived nothing incongruous in an ordinary stair - carpet which was being trodden by the feet of angels perceived nothing incongruous in an ordinary stair - carpet which was being trodden by the feet of [angels]434-angels]432-the people to whom the other world was so near and so real that they perceived nothing incongruous in an ordinary stair - carpet which was being trodden by the feet of angels , had grasped a truth which on one side touched the divine , even though on the other it came perilously near to the grotesque . And [He]116-jacob , Who taught [them]432-the people to whom the other world was so near and so real that they perceived nothing incongruous in an ordinary stair - carpet which was being trodden by the feet of angels as by parables , never misunderstood — as did certain of [[His]116-jacob followers]435-his followers — [their]435-his followers reverent irreverence ; but , understanding it , saw that it was good . The great day in [East Lane Chapel]12-east lane chapel was the Sunday School anniversary ; and in [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's childish eyes this was a feast compared with which Christmas and Easter sank to the level of black - letter days . On these festivals [the Sunday School scholars]436-the sunday school scholars sat all together in those parts of [the gallery]437-the gallery adjacent to the organ , [the girls]438-the girls wearing white frocks and blue neckerchiefs , and [the boys]439-the boys black suits and blue ties . The pews were strewn with white hymn - sheets , which lay all over [the chapel]322-the chapel like snow in Salmon , and which contained special spiritual songs more stirring in their character than the contents of the Hymn - book ; these hymns [the Sunday School children]441-the sunday school children sang by [themselves]441-the sunday school children , while [the congregation]442-the congregation sat swaying to and fro to the tune . And [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's soul was uplifted within [her]102-elisabeth as [she]102-elisabeth listened to [the children]443-the children 's voices ; for [she]102-elisabeth felt that mystical hush which — let [us]444-us hope — comes to [us]444-us all at some time or other , when [we]444-us hide [our]444-us faces in [our]444-us mantles and feel that a Presence is passing by , and is passing by so near to [us]444-us that [we]444-us have only to stretch out [our]444-us hands in order to touch it . At sundry times and in divers manners does that wonderful sense of a Personal Touch come to [men]445-men and to [women]446-women . It may be in a wayside [Bethel]117-bethel , it may be in one of [the fairest fanes of [Christendom]13-christendom]447-the fairest fanes of christendom , or it may be not in any temple made with hands : according to the separate natures which [God]105-god has given to [us]444-us , so must [we]444-us choose the separate ways that will lead [us]444-us to [Him]105-god ; and as long as there are different natures there must be various ways . Then let each of [us]444-us take the path at the end whereof [we]444-us see [Him]105-god standing , always remembering [that wayfaring men]448-that wayfaring men , though [fools]449-fools , shall not err therein ; and never forgetting that — come whence and how [they]448-that wayfaring men may — whosoever shall touch but the hem of [His]105-god garment shall be made perfectly whole . There are two things which are absolutely necessary to the well - being of [the normal feminine mind]450-the normal feminine mind — namely , one romantic attachment and one comfortable friendship . [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth was perfectly normal and extremely feminine ; and consequently [she]102-elisabeth provided [herself]102-elisabeth early with these two aids to happiness . In those days the object of [her]102-elisabeth romantic attachment was [[her]102-elisabeth cousin]451-her cousin [Anne]108-miss anne . [Anne Farringdon]103-anne farringdon was one of [those graceful , elegant women who appear so much deeper than they really are]452-those graceful , elegant women who appear so much deeper than they really are . All [her]103-anne farringdon life [she]103-anne farringdon had been inspiring devotion which [she]103-anne farringdon was utterly unable to fathom ; and this was still the case with regard to [herself]103-anne farringdon and [[her]103-anne farringdon adoring little worshipper]453-her adoring little worshipper . [People]2982-people always wondered why [Anne Farringdon]103-anne farringdon had never married ; and explained the mystery to [their]2982-people own satisfaction by conjecturing that [she]103-anne farringdon had had a disappointment in [her]103-anne farringdon youth , and had been incapable of loving twice . It never struck [them]2982-people — which was actually the case — that [she]103-anne farringdon had been incapable of loving once ; and that [her]103-anne farringdon single - blessedness was due to no unforgotten love - story , but to the unromantic fact that among [[her]103-anne farringdon score of [lovers]456-lovers]455-her score of lovers [she]103-anne farringdon had never found [a man for whom [she]103-anne farringdon seriously cared]457-a man for whom she seriously cared . In a delicate and ladylike fashion [she]103-anne farringdon had flirted outrageously in [her]103-anne farringdon time ; but [she]103-anne farringdon had always broken hearts so gently , and put away the pieces so daintily , that [the owners of these hearts]458-the owners of these hearts had never dreamed of resenting the damage [she]103-anne farringdon had wrought . [She]103-anne farringdon had refused [them]2982-people with such a world of pathos in [her]103-anne farringdon beautiful eyes — the Farringdon gray - blue eyes , with thick black brows and long black lashes — that [the poor souls]459-the poor souls had never doubted [her]103-anne farringdon sympathy and comprehension ; nor had [they]459-the poor souls the slightest idea that [she]103-anne farringdon was totally ignorant of the depth of the love which [she]103-anne farringdon had inspired , or the bitterness of the pain which [she]103-anne farringdon had caused . All the romance of [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's nature — and there was a great deal of it — was lavished upon [Anne Farringdon]103-anne farringdon . If [Anne]103-anne farringdon smiled , [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's sky was cloudless ; if [Anne]103-anne farringdon sighed , [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's sky grew gray . The mere sound of [Anne]103-anne farringdon 's voice vibrated through [the child]2988-the child 's whole being ; and every little trifle connected with [[her]103-anne farringdon cousin]451-her cousin became a sacred relic in [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's eyes . Like [every Methodist child]462-every methodist child , [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth was well versed in [her]102-elisabeth Bible ; but , unlike [most Methodist children]463-most methodist children , [she]102-elisabeth regarded it more as a poetical than an ethical work . When [she]102-elisabeth was only twelve , the sixty - eighth Psalm thrilled [her]102-elisabeth as with the sound of a trumpet ; and [she]102-elisabeth was completely carried away by the glorious imagery of the Book of [Isaiah]118-isaiah , even when [she]102-elisabeth did not in the least understand its meaning . But [her]102-elisabeth favourite book was the Book of [Ruth]119-ruth ; for was not [Ruth]119-ruth 's devotion to Naomi the exact counterpart of [hers]102-elisabeth to [Cousin Anne]120-cousin anne ? And [she]102-elisabeth used to make up long stories in [her]102-elisabeth own mind about how [Cousin Anne]120-cousin anne should , by some means , lose all [[her]120-cousin anne friends]464-her friends and all [her]120-cousin anne money , and be driven out of [Sedgehill]1-sedgehill and away from [the Osierfield Works]14-the osierfield works ; and then how [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth would say , " Entreat [me]102-elisabeth not to leave [thee]120-cousin anne , "[102-elisabeth] and would follow [Cousin Anne]120-cousin anne to [the ends of [the earth]466-the earth]465-the ends of the earth . [People]2982-people sometimes smile at the adoration of [a young girl]2987-a young girl for [a woman]469-a woman , and there is no doubt but that the feeling savours slightly of school - days and bread - and - butter ; but there is also no doubt that [a girl who has once felt it]470-a girl who has once felt it has learned what real love is , and that is [no small item in the lesson - book of life]471-no small item in the lesson - book of life . But [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth had [her]102-elisabeth comfortable friendship as well as [her]102-elisabeth romantic attachment ; and [the partner in that friendship]472-the partner in that friendship was [Christopher Thornley]121-christopher , [the nephew of [Richard Smallwood]104-richard smallwood]473-the nephew of richard smallwood . In the days of [his]104-richard smallwood youth , when [[his]104-richard smallwood father]338-his father was still [manager of [the Osierfield Works]14-the osierfield works]475-manager of the osierfield works , [Richard]104-richard smallwood had [a very pretty sister]476-a very pretty sister ; but as [Emily Smallwood]112-emily was pretty , so was [she]112-emily also vain , and the strict atmosphere of [[her]112-emily home life]477-her home life did not recommend itself to [her]112-emily taste . After many quarrels with [[her]112-emily stern old father]478-her stern old father ( [[her]112-emily mother]479-her mother having died when [she]112-emily was [a baby]480-a baby ) , [Emily]112-emily left [home]399-home , and took a situation in [London]15-london as [governess]482-governess , in [the house of [some wealthy people with no pretensions to religion]484-some wealthy people with no pretensions to religion]483-the house of some wealthy people with no pretensions to religion . For this [[her]112-emily father]485-her father never forgave [her]112-emily ; [he]485-her father called it " consorting with [children of Belial]2991-children of belial . "[485-her father] In time [she]112-emily wrote to tell [Richard]104-richard smallwood that [she]112-emily was going to be married , and that [she]112-emily wished to cut off entirely all communication with [[her]112-emily old home]486-her old home . After that , [Richard]104-richard smallwood lost sight of [her]112-emily for many years ; but some time after [[his]104-richard smallwood father]338-his father 's death [he]104-richard smallwood received a letter from [Emily]112-emily , begging [him]104-richard smallwood to come to [her]112-emily at once , as [she]112-emily was dying . [He]104-richard smallwood complied with [her]112-emily request , and found [[his]104-richard smallwood once beautiful sister]488-his once beautiful sister in great poverty in [a London lodging - house]489-a london lodging - house . [She]112-emily told [him]104-richard smallwood that [she]112-emily had endured great sorrow , having lost [[her]112-emily husband]490-her husband and [[her]112-emily five eldest children]491-her five eldest children . [[Her]112-emily husband]490-her husband had never been unkind to [her]112-emily , [she]112-emily said , but [he]490-her husband was one of [the men who lack the power either to make or to keep money]493-the men who lack the power either to make or to keep money ; and when [he]490-her husband found [he]490-her husband was foredoomed to failure in everything to which [he]490-her husband turned [his]490-her husband hand , [he]490-her husband had not the spirit to continue the fight against [Fate]122-fate , but turned [his]490-her husband face to the wall and died . [She]112-emily had still [one child]494-one child left , [a fair - haired boy of about two years old]495-a fair - haired boy of about two years old , called [Christopher]121-christopher ; to [[her]112-emily brother]496-her brother 's care [she]112-emily confided [this boy]497-this boy , and then [she]112-emily also turned [her]112-emily face to the wall and died . This happened a year or so before [the Miss Farringdons]96-the farringdons adopted [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth ; so that when [that young lady]498-that young lady appeared upon the scene , and subsequently grew up sufficiently to require a playfellow , [she]112-emily found [Christopher Thornley]121-christopher ready to hand . [He]121-christopher lived with [[his]121-christopher bachelor uncle]499-his bachelor uncle in [a square red house on the east side of [Sedgehill High Street]16-sedgehill high street]500-a square red house on the east side of sedgehill high street , exactly opposite to [[the Farringdons]96-the farringdons ' lodge]501-the farringdons ' lodge . [It]500-a square red house on the east side of sedgehill high street was [one of [those big , bald houses]503-those big , bald houses with unblinking windows , that stare at [you]504-you as if [they]503-those big , bald houses had not any eyebrows or eyelashes]502-one of those big , bald houses with unblinking windows , that stare at you as if they had not any eyebrows or eyelashes ; and there was not even a strip of greenery between [it]500-a square red house on the east side of sedgehill high street and [the High Street]9-the high street . So to prevent [the passers - by]505-the passers - by from looking in and [the occupants]506-the occupants from looking out , the lower parts of the front windows were covered with a sort of black crape mask , which put even the sunbeams into half - mourning . Unlike [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth , [Christopher]121-christopher had a passion for righteousness and for honour , but no power of artistic perception . [His]121-christopher standard was whether things were right or wrong , honourable or dishonourable ; hers was whether they were beautiful or ugly , pleasant or unpleasant . Consequently [the two]340-the two moved along parallel lines ; and [she]102-elisabeth moved a great deal more quickly than [he]121-christopher did . [Christopher]121-christopher had deep convictions , but was very shy of expressing them ; [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's convictions were not particularly deep , but such as they were , all [the world]301-the world was welcome to [them]503-those big , bald houses as far as [she]102-elisabeth was concerned . As [the children]443-the children grew older , one thing used much to puzzle and perplex [Christopher]121-christopher . [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth did not seem to care about being good nearly as much as [he]121-christopher cared : [he]121-christopher was always trying to do right , and [she]102-elisabeth only tried when [she]102-elisabeth thought about it ; nevertheless , when [she]102-elisabeth did give [her]102-elisabeth attention to the matter , [she]102-elisabeth had much more comforting and beautiful thoughts than [he]121-christopher had , which appeared rather hard . [He]121-christopher was not yet old enough to know that this difference between [them]340-the two arose from no unequal division of divine favour , but was simply and solely a question of temperament . But though [he]121-christopher did not understand , [he]121-christopher did not complain ; for [he]121-christopher had been brought up under the shadow of [the Osierfield Works]299-the osierfield works , and in the fear and love of [the Farringdons]96-the farringdons ; and [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth , whatever [her]102-elisabeth shortcomings , was [a princess of the blood]511-a princess of the blood . [Christopher]121-christopher was [a day - boy at [the Grammar School at [Silverhampton]245-lady silverhampton]513-the grammar school at silverhampton , [a fine old town]514-a fine old town some three miles to [the north of [Sedgehill]1-sedgehill]515-the north of sedgehill]512-a day - boy at the grammar school at silverhampton , a fine old town some three miles to the north of sedgehill ; and there and back [he]121-christopher walked every day , wet or fine , and there [he]121-christopher learned to be [a scholar]516-a scholar and [a gentleman]517-a gentleman , and sundry other important things . " Do [you]121-christopher hear that noise ? "[102-elisabeth] said [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth , one afternoon in the holidays , when [she]102-elisabeth was twelve and [Christopher]121-christopher fifteen ; " that 's [Mrs. Bateson]123-mrs. bateson 's pig being killed . "[102-elisabeth] " Hear it?—rather , "[121-christopher] replied [Christopher]121-christopher , standing still in the wood to listen . " Let 's go and see it , "[102-elisabeth] [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth suggested . [Christopher]121-christopher looked shocked . " Well , [you]121-christopher are [a horrid girl]2992-a horrid girl ! Nothing would induce [me]121-christopher to go , or to let [you]121-christopher go either ; but [I]121-christopher 'm surprised at [your]121-christopher being so horrid as to wish for such a thing . "[121-christopher] " It is n't really horridness , "[102-elisabeth] [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth explained meekly ; " it is interest . [I]102-elisabeth 'm so frightfully interested in things ; and [I]102-elisabeth want to see everything , just to know what it looks like . "[102-elisabeth] " Well , [I]121-christopher call it horrid . And , what 's more , if [you]121-christopher saw it , it would make [you]121-christopher feel ill . "[121-christopher] " No ; it would n't . "[102-elisabeth] " Then it ought to , "[121-christopher] said [Christopher]121-christopher , who , with true masculine dulness of perception , confounded weakness of nerve with tenderness of heart . [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth sighed . " Nothing makes [me]102-elisabeth feel ill , "[102-elisabeth] [she]102-elisabeth replied apologetically ; " not even an accident or an after - meeting . "[102-elisabeth] [Christopher]121-christopher could not help indulging in a certain amount of envious admiration for [an organism that could pass unmoved through such physical and spiritual crises as these]518-an organism that could pass unmoved through such physical and spiritual crises as these ; but [he]121-christopher was not going to let [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth see that [he]121-christopher admired [her]102-elisabeth . [He]121-christopher considered it " unmanly "[121-christopher] to admire [girls]519-girls . " Well , [you]102-elisabeth are [a rum little cove]2993-a rum little cove ! "[121-christopher] [he]121-christopher said . " Of course , [I]121-christopher do n't want to go if [you]102-elisabeth think it would be horrid of [me]121-christopher ; but [I]121-christopher thought [we]2994-we might pretend it was the execution of [Mary Queen of Scots]124-mary queen of scots , and find it most awfully exciting . "[121-christopher] " How [you]121-christopher do go on about [Mary Queen of Scots]124-mary queen of scots ! Not long ago [you]121-christopher were always bothering about [heathen goddesses]2995-heathen goddesses , and now [you]121-christopher have no thought for anything but [Mary]124-mary queen of scots . "[121-christopher] " Oh ! but [I]121-christopher 'm still immensely interested in [goddesses]2996-goddesses , [Chris]125-chris ; and [I]121-christopher do wish , when [you]125-chris are doing Latin and Greek at [school]2997-school , [you]125-chris 'd find out what colour [Pallas Athene]107-pallas athene 's hair was . Could n't [you]125-chris ? "[121-christopher] " No ; [I]121-christopher could n't . "[121-christopher] " But [you]121-christopher might ask one of [the masters]2998-the masters . [They]2998-the masters 'd be sure to know . "[121-christopher] [Christopher]121-christopher laughed the laugh of the scornful . " [I]121-christopher say , [you]125-chris are a duffer to suppose that [clever men like [schoolmasters]3000-schoolmasters]2999-clever men like schoolmasters bother [their]2999-clever men like schoolmasters heads about such rot as the colour of [a woman]469-a woman 's hair . "[121-christopher] " Of course , [I]102-elisabeth know [they]3000-schoolmasters would n't about [a woman]469-a woman 's , "[102-elisabeth] [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth hastened to justify [herself]102-elisabeth ; " but [I]102-elisabeth thought perhaps [they]3000-schoolmasters might about [a goddess]3003-a goddess 's . "[102-elisabeth] " It is the same thing . [You]125-chris 've no idea what [tremendously clever chaps schoolmasters]3004-tremendously clever chaps schoolmasters are — much too clever to take any interest in [girls]519-girls ' and [women]446-women 's concerns . Besides , [they]3000-schoolmasters are too old for that , too — [they]3000-schoolmasters are generally quite thirty . "[102-elisabeth] [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth was silent for a moment ; and [Christopher]121-christopher whistled as [he]121-christopher looked across [the green valley]520-the green valley to the sunset , without in the least knowing how beautiful it was . But [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth knew , for [she]102-elisabeth possessed an innate knowledge of many things which [he]121-christopher would have to learn by experience . But even [she]102-elisabeth did not yet understand that because the sunset was beautiful [she]102-elisabeth felt a sudden hunger and thirst after righteousness . " [Chris]125-chris , do [you]125-chris think it is wicked of [people]2982-people to fall in love ? "[102-elisabeth] [she]102-elisabeth asked suddenly . " Not exactly wicked ; more silly , [I]125-chris should say , "[125-chris] replied [Chris]125-chris generously . " Because if it is wicked , [I]125-chris shall give up reading tales about it . "[125-chris] This was a tremendous and unnatural sacrifice to principle on the part of [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth . [Christopher]121-christopher turned upon [her]102-elisabeth sharply . " [You]102-elisabeth do n't read tales that [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth has n't said [you]102-elisabeth may read , do [you]102-elisabeth ? "[121-christopher] " Yes ; lots . But [I]121-christopher never read tales that [she]102-elisabeth has said [I]121-christopher must n't read . "[121-christopher] " [You]102-elisabeth ought n't to read any tale till [you]102-elisabeth have asked [her]102-elisabeth first if [you]102-elisabeth may . "[121-christopher] [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's face fell . " [I]102-elisabeth never thought of doing such a thing as asking [her]102-elisabeth first . Oh ! [Chris]125-chris , [you]125-chris do n't really think [I]102-elisabeth ought to , do [you]125-chris ? Because [she]102-elisabeth 'd be sure to say no . "[102-elisabeth] " That is exactly why [you]125-chris ought to ask . "[121-christopher] [Christopher]121-christopher 's sense of honour was one of [his]121-christopher strong points . Then [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth lost [her]102-elisabeth temper . " That is [you]125-chris all over ! [You]125-chris are [the most tiresome boy]3008-the most tiresome boy to have anything to do with ! [You]125-chris are always bothering about things being wrong , till [you]125-chris make them wrong . Now [I]102-elisabeth hardly ever think of it ; but [I]102-elisabeth ca n't go on doing things after [you]125-chris 've said they are wrong , because that would be wrong of [me]102-elisabeth , do n't [you]125-chris see ? And yet it was n't a bit wrong of [me]102-elisabeth before [I]102-elisabeth knew . [I]102-elisabeth hate [you]125-chris ! "[102-elisabeth] " [I]121-christopher say , [Betty]102-elisabeth , [I]121-christopher 'm awfully sorry [lo]121-christopher have riled [you]125-chris ; but [you]125-chris asked [me]121-christopher . "[121-christopher] " [I]102-elisabeth did n't ask [you]125-chris whether [I]102-elisabeth need ask [Cousin Maria]100-cousin maria , stupid ! [You]125-chris know [I]102-elisabeth did n't . [I]102-elisabeth asked [you]125-chris whether it was wrong to fall in love , and then [you]125-chris went and dragged [Cousin Maria]100-cousin maria in . [I]102-elisabeth wish [I]102-elisabeth 'd never asked [you]125-chris anything ; [I]102-elisabeth wish [I]102-elisabeth 'd never spoken to [you]125-chris ; [I]102-elisabeth wish [I]102-elisabeth 'd got [somebody else to play with]3009-somebody else to play with , and then [I]102-elisabeth 'd never speak to [you]125-chris again as long as [I]102-elisabeth live . "[102-elisabeth] Of course it was unwise of [Christopher]121-christopher to condemn a weakness to which [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth was prone , and to condone one to which [she]102-elisabeth was not ; but [no man]521-no man has learned wisdom at fifteen , and but few at fifty . " [You]125-chris are [the most disagreeable boy [I]102-elisabeth have ever met]3010-the most disagreeable boy i have ever met , and [I]102-elisabeth wish [I]102-elisabeth could think of something to do to annoy [you]125-chris . [I]102-elisabeth know what [I]102-elisabeth 'll do ; [I]102-elisabeth 'll go by [myself]102-elisabeth and see [Mrs. Bateson]123-mrs. bateson 's pig , just to show [you]125-chris how [I]102-elisabeth hate [you]125-chris . "[102-elisabeth] And [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth flew off in the direction of [[Mrs. Bateson]123-mrs. bateson 's cottage]522-mrs. bateson 's cottage , with the truly feminine intention of punishing [the male being who had dared to disapprove of [her]102-elisabeth]523-the male being who had dared to disapprove of her , by making [him]523-the male being who had dared to disapprove of her disapprove of [her]102-elisabeth still more . [Her]102-elisabeth programme , however , was frustrated ; for [Mrs. Bateson]123-mrs. bateson [herself]123-mrs. bateson intervened between [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth and [her]102-elisabeth unholy desires , and entertained [the latter]524-the latter with a plate of delicious bread - and - dripping instead . Finally , [that young lady]498-that young lady returned to [[her]498-that young lady home]526-her home in a more magnanimous frame of mind ; and fell asleep that night wondering if [the whole male sex]527-the whole male sex were as stupid as the particular specimen with which [she]498-that young lady had to do — a problem which has puzzled older female brains than [hers]102-elisabeth . But [poor Christopher]121-christopher was very unhappy . It was agony to [him]121-christopher when [his]121-christopher conscience pulled [him]121-christopher one way and [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth pulled [him]121-christopher the other ; and yet this form of torture was constantly occurring to [him]121-christopher . [He]121-christopher could not bear to do what [he]121-christopher knew was wrong , and [he]121-christopher could not bear to vex [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth ; yet [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's wishes and [his]121-christopher own ideas of right were by no means always synonymous . [His]121-christopher only comfort was the knowledge that [[his]121-christopher sovereign]528-his sovereign 's anger was , as a rule , short - lived , and that [he]121-christopher [himself]121-christopher was indispensable to [that sovereign]529-that sovereign 's happiness . This was true ; but [he]121-christopher did not then realize that it was in [[his]121-christopher office]530-his office as admiring and sympathizing audience , and not in [his]121-christopher person as [Christopher Thornley]121-christopher , that [he]121-christopher was necessary to [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth . A fuller revelation was vouchsafed to [him]121-christopher later . The next morning [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth was [herself]102-elisabeth again , and was quite ready to enjoy [Christopher]121-christopher 's society and to excuse [his]121-christopher scruples . [She]102-elisabeth knew that self of [hers]102-elisabeth when [she]102-elisabeth said that [she]102-elisabeth wished [she]102-elisabeth had [somebody else to play with]3009-somebody else to play with , in order that [she]102-elisabeth might withdraw the light of [her]102-elisabeth presence from [[her]102-elisabeth offending henchman]532-her offending henchman . To thus punish [Christopher]121-christopher , until [she]102-elisabeth had found some one to take [his]121-christopher place , was a course of action which would not have occurred to [her]102-elisabeth . [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's pride could never stand in the way of [her]102-elisabeth pleasure ; [Christopher]121-christopher 's , on the contrary , might . It was a remarkable fact that after [Christopher]121-christopher had reproved [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth for some fault — which happened neither infrequently nor unnecessarily — [he]121-christopher was always repentant and [she]102-elisabeth forgiving ; yet nine times out of ten [he]121-christopher had been in the right and [she]102-elisabeth in the wrong . But [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's was one of those exceptionally generous natures which can pardon the reproofs and condone the virtues of [[their]533-their friends]534-their friends ; and [she]102-elisabeth bore no malice , even when [Christopher]121-christopher had been more obviously right than usual . But [she]102-elisabeth was already enough of [a woman]469-a woman to adapt to [her]102-elisabeth own requirements [his]121-christopher penitence for right - doing ; and on this occasion [she]102-elisabeth took advantage of [his]121-christopher chastened demeanour to induce [him]121-christopher to assist [her]102-elisabeth in erecting [a new shrine to [Athene]107-pallas athene in the wood]536-a new shrine to athene in the wood — which meant that [she]102-elisabeth gave all the directions and [he]121-christopher did all the work . " [You]121-christopher are doing it beautifully , [Chris]125-chris — [you]121-christopher really are ! "[102-elisabeth] [she]102-elisabeth exclaimed with delight . " [We]3011-we shall be able to have a splendid sacrifice this afternoon . [I]102-elisabeth 've got some feathers to offer up from the fowl cook is plucking ; and they make a much better sacrifice than waste paper . "[102-elisabeth] " Why ? "[102-elisabeth] [Christopher]121-christopher was too shy in those days to put the fact into words ; nevertheless , the fact remained that [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth interested [him]121-christopher profoundly . [She]102-elisabeth was so original , so unexpected , that [she]102-elisabeth was continually providing [him]121-christopher with fresh food for thought . Although [he]121-christopher was cleverer at lessons than [she]102-elisabeth was , [she]102-elisabeth was by far the cleverer at play ; and though [he]121-christopher had the finer character , [hers]102-elisabeth was the stronger personality . It was because [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth was so much to [him]121-christopher that [he]121-christopher now and then worried [her]102-elisabeth easy - going conscience with [his]121-christopher strictures ; for , to do [him]121-christopher justice , [the boy]413-the boy was [no prig]538-no prig , and would never have dreamed of preaching to [anybody]376-anybody except [her]102-elisabeth . But it must be remembered that [Christopher]121-christopher had never heard of such things as spiritual evolutions and streams of tendency : to [him]121-christopher right or wrong meant [heaven]415-heaven or hell — neither more nor less ; and [he]121-christopher was overpowered by a burning anxiety that [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth should eventually go to [heaven]415-heaven , partly for [her]102-elisabeth own sake , and partly ( since human love is stronger than dogmas and doctrines ) because [a heaven]542-a heaven , uncheered by the presence of [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth , seemed a somewhat dreary place wherein to spend one 's eternity . " Why do feathers make a better sacrifice than paper ? "[121-christopher] repeated [Christopher]121-christopher , [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth being so much absorbed in [his]121-christopher work that [she]102-elisabeth had not answered [his]121-christopher question . " Oh ! because they smell ; and it seems so much more like a real sacrifice , somehow , if it smells . "[102-elisabeth] " [I]102-elisabeth see . What ideas [you]121-christopher do get into [your]121-christopher head ! "[102-elisabeth] But [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's volatile thoughts had flown off in another direction . " [You]125-chris really have got awfully nice - coloured hair , "[102-elisabeth] [she]102-elisabeth remarked , [Chris]125-chris having taken [his]125-chris cap off for the sake of coolness , as [he]125-chris was heated with [his]125-chris toil . " [I]102-elisabeth do wish [I]102-elisabeth had light hair like [yours]125-chris . "[102-elisabeth] " [I]121-christopher do n't : [I]121-christopher like dark hair best ; and [I]121-christopher do n't think [yours]125-chris is half bad . "[121-christopher] [Christopher]121-christopher never overstated a case ; but then [one]543-one had the comfort of knowing that [he]121-christopher always meant what [he]121-christopher said , and frequently a good deal more . " Do n't [you]125-chris really , [Chris]125-chris ? [I]102-elisabeth think it is hideous , "[102-elisabeth] replied [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth , taking one of [her]102-elisabeth elf - locks between [her]102-elisabeth fingers and examining it as if it were a sample of material ; " it is like that ugly brown seaweed which shows which way the wind blows — no , [I]102-elisabeth mean that shows whether it is going to rain or not . "[102-elisabeth] " Never mind ; [I]125-chris 've seen lots of [people with uglier hair than yours]3018-people with uglier hair than yours . "[125-chris] [Chris]125-chris really could be of great consolation when [he]125-chris tried . " Are n't the trees lovely when [they]3019-they have got all their leaves off ? "[102-elisabeth] said [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth , [her]102-elisabeth thoughts wandering again . " [I]102-elisabeth believe [I]102-elisabeth like them better now than [I]102-elisabeth do in summer . Now they are like the things [you]3020-you wish for , and in the summer they are like the things [you]3020-you get ; and the things [you]3020-you get are never half as nice as the things [you]3020-you wish for . "[102-elisabeth] This was too subtle for [Christopher]121-christopher . " [I]102-elisabeth like them best with the leaves on ; but anyhow they are nicer to look at than the chimneys that [we]3021-we see from [[our]3021-we house]3022-our house . [You]3020-you ca n't think how gloomy it is for [[your]3020-you rooms]3023-your rooms to look out on nothing but smoke and chimneys and furnaces . When [you]3020-you go to bed at night it 's all red , and when [you]3020-you get up in the morning it 's all black . "[102-elisabeth] " [I]102-elisabeth should like to live in [a house like that]3024-a house like that . "[102-elisabeth] " What on earth do [they]3025-they make [you]102-elisabeth think about ? "[102-elisabeth] [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's gray eyes grew dreamy . " [They]3025-they make [me]102-elisabeth think that [the Black Country]18-the black country is [a wilderness that [we]3021-we are all travelling through]3026-a wilderness that we are all travelling through ; and over it there is always the pillar of cloud by day and the pillar of fire by night , to tell [us]3021-we which way to go . [I]102-elisabeth make up tales to [myself]102-elisabeth about [the people in [the wilderness]3028-the wilderness]3027-the people in the wilderness ; and how [they]3027-the people in the wilderness watch the pillar , and how it keeps [them]3027-the people in the wilderness from idling in [their]3027-the people in the wilderness work , or selling bad iron , or doing anything that is horrid or mean , because it is a sign to [them]3027-the people in the wilderness that [God]105-god is with [them]3027-the people in the wilderness , just as it used to be to [the Children of [Israel]19-israel]3029-the children of israel . "[102-elisabeth] [Christopher]121-christopher looked up from [his]121-christopher work . " And then [I]102-elisabeth pretend that [the people]3030-the people come out of [the wilderness]3028-the wilderness and go to live in [the country over there]3032-the country over there , "[102-elisabeth] [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth continued , pointing to [the distant hills]545-the distant hills ; " and [I]102-elisabeth make up lovely tales about [that country]3033-that country , and all the beautiful things there . "[102-elisabeth] For some minutes [Christopher]121-christopher worked silently , and [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth watched [him]121-christopher . "[524-the latter] " Do n't [you]121-christopher ? "[524-the latter] Rapid changes of sentiment were beyond [Christopher]121-christopher 's comprehension . [He]121-christopher grew to know the feeling well in after years , and to wonder how [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth could understand so much and yet understand so little ; but at present [he]121-christopher was too young to understand [himself]121-christopher . "[102-elisabeth] said [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth one day , opening [the library]3042-the library door a little , and endeavouring to squeeze [[her]102-elisabeth small person]552-her small person through as narrow an aperture as possible , as is the custom with [children]553-children . It was one of [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's little tricks that [her]102-elisabeth fingers were never idle when [she]102-elisabeth was talking . " What have [I]102-elisabeth taught [you]2988-the child are the two chief ends at which [every woman]3071-every woman should aim , [[my]102-elisabeth child]2977-my child ? "[102-elisabeth] " To be first [a Christian]3073-a christian and then [a gentlewoman]3074-a gentlewoman , "[102-elisabeth] quoted [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth glibly . " And how does [a true gentlewoman]3075-a true gentlewoman show [her]3075-a true gentlewoman good breeding ? "[102-elisabeth] " [You]2988-the child mean [I]102-elisabeth must talk about [their]3081-the people to whom you are talking things and not about [mine]102-elisabeth ? "[102-elisabeth] " More than that . Make the most of any common ground between [yourself]2988-the child and [them]3081-the people to whom you are talking ; make the least of any difference between [yourself]2988-the child and [them]3081-the people to whom you are talking ; and , above all , keep strenuously out of sight any real or fancied superiority [you]2988-the child may possess over [them]3081-the people to whom you are talking . [I]102-elisabeth always think that [Saint Paul]129-saint paul 's saying , ' To [the weak]3083-the weak became [I]102-elisabeth as weak , ' was the perfection of good manners . "[102-elisabeth] " [I]102-elisabeth do n't think [I]102-elisabeth quite understand . "[102-elisabeth] [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth spoke in parables . " Then listen to this story . There was once [a common soldier who raised [himself]3084-a common soldier who raised himself from the ranks and earned a commission from the ranks and earned a commission]3084-a common soldier who raised himself from the ranks and earned a commission . [He]3084-a common soldier who raised himself from the ranks and earned a commission was naturally very nervous the first night [he]3084-a common soldier who raised himself from the ranks and earned a commission dined at [[the officers]3085-the officers ' mess]3086-the officers ' mess , as [he]3084-a common soldier who raised himself from the ranks and earned a commission had never dined with [gentlemen]3087-gentlemen before , and [he]3084-a common soldier who raised himself from the ranks and earned a commission was afraid of making some mistake . It happened that the wine was served while the soup was yet on the table , and with the wine the ice . [The poor man]3088-the poor man did not know what the ice was for , so took a lump and put it in [his]3088-the poor man soup . "[102-elisabeth] [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth laughed . " [The younger officers]3089-the younger officers began to giggle , as [you]102-elisabeth are doing , "[102-elisabeth] [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth continued ; " but [the colonel , to whom the ice was handed next]3090-the colonel , to whom the ice was handed next , took a lump and put it in [his]3090-the colonel , to whom the ice was handed next soup also ; and then [the young officers]3091-the young officers did not want to laugh any more . [The colonel]3092-the colonel was [a perfect gentleman]3093-a perfect gentleman . "[102-elisabeth] " It seems to [me]102-elisabeth , "[102-elisabeth] said [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth thoughtfully , " that [you]102-elisabeth 've got to be good before [you]102-elisabeth can be polite . "[102-elisabeth] " Politeness appears to be what goodness really is , "[102-elisabeth] replied [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth , " and is an attitude rather than an action . Fine breeding is not the mere learning of any code of manners , any more than gracefulness is the mere learning of any kind of physical exercise . [The gentleman]3094-the gentleman apparently , as [the Christian]3095-the christian really , looks not on [his]3094-the gentleman own things , but on the things of [others]3096-others ; and [the selfish person]3097-the selfish person is always both unchristian and ill - bred . "[102-elisabeth] [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth gazed wistfully up into [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth 's face . " [I]102-elisabeth should like to be [a real gentlewoman]3098-a real gentlewoman , [Cousin Maria]100-cousin maria ; do [you]102-elisabeth think [I]102-elisabeth ever shall be ? "[102-elisabeth] " [I]102-elisabeth think it quite possible , if [you]102-elisabeth bear all these maxims in mind , and if [you]102-elisabeth carry [yourself]102-elisabeth properly and never stoop . [I]102-elisabeth can not approve of the careless manners of [the young people of to - day]3099-the young people of to - day , who loll upon easy - chairs in the presence of [[their]3099-the young people of to - day elders]3100-their elders , and who slouch into [a room]3101-a room with constrained familiarity and awkward ease , "[102-elisabeth] replied [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth , who had never sat in an easy - chair in [her]102-elisabeth life , and whose back was still as straight as an arrow . So in the afternoon of that day [Christopher]121-christopher and [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth attended [Mrs. Bateson]123-mrs. bateson 's tea - party . [The Batesons]130-the batesons lived in [a clean little cottage on the west side of [High Street]9-the high street]560-a clean little cottage on the west side of high street , and enjoyed [a large garden to the rearward]561-a large garden to the rearward . It was a singular fact that whereas all [their]130-the batesons windows looked upon nothing more interesting than the smokier side of [the bleak and narrow street]562-the bleak and narrow street , [[their]130-the batesons pigsties]563-their pigsties commanded a view such as can rarely be surpassed for beauty and extent in [England]3-england . But [Mrs. Bateson]123-mrs. bateson called [her]123-mrs. bateson front view " lively "[123-mrs. bateson] and [her]123-mrs. bateson back view " dull , "[123-mrs. bateson] and congratulated [herself]123-mrs. bateson daily upon the aspect and the prospect of [her]123-mrs. bateson dwelling - place . [The good lady]564-the good lady 's ideas as to what constitutes beauty in furniture were by no means behind [her]123-mrs. bateson opinions as to what is effective in scenery . [[Her]123-mrs. bateson kitchen]565-her kitchen was paved with bright red tiles , which made one feel as if one were walking across [a coral reef]566-a coral reef , and was flanked on one side with a black oak dresser of unnumbered years , covered with a brave array of blue - and - white pottery . [An artist]567-an artist would have revelled in [this kitchen]568-this kitchen , with [its]568-this kitchen delicious effects in red and blue ; but [Mrs. Bateson]123-mrs. bateson accounted it as nothing . [Her]123-mrs. bateson pride was centred in [[her]123-mrs. bateson parlour]569-her parlour and [its]569-her parlour mural decorations , which consisted principally of a large and varied assortment of funeral - cards , neatly framed and glazed . In addition to these there was a collection of family portraits in daguerreotype , including an interesting representation of [[Mrs. Bateson]123-mrs. bateson 's parents]570-mrs. bateson 's parents sitting side by side in two straight - backed chairs , with [[their]570-mrs. bateson 's parents whole family]571-their whole family twining round [them]570-mrs. bateson 's parents — a sort of [Swiss Family Laocoon]131-swiss family laocoon ; and a picture of [Mr. Bateson]132-mr. bateson — in the attitude of [Juliet]133-juliet and the attire of [a local preacher]572-a local preacher — leaning over [a balcony]573-a balcony , which was overgrown with a semi - tropical luxuriance of artificial ivy , and which was obviously too frail to support [him]132-mr. bateson . But the masterpiece in [[Mrs. Bateson]123-mrs. bateson 's art - gallery]574-mrs. bateson 's art - gallery was a soul - stirring illustration of the death of [the revered John Wesley]115-john wesley . This picture was divided into two compartments : the first represented [the room at [Wesley]115-john wesley 's house in [City Road]22-city road]575-the room at wesley 's house in city road , with [the assembled survivors of [the great man]577-the great man 's family]576-the assembled survivors of the great man 's family weeping round [his]115-john wesley bed ; and the second depicted [the departing saint]578-the departing saint flying across [Bunhill Fields burying - ground]579-bunhill fields burying - ground in [his]578-the departing saint wig and gown and bands , supported on either side by [a stalwart angel]580-a stalwart angel . As [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth had surmised , the entertainment on this occasion was pork - pie ; and [Mrs. Hankey]134-mrs. hankey , [a near neighbour]581-a near neighbour , had also been bidden to share the feast . So the tea - party was a party of four , [the respective husbands of [the two ladies not yet having returned from [their]582-the respective husbands of the two ladies not yet having returned from their duties at the osierfield duties at [the Osierfield]102-elisabeth]583-the two ladies not yet having returned from their duties at the osierfield]582-the respective husbands of the two ladies not yet having returned from their duties at the osierfield . " [I]584-the hostess hope that [you]585-you 'll [all]3102-all make [yourselves]585-you welcome , "[584-the hostess] said [the hostess]584-the hostess , after [they]585-you had sat down at the festive board . " [Master Christopher]135-christopher , [[my]584-the hostess dear]3103-my dear , will [you]135-christopher kindly ask a blessing ? "[584-the hostess] [Christopher]135-christopher asked a blessing as kindly as [he]135-christopher could , and [Mrs. Bateson]123-mrs. bateson continued : " Well , to be sure , it is a pleasure to see [you]135-christopher looking so tall and strong , [Master Christopher]135-christopher , after all [your]135-christopher schooling . [I]123-mrs. bateson 'm not in favour of much schooling [myself]123-mrs. bateson , as [I]123-mrs. bateson think it hinders [young folks]3104-young folks from growing , and puts [them]3104-young folks off [their]3104-young folks vittles ; but [you]135-christopher give the contradiction to that notion — doesn't [he]135-christopher , [Mrs. Hankey]134-mrs. hankey ? "[123-mrs. bateson] [Mrs. Hankey]134-mrs. hankey shook [her]134-mrs. hankey head . It was [her]134-mrs. hankey rule in life never to look on the bright side of things ; [she]134-mrs. hankey considered that to do so was what [she]134-mrs. hankey called " tempting [Providence]136-providence . "[134-mrs. hankey] [Her]134-mrs. hankey theory appeared to be that as long as [Providence]136-providence saw [you]586-you were miserable , that [Power]137-power was comfortable about [you]586-you and let [you]586-you alone ; but if [Providence]136-providence discovered [you]586-you could bear more sorrow than [you]586-you were then bearing , [you]586-you were at once supplied with that little more . Naturally , therefore , [her]134-mrs. hankey object was to convince [Providence]136-providence that [her]134-mrs. hankey cup of misery was full . But [Mrs. Hankey]134-mrs. hankey had [her]134-mrs. hankey innocent enjoyments , in spite of the sternness of [her]134-mrs. hankey creed . If [she]134-mrs. hankey took light things seriously , [she]134-mrs. hankey took serious things lightly ; so [she]134-mrs. hankey was not without [her]134-mrs. hankey compensations . For instance , a Sunday evening 's discourse on future punishment and the like , with illustrations , was an unfailing source of pure and healthful pleasure to [her]134-mrs. hankey ; while a funeral sermon — when [the chapel]322-the chapel was hung with black , and [the bereaved family]588-the bereaved family sat in state in [their]588-the bereaved family new mourning , and [the choir]589-the choir sang Vital Spark as an anthem — filled [her]134-mrs. hankey soul with joy . So when [Mrs. Bateson]123-mrs. bateson commented with such unseemly cheerfulness upon [Christopher]135-christopher 's encouraging appearance , it was but consistent of [Mrs. Hankey]134-mrs. hankey to shake [her]134-mrs. hankey head . " [You]134-mrs. hankey can never tell , "[134-mrs. hankey] [she]134-mrs. hankey replied—"never ; often [them]3105-them that looks the best feels the worst ; and many 's the time [I]584-the hostess 've seen [folks]3106-folks look the very picture of health just before [they]3106-folks was took with a mortal illness . "[584-the hostess] " Ay , that 's so , "[584-the hostess] agreed [the hostess]584-the hostess ; " but [I]584-the hostess think [Master Christopher]135-christopher 's looks are the right sort ; such a nice colour as [he]135-christopher 's got , too ! "[584-the hostess] " That comes from [him]135-christopher being so fair complexioned — it 's no sign of health , "[134-mrs. hankey] persisted [Mrs. Hankey]134-mrs. hankey ; " in fact , [I]134-mrs. hankey mistrust those fair complexions , especially in [lads of [his]135-christopher age]3107-lads of his age . Why , [he]135-christopher ought to be as brown as a berry , instead of pink and white like [a girl]3047-a girl . "[134-mrs. hankey] " It would look hideous to have a brown face with such yellow hair as [mine]135-christopher , "[135-christopher] said [Christopher]135-christopher , who naturally resented being compared to [a girl]3047-a girl . " [Master Christopher]135-christopher , do n't call anything that [the Lord]2978-the lord has made hideous . "[134-mrs. hankey] " But [the Lord]2978-the lord did n't make [him]135-christopher with a brown face and yellow hair ; that 's just the point , "[102-elisabeth] interrupted [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth , who regarded the bullying of [Christopher]135-christopher as [her]102-elisabeth own prerogative , and allowed [no one else]592-no one else to indulge in that sport unpunished . " No , [[my]123-mrs. bateson love]3112-my love ; that 's true enough , "[123-mrs. bateson] [Mrs. Bateson]123-mrs. bateson said soothingly : " a truer word than that never was spoken . "[123-mrs. bateson] " Now [Miss Elisabeth]102-elisabeth does look delicate , and no mistake , "[134-mrs. hankey] assented [Mrs. Hankey]134-mrs. hankey ; " [she]102-elisabeth grows too fast for [her]102-elisabeth strength , [I]134-mrs. hankey 'll be bound ; and [[her]102-elisabeth poor mother]3115-her poor mother died young , [you]3112-my love know , so it is in [the family]3116-the family . "[134-mrs. hankey] [Christopher]135-christopher looked at [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth with the quick sympathy of a sensitive nature . [He]135-christopher thought it would frighten [her]102-elisabeth to hear [Mrs. Hankey]134-mrs. hankey talk in that way , and [he]135-christopher felt that [he]135-christopher hated [Mrs. Hankey]134-mrs. hankey for frightening [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth . But [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth was made after a different pattern , and was not in the least upset by [Mrs. Hankey]134-mrs. hankey 's gloomy forebodings . [She]102-elisabeth was essentially dramatic ; and , unconsciously , [her]102-elisabeth first object was to attract notice . [She]102-elisabeth would have preferred to do this by means of unsurpassed beauty or unequalled talent ; but , failing these aids to distinction , an early death - bed was an advertisement not to be despised . In [her]102-elisabeth mind 's eye [she]102-elisabeth saw a touching account of [her]102-elisabeth short life in Early Days , winding up with a heart - rending description of its premature close ; and [her]102-elisabeth mind 's eye gloated over the sight . [The hostess]584-the hostess gazed at [her]102-elisabeth critically .
