" With which consoling remark [he]803-nice old boy took leave of [[his]803-nice old boy liege - lady]3562-his liege - lady . The friendship between [Alan Tremaine]161-alan and [Elisabeth Farringdon]102-elisabeth grew apace during the next twelve months . [His]161-alan mind was of the metaphysical and speculative order , which is interesting to [all women]3563-all women ; and [hers]102-elisabeth was of the volatile and vivacious type which is attractive to [some men]3406-some men . [They]806-they discussed everything under the sun , and some things over it ; [they]806-they read the same books and compared notes afterward ; [they]806-they went out sketching together , and instructed [each other]3364-each other in the ways of art ; and [they]806-they carefully examined the foundations of [each other]3364-each other 's beliefs , and endeavoured respectively to strengthen and undermine the same . Gradually [they]806-they fell into the habit of wondering every morning whether or not [they]806-they should meet during the coming day ; and of congratulating [themselves]806-they nearly every evening that [they]806-they had succeeded in so meeting . As for [Christopher]162-elisabeth , [he]803-nice old boy was extremely and increasingly unhappy , and , it must be admitted , extremely and increasingly cross in consequence . The fact that [he]803-nice old boy had not the slightest right to control [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth 's actions , in no way prevented [him]803-nice old boy from highly disapproving of [them]806-they ; and the fact that [he]803-nice old boy was too proud to express this disapproval in words , in no way prevented [him]803-nice old boy from displaying it in manner . [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth was wonderfully amiable with [him]803-nice old boy , considering how very cross [he]803-nice old boy was ; but are [we]3567-we not all amiable with people toward whom [we]3567-we — in [our]3567-we inner consciousness — know that [we]3567-we are behaving badly ? "[0-i] [I]0-i can not make out what [you]808-you can see in [that conceited ass]809-that conceited ass ? " [he]0-i said to [her]162-elisabeth , when [Alan Tremaine]161-alan had been living at [the Moat House]34-the moat house for something over a year . "[808-you] Perhaps not ; making things out never is [your]0-i strong point , " replied [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth suavely . "[0-i] But [he]0-i is such [an ass]810-an ass ! [I]0-i 'm sure the other evening , when [he]0-i trotted out [his]0-i views on the Higher Criticism for [your]808-you benefit , [he]0-i made [me]0-i feel positively ill . " "[0-i] [I]0-i found it very interesting ; and if , as [you]808-you say , [he]0-i did it for [my]0-i benefit , [he]0-i certainly succeeded in [his]0-i aim . " There were limits to the patience of [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth . "[0-i] Well , how [women]446-women can listen to bosh of that kind [I]0-i can not imagine ! What can it matter to [you]808-you what [he]0-i disbelieves or why [he]0-i disbelieves it ? And it is beastly cheek of [him]0-i to suppose that it can . " "[0-i] But [he]0-i is right in supposing it , and it does matter to [me]0-i . [I]0-i like to know how old - fashioned truths accord or do not accord with modern phases of thought . " "[808-you] Modern phases of nonsense , [you]808-you mean ! Well , the old - fashioned truths are good enough for [me]0-i , and [I]0-i 'll stick to them , if [you]808-you please , in spite of [Mr. Tremaine]161-alan 's overwhelming arguments ; and [I]0-i should advise [you]808-you to stick to them , too . " "[0-i] Oh ! [Chris]125-chris , [I]0-i wish [you]125-chris would n't be so disagreeable . " And [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth sighed . "[125-chris] It is so difficult to talk to [you]125-chris when [you]125-chris are like this . " "[125-chris] [I]0-i 'm not disagreeable , " replied [Christopher]162-elisabeth mendaciously ; "[0-i] only [I]0-i can not let [you]808-you be taken in by [a stuck - up fool]812-a stuck - up fool without trying to open [your]808-you eyes ; [I]0-i should n't be [[your]808-you friend]813-your friend if [I]0-i could . " And [he]0-i actually believed that this was the case . [He]0-i forgot that it is not the trick of friendship , but of love , to make "[0-i] a corner " in affection , and to monopolize the whole stock of the commodity . "[808-you] [You]808-you see , " [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth explained , "[808-you] [I]0-i am so frightfully modern , and yet [I]0-i have been brought up in such a dreadfully old - fashioned way . It was all very well for [the last generation]814-the last generation to accept revealed truth without understanding it , but it wo n't do for [us]815-we . " "[816-they] Why not ? " "[816-they] Oh ! because [we]815-we are young and modern . " "[816-they] So were [they]816-they at one time , and [we]815-we shall not be so for long . " [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth sighed again . "[808-you] How difficult [you]808-you are ! Of course , the sort of religion that did for [Cousin Maria]100-cousin maria and [Mr. Smallwood]169-mr. smallwood wo n't do for [Mr. Tremaine]161-alan and [me]0-i . Ca n't [you]808-you see that ? " "[0-i] [I]0-i can not , [I]0-i am sorry to say . " "[0-i] [Their]816-they religion had no connection with [their]816-they intellects . " "[816-they] Still , it changed [their]816-they hearts , which [I]0-i have heard is no unimportant operation . " "[816-they] [They]816-they accepted what [they]816-they were told without trying to understand it , " [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth continued , "[816-they] which is not , after all , a high form of faith . " "[816-they] Indeed . [I]0-i should have imagined that it was the highest . " "[0-i] But ca n't [you]808-you see that to accept blindly what [you]808-you are told is not half so great as to sift it all , and to separate the chaff from the wheat , and to find the kernel of truth in the shell of tradition ? " [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth had not talked to [Alan Tremaine]161-alan for over a year without learning [his]161-alan tricks of thought and even of expression . "[808-you] Do n't [you]808-you think that it is better to believe a little with the whole intellect than a great deal apart from it ? " [Christopher]162-elisabeth looked obstinate . "[0-i] [I]0-i ca n't and do n't . " "[0-i] Have [you]808-you no respect for ' honest doubt ' ? " "[808-you] Honest bosh ! " [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth 's face flushed . "[808-you] [You]808-you really are too rude for anything . " [Christopher]162-elisabeth was penitent at once ; [he]125-chris could not bear really to vex [her]162-elisabeth . "[808-you] [I]0-i am sorry if [I]0-i was rude ; but it riles [me]0-i to hear [you]808-you quoting [Tremaine]161-alan 's platitudes by [the yard]817-the yard — such rotten platitudes as they are , too ! " "[808-you] [You]808-you do n't do [Mr. Tremaine]161-alan justice , [Chris]125-chris . Even though [he]161-alan may have outgrown the old faiths , [he]161-alan is [a very good man]818-a very good man ; and [he]161-alan has such lovely thoughts about truth and beauty and love and things like that . " "[161-alan] [His]161-alan thoughts are nothing but empty windbags ; for [he]161-alan is [the type of man who is too ignorant to accept truth , too blind to appreciate beauty , and too selfish to be capable of loving [any woman]820-any woman as [a woman]469-a woman ought to be loved]819-the type of man who is too ignorant to accept truth , too blind to appreciate beauty , and too selfish to be capable of loving any woman as a woman ought to be loved . " "[0-i] [I]0-i think [his]161-alan ideas about love are quite ideal , " persisted [the girl]629-the girl . "[161-alan] Only yesterday [he]161-alan was abusing the selfishness of [men]445-men in general , and saying that [a man who is really in love]823-a man who is really in love thinks of [the woman [he]823-a man who is really in love loves as well as of [himself]823-a man who is really in love]824-the woman he loves as well as of himself . " "[161-alan] [He]161-alan said that , did [he]161-alan ? Then [he]161-alan was mistaken . " [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth looked surprised . "[161-alan] Then do n't [you]825-you agree with [him]161-alan that [a man in love]826-a man in love thinks of [the woman]3411-the woman as well as of [himself]823-a man who is really in love ? " "[825-you] No ; [I]0-i do n't . [A man who is really in love]823-a man who is really in love never thinks of [himself]823-a man who is really in love at all , but only of [the woman]3411-the woman . It strikes [me]0-i that [Master Alan Tremaine]161-alan knows precious little about the matter . " "[161-alan] [I]0-i think [he]161-alan knows a great deal . [He]161-alan said that love was the discovery of [the one woman]830-the one woman whereof [all other women]831-all other women were but [types]832-types . That really was a sweet thing to say ! " "[161-alan] [[My]0-i dear]3103-my dear [Betty]162-elisabeth , [you]162-elisabeth know no more about the matter than [he]161-alan does . Falling in love does n't merely mean that [a man]310-a man has found [a woman who is dearer to [him]310-a man than [all other women]831-all other women]835-a woman who is dearer to him than all other women , but that [he]310-a man has found [a woman who is dearer to [him]310-a man than [himself]310-a man]837-a woman who is dearer to him than himself . " [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth changed [her]162-elisabeth ground . "[0-i] [I]0-i admit that [he]161-alan is n't what [you]838-you might call orthodox , " [she]162-elisabeth said—"not[161-alan] [the sort of man who would clothe [himself]161-alan in the rubric , tied on with red tape]839-the sort of man who would clothe himself in the rubric , tied on with red tape ; but though [he]161-alan may not be [a Christian]3073-a christian , as [we]841-we count Christianity , [he]161-alan believes with all [his]161-alan heart in an overruling Power which makes for righteousness . " "[161-alan] That is very generous of [him]161-alan , " retorted [Christopher]162-elisabeth ; "[161-alan] still , [I]0-i can not for the life of [me]0-i see that the possession of three or four thousand a year , without the trouble of earning it , gives [a man]310-a man the right to patronize [the Almighty]843-the almighty . " "[838-you] [You]838-you are frightfully narrow , [Chris]125-chris . " "[125-chris] [I]0-i know [I]0-i am , and [I]0-i am thankful for it . [I]0-i had rather be as narrow as a plumbing - line than indulge in the sickly latitudinarianism that [such men as [Tremaine]161-alan nickname breadth]844-such men as tremaine nickname breadth . " "[161-alan] Oh ! [I]0-i am tired of arguing with [you]838-you ; [you]838-you are too stupid for anything . " "[838-you] But [you]838-you have n't been arguing — [you]838-you have only been quoting [Tremaine]161-alan verbatim ; and that that may be tiring [I]0-i can well believe . " "[838-you] Well , [you]838-you can call it what [you]838-you like ; but by any other name it will irritate [you]838-you just as much , because [you]838-you have such a horrid temper . [Your]838-you religion may be very orthodox , but [I]0-i can not say much for its improving qualities ; it is the crossest , nastiest , narrowest , disagreeablest sort of religion that [I]0-i ever came across . " And [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth walked away in high dudgeon , leaving [Christopher]162-elisabeth very angry with [himself]162-elisabeth for having been disagreeable , and still angrier with [Tremaine]161-alan for having been [the reverse]3569-the reverse . "[0-i] [I]0-i want to give [[your]838-you work - [people]2982-people]845-your work - people a treat , " said [Tremaine]161-alan to [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth , in the early summer . "[0-i] That is very nice of [you]838-you ; but this goes without saying , as [you]838-you are always planning and doing something nice . [I]0-i shall be very glad for [[our]847-our people]848-our people to have a little pleasure , as at present the annual tea - meeting at [East Lane Chapel]12-east lane chapel seems to be [their]848-our people one and only dissipation ; and although tea - meetings may be very well in [their]848-our people way , they hardly seem to fulfil [one]543-one 's ideal of human joy . " "[838-you] Ah ! [you]838-you have touched upon a point to which [I]0-i was coming , " said [Alan]161-alan earnestly ; "[838-you] it is wonderful how often [our]847-our minds jump together ! Not only am [I]0-i anxious to give [the Osierfield people]850-the osierfield people something more enjoyable than a tea - meeting — [I]0-i also wish to eliminate the tea - meeting spirit from [their]850-the osierfield people idea of enjoyment . " "[838-you] How do [you]838-you mean ? " It was noteworthy that while [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth was always ready to teach [Christopher]162-elisabeth , [she]162-elisabeth was equally willing to learn from [Alan]161-alan . "[838-you] [I]0-i mean that [I]0-i want to show [people]2982-people that pleasure and religion have nothing to do with [each other]3364-each other . It always seems to [me]0-i such a mistake that the pleasures of [the poor]853-the poor — the innocent pleasures , of course — are generally inseparable from religious institutions . If [they]853-the poor attend a tea - party , [they]853-the poor open it with prayer ; if [they]853-the poor are taken for a country drive , [they]853-the poor sing hymns by the way . " "[853-the poor] Oh ! but [I]0-i think [they]853-the poor do this because [they]853-the poor like it , and not because [they]853-the poor are made to do it , " said [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth eagerly . "[853-the poor] Not a bit of it ; [they]853-the poor do it because [they]853-the poor are accustomed to do it , and [they]853-the poor feel that it is expected of [them]853-the poor . Religion is as much a part of [their]853-the poor dissipation as evening dress is of [ours]854-ours , and just as much a purely conventional part ; and [I]0-i want to teach [them]853-the poor to dissociate the two ideas in [their]853-the poor own minds . " "[0-i] [I]0-i doubt if [you]0-i will succeed , [Mr. Tremaine]161-alan . " "[161-alan] Yes , [I]0-i shall ; [I]0-i invariably succeed . [I]0-i have never failed in anything yet , and [I]0-i never mean to fail . And [I]0-i do so want to make [the poor people]855-the poor people enjoy [themselves]855-the poor people thoroughly . Of course , it is a good thing to have one 's pills always hidden in jam ; but it must be a miserable thing to belong to a section of society where one 's jam is invariably full of pills . " [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth smiled , but did not speak ; [Alan]161-alan was [the one person of [her]162-elisabeth acquaintance]3570-the one person of her acquaintance to whom [she]162-elisabeth would rather listen than talk . "[856-english people] It is a morbid and unhealthy habit , " [he]161-alan went on , "[856-english people] to introduce religion into everything , in the way that [English people]856-english people are so fond of doing . It decreases [their]856-english people pleasures by casting its shadow over purely human and natural joys ; and it increases [their]856-english people sorrow and want by teaching [them]856-english people to lean upon some hypothetical Power , instead of trying to do the best that [they]856-english people can for [themselves]856-english people . Also it enervates [their]856-english people reasoning faculties ; for nothing is so detrimental to [one]543-one 's intellectual strength as the habit of believing things which [one]543-one knows to be impossible . " "[0-i] Then do n't [you]0-i believe in religion of any kind ? " "[0-i] Most certainly [I]0-i do — in many religions . [I]0-i believe in the religion of art and of science and of humanity , and countless more ; in fact , the only religion [I]0-i do not believe in is Christianity , because that spoils all the rest by condemning art as fleshly , science as untrue , and humanity as sinful . [I]0-i want to bring the old Pantheism to life again , and to teach [[our]859-our people]848-our people to worship beauty as [the Greeks]861-the greeks worshipped it of old ; and [I]0-i want [you]862-you to help [me]0-i . " [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth gasped as [Elisha]170-elisha might have gasped when [Elijah]171-elijah 's mantle fell upon [him]171-elijah . [She]162-elisabeth was as yet too young to beware of [false prophets]3571-false prophets . "[862-you] [I]0-i should love to make [people]2982-people happy , " [she]162-elisabeth said ; "[173-the english] there seems to be so much happiness in [the world]301-the world and [so few that find it]865-so few that find it . " "[172-the greeks] [The Greeks]172-the greeks found it ; therefore , why should not [the English]173-the english ? [I]0-i mean to teach [them]173-the english to find it , and [I]0-i shall begin with [your]862-you work - people on [Whit Monday]36-whit monday . " "[0-i] What shall [you]0-i do ? " asked [the girl]629-the girl , with intense interest . "[0-i] It is no good taking away old lamps until [you]862-you are prepared to offer new ones in [their]173-the english place ; therefore [I]0-i shall not take away the consolations ( so called ) of religion until [I]0-i have shown [the people]3030-the people a more excellent way . [I]0-i shall first show [them]173-the english nature , and then art — nature to arouse [their]173-the english highest instincts , and art to express the same ; and [I]0-i am convinced that after [they]173-the english have once been brought face to face with the beautiful thus embodied , [the old faiths]867-the old faiths will lose the power to move [them]173-the english . " When [Whit Monday]36-whit monday came round , the throbbing heart of [the Osierfield]102-elisabeth stopped beating , as it was obliged to stop on a bank - holiday ; and [the workmen]3573-the workmen , with [[their]3573-the workmen wives]3574-their wives and [sweethearts]3575-sweethearts , were taken by [Alan Tremaine]161-alan in large brakes to [Pembruge Castle]37-pembruge castle , which [the owner]763-the owner had kindly thrown open to [them]173-the english , at [Alan]161-alan 's request , for the occasion . It was a long drive and a wonderfully beautiful one , for the year was at its best . All the trees had put on [their]3573-the workmen new summer dresses , and never a pair of them were of the same shade . [The hedges]3577-the hedges were covered with a wreath of white May - blossom , and seemed like interminable drifts of that snow in summer which is as good news from [a far country]3578-a far country ; and [the roads]3579-the roads were bordered by the feathery hemlock , which covered the face of [the land]3580-the land as with a bridal veil . "[867-the old faiths] Is n't [the world a beautiful place]868-the world a beautiful place ? " said [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth , with a sigh of content , to [Alan]161-alan , who was driving [her]162-elisabeth in [[his]161-alan mail - phaeton]3581-his mail - phaeton . "[0-i] [I]0-i do hope [all the people]869-all the people will see and understand how beautiful it is . " "[869-all the people] [They]869-all the people can not help seeing and understanding ; beauty such as this is its own interpreter . Surely such a glimpse of nature as [we]870-we are now enjoying does [people]2982-people more good than a hundred prayer - meetings in [a stuffy chapel]872-a stuffy chapel . " "[869-all the people] Beauty slides into [one]543-one 's soul on a day like this , just as something — [I]0-i forget what — slid into the soul of [the Ancient Mariner]874-the ancient mariner ; does n't it ? " "[869-all the people] Of course it does ; and [you]875-you will find that [these people]876-these people — now that [they]876-these people are brought face to face with it — will be just as ready to worship abstract beauty as ever [the Greeks]861-the greeks were . The fault has not been with [the poor]853-the poor for not having worshipped beauty , but with [the rich]879-the rich for not having shown [them]876-these people sufficient beauty to worship . [The rich]879-the rich have tried to choke [them]876-these people off with religion instead , because it came cheaper and was less troublesome to produce . " "[0-i] Then do [you]0-i think that the love of beauty will elevate [these people]876-these people more and make [them]876-these people happier than Christianity has done ? " "[0-i] Most assuredly [I]0-i do . Had [our]870-we climate been sunnier and the fight for existence less bitter , [I]0-i believe that Christianity would have died out in [England]3-england years ago ; but the worship of sorrow will always have its attractions for the sorrowful ; and the doctrine of renunciation will never be without its charm for [those unfortunate ones to whom poverty and disease have stood sponsors]882-those unfortunate ones to whom poverty and disease have stood sponsors , and have renounced all life 's good things in [their]882-those unfortunate ones to whom poverty and disease have stood sponsors name before ever [they]882-those unfortunate ones to whom poverty and disease have stood sponsors saw the light . [Man]174-man makes [[his]174-man god]883-his god in [his]174-man own image ; and thus it comes to pass that while [the strong and joyous Greek]884-the strong and joyous greek adored [Zeus]175-zeus on [Olympus]38-olympus , [the anæmic and neurotic Englishman]885-the anæmic and neurotic englishman worships [Christ]176-christ on [Calvary]39-calvary . Do [you]886-you tell [me]0-i that if [people]2982-people were happy [they]2982-people would bow down before [a stricken and crucified God]888-a stricken and crucified god ? Not [they]2982-people . And [I]0-i want to make [them]2982-people so happy that [they]2982-people shall cease to have any desire for [a suffering Deity]889-a suffering deity . " "[0-i] Well , [you]0-i have made [them]2982-people happy enough for to - day , at any rate , " said [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth , as [she]162-elisabeth looked up at [him]0-i with gratitude and admiration . "[0-i] [I]0-i saw [them]2982-people all when [they]2982-people were starting , and there was n't one face among [them]2982-people that had n't joy written on every feature in capital letters . " "[0-i] Then in that case [they]2982-people wo n't be troubling [their]2982-people minds to - day about [their]2982-people religion ; [they]2982-people will save it for the gloomy days , as [we]890-we save narcotics for times of pain . [You]0-i may depend upon that . " "[0-i] [I]0-i 'm not so sure : [their]2982-people religion is more of a reality to [them]2982-people than [you]0-i think , " [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth replied . While [Alan]161-alan was thus , enjoying [himself]0-i in [his]0-i own fashion , [[his]0-i guests]3582-his guests were enjoying [themselves]3582-his guests in [theirs]3582-his guests ; and as [they]3582-his guests drove through summer 's fairyland , [they]3582-his guests , too , talked by the way . "[0-i] Eh ! but the May - blossom 's a pretty sight , " exclaimed [Caleb Bateson]127-caleb , as [the big wagonettes]3583-the big wagonettes rolled along [the country roads]3584-the country roads . "[0-i] [I]0-i never saw it finer than it is this year — not in all the years [I]0-i 've lived in [Mershire]2-mershire ; and [Mershire]2-mershire 's [the land]3580-the land for [May - blossom]100-cousin maria . " "[0-i] It do look pretty , " agreed [[his]127-caleb wife]3146-his wife . "[0-i] [I]0-i only wish [Lucy Ellen]111-lucy ellen was [here]3308-here to see it ; [she]111-lucy ellen was always a one for [the May - blossom]100-cousin maria . Why , when [she]111-lucy ellen was ever such [a little girl]3044-a little girl [she]111-lucy ellen 'd come [home]399-home carrying branches of it bigger than [herself]111-lucy ellen , till [she]111-lucy ellen looked like nothing but a walking May - pole . " "[111-lucy ellen] [Poor thing]895-poor thing ! " said [Mrs. Hankey]134-mrs. hankey , who happened to be driving in [the same vehicle]3586-the same vehicle as [the Batesons]130-the batesons , "[111-lucy ellen] [she]111-lucy ellen 'll be feeling sad and homesick to see it all again , [I]0-i 'll be bound . " [[Lucy Ellen]111-lucy ellen 's mother]3587-lucy ellen 's mother laughed contentedly . "[3106-folks] [Folks]3106-folks have n't time to feel homesick when [they]3106-folks 've got [a husband to look after]897-a husband to look after ; [he]897-a husband to look after soon takes the place of [May - blossom]100-cousin maria , bless [you]0-i ! " "[897-a husband to look after] [You]0-i 're in luck to see all [[your]0-i children]898-your children married and settled before [the Lord]2978-the lord has been pleased to take [you]0-i , " remarked [Mrs. Hankey]134-mrs. hankey , with envy in [her]134-mrs. hankey voice . "[2978-the lord] Well , [I]0-i 'm glad for [the two lads]900-the two lads to have [somebody]901-somebody to look after [them]900-the two lads , [I]0-i 'm bound to say ; [I]0-i feel now as [they]900-the two lads 've [some one]902-some one to air [their]900-the two lads shirts when [I]0-i 'm not there , for [you]903-you never can trust [a man]310-a man to look after [himself]310-a man — never . [Men]445-men have no sense to know what is good for ['em]906-'em and what is bad for 'em , poor things ! But [Lucy Ellen]111-lucy ellen is a different thing . Of course [I]0-i 'm pleased for [her]111-lucy ellen to have [a home of [her]111-lucy ellen own]907-a home of her own , and such nice furniture as [she]111-lucy ellen 's got , too , and in such a good circuit ; but when [[your]903-you daughter]908-your daughter is married [you]903-you do n't see [her]908-your daughter as often as [you]903-you want to , and it is no good pretending as [you]903-you do . " "[903-you] That 's true , " agreed [Caleb Bateson]127-caleb , with a big sigh ; "[903-you] and [I]0-i never cease to miss [[my]0-i little lass]909-my little lass . " "[111-lucy ellen] So [she]111-lucy ellen be , [Mrs. Hankey]134-mrs. hankey — so [she]111-lucy ellen be ; but [she]111-lucy ellen is [[my]0-i little lass to [me]0-i]911-my little lass to me , all the same , and always will be . [The children]443-the children never grow up to [them]443-the children as loves 'em . [They]443-the children are always [[our]913-we children]914-our children , just as [we]913-we are always [[the Lord]2978-the lord 's children]916-the lord 's children ; and [we]913-we never leave off a - screening and a - sheltering o ' [them]443-the children , any more than [He]2978-the lord ever leaves off a - screening and a - sheltering of [us]913-we . " "[0-i] [I]0-i 'm glad to hear as [Lucy Ellen]111-lucy ellen has married into [a good circuit]917-a good circuit . Unless [the Lord]2978-the lord build [the house]596-the house [we]913-we know how [they]2978-the lord labour in vain that build [it]596-the house ; and [the Lord]2978-the lord ca n't do much unless [He]2978-the lord has [a good minister]921-a good minister to help [Him]2978-the lord . " "[923-a regular superintendent] Oh ! [Lucy Ellen]111-lucy ellen lives in [one of the best circuits in [the Connexion]40-the connexion]925-one of the best circuits in the connexion , " said [Mrs. Bateson]123-mrs. bateson proudly ; "[926-they] [they]926-they have [an ex - president]927-an ex - president as [superintendent]928-superintendent , and [three ministers under [him]927-an ex - president]929-three ministers under him , and a supernumerary as well . [They]926-they never hear the same preached more than once a month ; it 's something grand ! " "[111-lucy ellen] Eh ! it 's [a fine place is [Craychester]41-craychester]930-a fine place is craychester , " added [Caleb]127-caleb ; "[926-they] [they]926-they held Conference [there]658-there two years ago . " "[926-they] It must be a grand thing to live in a place where [they]926-they hold Conference , " remarked [Mrs. Hankey]134-mrs. hankey . "[926-they] It is indeed , " agreed [Mrs. Bateson]123-mrs. bateson ; "[111-lucy ellen] [Lucy Ellen]111-lucy ellen said it seemed for all [the world]301-the world like [heaven]415-heaven , to see so many [ministers about]934-ministers about , all in [their]934-ministers about black coats and white neckcloths . And then such preaching as [they]926-they heard ! It is n't often [young folks]3104-young folks enjoy such privileges , and so [I]0-i told [her]111-lucy ellen . " "[0-i] When all 's said and done , there 's nothing like a good sermon for giving [folks]3106-folks real pleasure . Nothing in [this world]3177-this world comes up to it , and [I]0-i doubt if there 'll be anything much better in the next , " said [Caleb]127-caleb ; "[0-i] [I]0-i do n't see as how there can be . " [[His]127-caleb friends]3588-his friends all agreed with [him]127-caleb , and continued , for the rest of the drive , to discuss the respective merits of various discourses [they]3588-his friends had been privileged to hear . It was a glorious day . The sky was blue , with just enough white clouds flitting about to show how blue the blue part really was ; and the varying shadows kept passing , like the caress of some unseen yet ever - protecting Hand , over [the green nearnesses]3589-the green nearnesses and the violet distances of [a country whose foundations seemed to be of emerald and amethyst]3590-a country whose foundations seemed to be of emerald and amethyst , and [its]3590-a country whose foundations seemed to be of emerald and amethyst walls and gateways of pearl . [The large company from [the Osierfield]102-elisabeth]3591-the large company from the osierfield drove across [the breezy common]3592-the breezy common at [the foot of [Sedgehill Ridge]42-sedgehill ridge]3593-the foot of sedgehill ridge , and then plunged into a network of lanes which led [them]3591-the large company from the osierfield , by sweet and mysterious ways , to [the great highway from [the Midlands]4-the western midlands]3594-the great highway from the midlands to [the coast of [the western sea]3596-the western sea]3595-the coast of the western sea . On [they]3591-the large company from the osierfield went , past [the little hamlet where [the Danes]177-the danes and [the Saxons]3598-the saxons fought a great fight more than a thousand years ago , and which is still called by a strange Saxon name , meaning "[0-i] the burying - place of the slain "]3597-the little hamlet where the danes and the saxons fought a great fight more than a thousand years ago , and which is still called by a strange saxon name , meaning " the burying - place of the slain " ; and [the little hamlet]3599-the little hamlet smiled in the summer sunshine , as if with kindly memories of those old warriors whose warfare had been accomplished so many centuries ago , and who lie together , beneath the white blossom , in the arms of [the great peacemaker called Death]3600-the great peacemaker called death , waiting for the resurrection morning which that blossom is sent to foretell . On , between [man]603-man 's walls of gray stone , till [they]3591-the large company from the osierfield came to [God]105-god 's walls of red sandstone ; and then up [a steep hill]3602-a steep hill to [another common]3603-another common , where the sweet - scented gorse made a golden pavement , and where there suddenly burst upon [their]3591-the large company from the osierfield sight a view so wide and so wonderful that [those who look upon it with the seeing eye and the understanding heart]3604-those who look upon it with the seeing eye and the understanding heart catch glimpses of [the King]3605-the king in [His]3605-the king beauty through the fairness of [the land that is very far off]3606-the land that is very far off . On past the mossy stone , like [an overgrown and illiterate milestone , which marks the boundary between [Mershire]2-mershire and [Salopshire]44-salopshire]3607-an overgrown and illiterate milestone , which marks the boundary between mershire and salopshire ; and then through [a typical English village]3608-a typical english village , noteworthy because the rites of Mayday , with [May - queen]3609-may - queen and May - pole to boot , are still celebrated [there]658-there exactly as they were celebrated some three hundred years ago . At last [they]3591-the large company from the osierfield came to a picturesque wall and gateway , built of the red stone which belongs to [that part of [the country]3528-the country]3611-that part of the country , and which has a trick of growing so much redder at evening - time that it looks as if the cold stone were blushing with pleasure at being kissed Good - night by the sun ; and then through a wood sloping on the left side down to a little stream , which was so busy talking to [itself]3613-itself about [its]3613-itself own concerns that it had not time to leap and sparkle for the amusement of [passers - by]3614-passers - by ; until [they]3591-the large company from the osierfield drew up in front of [a quaint old castle , built of the same stone as the outer walls and gateway]3615-a quaint old castle , built of the same stone as the outer walls and gateway . [The family]3116-the family were away from [home]399-home , so [the whole of [the castle]3619-the castle]3618-the whole of the castle was at the disposal of [Alan]161-alan and [[his]161-alan party]3620-his party , and [they]3591-the large company from the osierfield had permission to go wherever [they]3591-the large company from the osierfield liked . [The state - rooms]3621-the state - rooms were in front of [the building]3622-the building and led out of each other , so that when all the doors were open any one could see right from one end of [the castle]3619-the castle to the other . Dinner was to be served in [the large saloon at the back , built over what was once [the courtyard]3625-the courtyard]3624-the large saloon at the back , built over what was once the courtyard ; and while [[his]161-alan servants]3626-his servants were laying the tables with the cold viands which [they]3626-his servants had brought with [them]3626-his servants , [Alan]161-alan took [[his]161-alan guests]3582-his guests through [the state - rooms]3621-the state - rooms to see the pictures , and endeavoured to carry out [his]161-alan plan of educating [them]3582-his guests by pointing out to [them]3582-his guests some of the finer works of art . "[0-i] This , " [he]161-alan said , stopping in front of a portrait , "[0-i] is a picture of [Lady Mary Wortley - Montagu]178-lady mary wortley - montagu , who was born [here]3308-here , painted by one of [the first portrait - painters of [her]178-lady mary wortley - montagu day]939-the first portrait - painters of her day . [I]0-i want [you]940-you to look at [her]178-lady mary wortley - montagu hands , and to notice how exquisitely they are painted . Also [I]0-i wish to call [your]940-you attention to the expression of [her]178-lady mary wortley - montagu face . [You]940-you know that it is the duty of art to interpret nature — that is to say , to show to [ordinary people]941-ordinary people those hidden beauties and underlying meanings of common things which [they]941-ordinary people would never be able to find out for [themselves]941-ordinary people ; and [I]0-i think that in the expression on [this woman]942-this woman 's face [the artist]393-the artist has shown forth , in a most wonderful way , the dissatisfaction and bitterness of [her]942-this woman heart . As [you]940-you look at [her]942-this woman face [you]940-you seem to see right into [her]942-this woman soul , and to understand how [she]942-this woman was foredoomed by nature and temperament to ask too much of life and to receive too little . " "[942-this woman] Well , to be sure ! " remarked [Mrs. Bateson]123-mrs. bateson , in an undertone , to [[her]123-mrs. bateson lord]3629-her lord and [master]3630-master ; "[942-this woman] [she]942-this woman is a bit like [[[our]944-our superintendent]945-our superintendent 's wife]946-our superintendent 's wife , only not so stout . And what a gown [she]942-this woman has got on ! [I]0-i should say that satin is worth five - and - six a yard if it is worth a penny . And [I]0-i call it a sin and a shame to have a dirty green parrot sitting on [your]940-you shoulder when [you]940-you 're wearing satin like that . If [she]942-this woman 'd had any sense [she]942-this woman 'd have fed the animals before [she]942-this woman put [her]942-this woman best gown on . " "[942-this woman] [I]0-i never could abide parrots , " joined in [Mrs. Hankey]134-mrs. hankey ; "[942-this woman] [they]947-they smell so . " "[947-they] And as for [her]942-this woman looking dissatisfied and all that , " continued [Mrs. Bateson]123-mrs. bateson , "[942-this woman] [I]0-i for one ca n't see it . But if [she]942-this woman did , it was all a pack of rubbish . What had [she]942-this woman to grumble at , [I]0-i should like to know , with a satin gown on at five - and - six a yard ? " By this time [Alan]161-alan had moved on to another picture . "[942-this woman] This represents an unhappy marriage , " [he]161-alan explained . "[942-this woman] At first sight [you]940-you see nothing but [two well - dressed people]948-two well - dressed people sitting at table ; but as [you]940-you look into the picture [you]940-you perceive the misery in [the woman]3411-the woman 's face and the cruelty in [the man]3356-the man 's , and [you]940-you realize all that [they]948-two well - dressed people mean . " "[948-two well - dressed people] Well , [I]0-i see nothing more at second sight , " whispered [Mrs. Hankey]134-mrs. hankey ; "[948-two well - dressed people] except that the tablecloth might have been cleaner . There 's another of [[your]940-you grumbling fine ladies]951-your grumbling fine ladies ! Now for sure [she]942-this woman 'd nothing to grumble at , sitting so grand at table with a glass of sherry - wine to drink . " "[952-the husband] [The husband]952-the husband looks [a cantankerous chap]953-a cantankerous chap , " remarked [Caleb]127-caleb . "[952-the husband] [You]940-you can see from [his]952-the husband complexion that [he]952-the husband is out of order , and that all that rich dinner will do [him]952-the husband no good . [I]0-i 've no patience with [her]942-this woman ! " "[0-i] Still , [he]952-the husband do look as if [he]952-the husband 'd a temper , " persisted [Mr. Bateson]132-mr. bateson . "[952-the husband] And if [he]952-the husband do , [Caleb]127-caleb , what of that ? [I]0-i 've no patience with [the women that will get married and have [a man of [their]958-the women that will get married and have a man of their own own]959-a man of their own]958-the women that will get married and have a man of their own ; and then cry [their]958-the women that will get married and have a man of their own eyes out because [the man]3356-the man is n't [an old woman]961-an old woman . " And [Mrs. Bateson]123-mrs. bateson waxed quite indignant . Here [Tremaine]161-alan took up [his]161-alan parable . "[964-this weird figure , clothed in skins , and feeding upon nothing more satisfying than locusts and wild honey] [This weird figure , clothed in skins , and feeding upon nothing more satisfying than locusts and wild honey]964-this weird figure , clothed in skins , and feeding upon nothing more satisfying than locusts and wild honey , is a type of [all those who are set apart for the difficult and unsatisfactory lot of heralds and forerunners]965-all those who are set apart for the difficult and unsatisfactory lot of heralds and forerunners . [They]958-the women that will get married and have a man of their own see the good time coming , and make ready the way for it , knowing all the while that its fuller light and wider freedom are not for [them]958-the women that will get married and have a man of their own ; [they]958-the women that will get married and have a man of their own lead [[their]958-the women that will get married and have a man of their own fellows]966-their fellows to [the very borders of [the promised land]968-the promised land]967-the very borders of the promised land , conscious that [their]958-the women that will get married and have a man of their own own graves are already dug in [the wilderness]3028-the wilderness . No great social or political movement has ever been carried on without [their]958-the women that will get married and have a man of their own aid ; and [they]958-the women that will get married and have a man of their own have never reaped the benefits of those reforms which [they]958-the women that will get married and have a man of their own lived and died to compass . Perhaps there are [no sadder sights on the page of history]970-no sadder sights on the page of history than [those solitary figures , of all nations and all times , who have foretold the coming of the dawn and yet died before it was yet day]971-those solitary figures , of all nations and all times , who have foretold the coming of the dawn and yet died before it was yet day . " ' "[972-you] Did [you]972-you ever ? " [Mr. Bateson]132-mr. bateson endeavoured to take a charitable view of the situation . " When the inspection of the pictures had been accomplished , [the company]3633-the company sat down to dinner in [the large saloon]3634-the large saloon ; and [Alan]161-alan was slightly disconcerted when [they]987-our opened the proceedings by singing , at the top of [their]987-our voices , "[179-john the baptist] Be present at [our]987-our table , [Lord]990-lord . " [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth , on seeing the expression of [his]161-alan face , sorely wanted to laugh ; but [she]162-elisabeth stifled this desire , as [she]162-elisabeth had learned by experience that humour was not one of [Alan]161-alan 's strong points . Now [Christopher]162-elisabeth could generally see when a thing was funny , even when the joke was at [his]161-alan own expense ; but [Alan]161-alan took life more seriously , which — as [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth assured [herself]162-elisabeth — showed what [a much more earnest man]3635-a much more earnest man than [Christopher]162-elisabeth [he]161-alan was , in spite of [his]161-alan less orthodox opinions . So [she]162-elisabeth made up [her]162-elisabeth mind that [she]162-elisabeth would not catch [Christopher]162-elisabeth 's eye on the present occasion , as [she]162-elisabeth usually did when anything amused [her]162-elisabeth , because it was cruel to laugh at the frustration of poor [Alan]161-alan 's high - flown plans ; and then naturally [she]162-elisabeth looked straight at the spot where [Chris]125-chris was presiding over a table , and returned [his]125-chris smile of perfect comprehension . It was one of [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth 's peculiarities that [she]162-elisabeth invariably did the thing which [she]162-elisabeth had definitely made up [her]162-elisabeth mind not to do . After dinner the party broke up and wandered about , in small detachments , over [the park]3636-the park and through [the woods]3637-the woods and by [the mere]3638-the mere , until it was tea - time . [Alan]161-alan spent most of [his]161-alan afternoon in explaining to [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth the more excellent ways whereby [the poor]853-the poor may be enabled to share the pleasures of [the rich]879-the rich ; and [Christopher]162-elisabeth spent most of [his]125-chris in carrying [Johnnie Stubbs]146-johnnie stubbs to [the mere]3638-the mere and taking [him]146-johnnie stubbs for a row , and so helping [the crippled youth]3642-the crippled youth to forget for a short time that [he]146-johnnie stubbs was not as [other men]3643-other men are , and that it was out of pity that [he]146-johnnie stubbs , who never worked , had been permitted to take the holiday which [he]146-johnnie stubbs could not earn . After tea [Alan]161-alan and [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth were standing on the steps leading from [the saloon]3644-the saloon to [the garden]3284-the garden . "[990-lord] What [a magnificent fellow that is]991-a magnificent fellow that is ! " exclaimed [Alan]161-alan , pointing to the huge figure of [Caleb Bateson]127-caleb , who was talking to [Jemima Stubbs]145-jemima on the far side of [the lawn]3646-the lawn . [Caleb]127-caleb certainly justified this admiration , for [he]127-caleb was [a fine specimen of [a Mershire puddler]3648-a mershire puddler — and there is no finer race of [men]445-men to be found anywhere than [the puddlers of [Mershire]2-mershire]3650-the puddlers of mershire]3647-a fine specimen of a mershire puddler — and there is no finer race of men to be found anywhere than the puddlers of mershire . [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth 's eyes twinkled . "[990-lord] That is one of [your]992-your anæmic and neurotic Christians , " [she]162-elisabeth remarked demurely . [Displeasure]181-displeasure settled on [Alan]161-alan 's brow ; [he]161-alan greatly objected to [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth 's habit of making fun of things , and had tried [his]161-alan best to cure [her]162-elisabeth of it . To a great extent [he]161-alan had succeeded ( for the time being ) ; but even yet the cloven foot of [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth 's levity now and then showed itself , much to [his]161-alan regret . "[990-lord] [Exceptions]182-exceptions do not disprove rules , " [he]161-alan replied coldly . "[995-they] Moreover , [Bateson]127-caleb is probably religious rather from the force of convention than of conviction . " [Tremaine]161-alan never failed to enjoy [his]161-alan own rounded sentences , and this one pleased [him]161-alan so much that it almost succeeded in dispelling the cloud which [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth 's ill - timed gibe had created . "[127-caleb] [He]127-caleb is [a class - leader]993-a class - leader and [a local preacher]572-a local preacher , " [she]162-elisabeth added . "[127-caleb] Those terms convey no meaning to [my]0-i mind . " "[995-they] Do n't [they]995-they ? Well , [they]995-they mean that [Caleb]127-caleb not only loyally supports [the government of [Providence]136-providence]996-the government of providence , but is prepared to take office under it , " [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth explained . [Alan]161-alan never quarrelled with [people]2982-people ; [he]161-alan always reproved [them]2982-people . "[127-caleb] [You]997-you make a great mistake — and an extremely feminine one — [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth , in invariably deducting general rules from individual instances . Believe [me]0-i , this is a most illogical form of reasoning , and leads to erroneous , and sometimes dangerous , conclusions . " [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth tossed [her]102-elisabeth head ; [she]102-elisabeth did not like to be reproved , even by [Alan Tremaine]161-alan . "[0-i] [My]0-i conclusions are nearly always correct , anyhow , " [she]102-elisabeth retorted ; "[0-i] and if [you]997-you get to the right place , [I]0-i do n't see that it matters how [you]997-you go [there]658-there . [I]0-i never bother [my]0-i head about the ' rolling stock ' or the ' permanent way ' of [my]0-i intuitions ; [I]0-i know [they]999-they 'll bring [me]0-i to the right conclusion , and [I]0-i leave [them]999-they to work out [their]999-they Bradshaw for [themselves]999-they . " In the meantime [Jemima Stubbs]145-jemima was pouring out a recital of [her]145-jemima grievances into the ever - sympathetic ear of [Caleb Bateson]127-caleb . "[0-i] [You]0-i do n't seem to be enjoying [yourself]0-i , [[my]0-i lass]1000-my lass , " [he]0-i had said in [his]0-i cheery voice , laying a big hand in tender caress upon [the girl]629-the girl 's narrow shoulders . "[0-i] And how should [I]0-i , [Mr. Bateson]132-mr. bateson , not having [a beau]1001-a beau nor [nobody to talk to]1002-nobody to talk to ? It 's a hard life as [you]132-mr. bateson 've had , and no mistake . " "[132-mr. bateson] That it is , [Mr. Bateson]132-mr. bateson . [Men]445-men wants [gells]1008-gells as look pretty and make ['em]1009-'em laugh ; [they]445-men do n't care for [the dull , dowdy ones]1010-the dull , dowdy ones , such as [me]0-i ; and yet how can [a gell]1011-a gell be light - hearted and gay , [I]0-i should like to know , when it 's work , work , work , all the day , and [nurse]1004-nurse , [nurse]1004-nurse , [nurse]1004-nurse , all the night ? Yet [the men]3428-the men do n't make no allowance for that — not [they]3428-the men . [They]3428-the men just see as [a gell]1011-a gell is plain and stupid , and then [they]3428-the men has nothing more to do with [her]1011-a gell , and [she]1011-a gell can go to [Jericho]46-jericho for all [they]3428-the men cares . " "[0-i] [You]0-i 've had a hard time of it , [[my]0-i lass]1000-my lass , " repeated [Bateson]132-mr. bateson , in [his]0-i full , deep voice . "[0-i] Right [you]0-i are , [Mr. Bateson]132-mr. bateson ; and it 's made [my]0-i hair gray , and [my]0-i face all wrinkles , and [my]0-i hands a sight o ' roughness and ugliness , till [I]0-i 'm [a regular old woman]1018-a regular old woman and a fright at that . And [I]0-i 'm but thirty - five now , though [no one]3126-no one ' ud believe it to look at [me]0-i . " "[0-i] Thirty - five , are [you]0-i ? B'ain't [you]0-i more than that , [Jemima]145-jemima , for surely [you]0-i look more ? " "[0-i] [I]0-i know [I]0-i does , but [I]0-i ai n't ; and [lots o ' [women]446-women]1020-lots o ' women — [them]1020-lots o ' women as has had easy times and [their]1020-lots o ' women way made smooth for [them]1020-lots o ' women — look little more than gells when [they]1020-lots o ' women are thirty - five ; and [the men]3428-the men run after ['em]1023-'em as fast as if [they]3428-the men was only twenty . " "[1072-the lord himself] That is pure imagination and sentiment , [Bateson]132-mr. bateson . Very pretty and poetic , no doubt ; but it wo n't hold water . " [Caleb]127-caleb smiled indulgently . " "[0-i] [I]0-i do n't quite see why . " "[0-i] Well , [you]1057-sir see , [sir]1057-sir , it 's like this . When the dove came back to [the ark]1080-the ark with the olive leaf in [her]1081-her mouth , [Noah]184-noah did n't begin sayin ' how wonderful it was for a leaf to have grown out of nothing all of a sudden , as [some folks]3151-some folks are so fond of saying . " [Tremaine]161-alan looked thoughtful ; [Caleb]127-caleb 's childlike faith and extensive vocabulary were alike puzzles to [him]161-alan . After a minute 's silence [he]0-i said : "[0-i] [I]0-i have been wondering whether it really is any pleasure to [the poor]853-the poor to see [the homes of [the rich]879-the rich]1086-the homes of the rich , or whether it only makes [them]853-the poor dissatisfied . Still , [I]0-i have a good deal of sympathy with socialism [myself]0-i ; and [I]0-i know [I]0-i should feel it very hard if [I]0-i were poor , while [other men]3643-other men , not a whit better and probably worse than [myself]0-i , were rich . " "[0-i] And so it would be hard , [sir]1057-sir , if this was the end of everything , and it was all haphazard , as it were ; so hard that [no sensible man]1091-no sensible man could see it without going clean off [his]1091-no sensible man head altogether . Whether [we]1094-we 're rich or poor , happy or sorrowful , is [His]1093-the master business and [He]1093-the master can attend to that ; but whether [we]1094-we serve [Him]1093-the master rightly in the place where [He]1093-the master has put [us]1094-we , is [our]1094-we business , and it 'll take [us]1094-we all [our]1094-we time to look after it without trying to do [His]1093-the master work as well . " [Tremaine]161-alan merely smiled , and [Bateson]127-caleb went on — "[1092-you] [You]1092-you see , [sir]1057-sir , there 's work in [the world]301-the world of all kinds for all sorts ; and whether [they]1097-they be [lords]1098-lords and [ladies]1099-ladies , or just [poor folks like [we]1094-we]1100-poor folks like we , [they]1097-they 've got to do the work that [the Lord]2978-the lord has set [them]1097-they to do , and not to go hankering after [each other]3364-each other 's . " "[161-alan] [You]161-alan think that religion is the only thing to make [people]2982-people contented and happy ? " "[0-i] No more do [I]0-i , [sir]1057-sir ; that 's where [you]161-alan make a mistake , begging [your]161-alan pardon ; [you]161-alan go confusing principles with [persons]1112-persons . " Thus [the rich man]3659-the rich man and [the poor man]3088-the poor man talked together , moving along parallel lines , neither understanding , and each looking down upon the other — [Alan]161-alan with the scornful pity of [the scholar who has delved in the dust of dreary negatives which generations of doubters have gradually heaped up]3661-the scholar who has delved in the dust of dreary negatives which generations of doubters have gradually heaped up ; and [Caleb]127-caleb with the pitiful scorn of one who has been into the sanctuary of [God]105-god , and so learned to understand the end of [these men]3662-these men . Late that night , when [all the merrymakers]3663-all the merrymakers had gone to [[their]3663-all the merrymakers homes]3664-their homes , [Tremaine]161-alan sat smoking in the moonlight on [the terrace of [the Moat House]34-the moat house]3665-the terrace of the moat house . "[176-christ] It is strange , " [he]0-i said to [himself]0-i , "[176-christ] what a hold the Christian myth has taken upon the minds of [the English people]1120-the english people , and especially of [the working classes]1121-the working classes . [I]0-i can see how its pathos might appeal to [those whose health was spoiled and whose physique was stunted by poverty and misery]1122-those whose health was spoiled and whose physique was stunted by poverty and misery ; but it puzzles [me]0-i to find [a magnificent giant such as [Bateson]127-caleb]1123-a magnificent giant such as bateson , [a man too strong to have nerves and too healthy to have delusions , as thoroughly imbued with its traditions as any one]1124-a man too strong to have nerves and too healthy to have delusions , as thoroughly imbued with its traditions as any one . " At that very moment [Caleb]127-caleb was closing the day , as was [his]127-caleb custom , with family prayer , and [his]127-caleb prayer ran thus — "[1125-we] [We]1125-we beseech [Thee]1126-thy , [O Lord]1127-o lord , look kindly upon [the stranger who has this day shown such favour unto [[Thy]1126-thy servants]1129-thy servants]1128-the stranger who has this day shown such favour unto thy servants ; pay back all that [he]1128-the stranger who has this day shown such favour unto thy servants has given [us]1125-we sevenfold into [his]1128-the stranger who has this day shown such favour unto thy servants bosom . [He]1128-the stranger who has this day shown such favour unto thy servants is very young , [Lord]1130-lord , and very ignorant and very foolish ; [his]1128-the stranger who has this day shown such favour unto thy servants eyes are holden so that [he]1128-the stranger who has this day shown such favour unto thy servants can not see the operations of [Thy]1126-thy Hands ; but [he]1128-the stranger who has this day shown such favour unto thy servants is [not very far from [Thy Kingdom]1132-thy kingdom]1131-not very far from thy kingdom . "[1138-o lord] Do [you]1139-you know what [I]0-i mean to do as soon as [Cousin Maria]100-cousin maria will let [me]0-i ? " "[3347-a great artist] It is sometimes a difficult lesson to learn to be great . " "[3347-a great artist] Nevertheless , [I]0-i mean to learn it . " The possibility of failure never occurred to [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth . "[0-i] There is so much [I]0-i want to teach [the world]301-the world , and [I]0-i feel [I]0-i can only do it through [my]0-i pictures ; and [I]0-i want to begin at once , for fear [I]0-i should n't get it all in before [I]0-i die . " "[0-i] And what time shall [you]0-i reserve for learning all that [the world]301-the world has to teach [you]0-i ? " "[0-i] [I]0-i never thought of that . [I]0-i 'm afraid [I]0-i sha'n't have much time for learning . " "[0-i] Then [I]0-i am afraid [you]0-i wo n't do much good by teaching . " [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth laughed in all the arrogance of [youth]3668-youth . "[0-i] Yes , [I]0-i shall ; the things [you]0-i teach best are the things [you]0-i know , and not the things [you]0-i have learned . " "[0-i] [I]0-i am not so sure of that . " "[0-i] Surely genius does greater things than culture . " "[0-i] [I]0-i grant [you]0-i that culture without genius does no great things ; neither , [I]0-i think , does genius without culture . [Untrained genius]1146-untrained genius is a terrible waste of power . [So many people]1147-so many people seem to think that if [they]1147-so many people have a spark of genius [they]1147-so many people can do without culture ; while really it is because [they]1147-so many people have a spark of genius that [they]1147-so many people ought to be , and are worthy to be , cultivated to the highest point . " "[0-i] Well , anyway — culture or no culture — [I]0-i mean to set the Thames on fire some day . " "[0-i] [You]0-i do , do [you]0-i ? Well , it is a laudable and not uncommon ambition . " "[0-i] Yes , [I]0-i do ; and [you]0-i must n't look so doubtful on the subject , as it is n't pretty manners . " "[0-i] Did [I]0-i look doubtful ? [I]0-i 'm very sorry . " "[0-i] Horribly so . [I]0-i know exactly what [you]0-i will do , [you]0-i are so shockingly matter - of - fact . First [you]0-i will prove to a demonstration that it is utterly impossible for such an inferior being as [a woman]469-a woman to set the Thames on fire at all . Then — when [I]0-i 've done it and [London]15-london is illuminated — [you]0-i will write to the papers to show that the ' flash - point ' of [the river]1149-the river is decidedly too low , or else such an unlooked - for catastrophe could never have occurred . Then [you]0-i will get [the Government]1150-the government to take the matter up , and to bring a charge of arson against [the New Woman]153-woman . And , finally , [you]0-i will have notices put up all along the banks from [Goring]48-goring to [Greenwich]49-greenwich , ' [Ladies]1099-ladies are requested not to bring inflammatory articles near [the river]1149-the river ; the right of setting [the Thames]50-the thames on fire is now — as formerly — reserved specially for [men]445-men . ' And then [you]0-i will try to set it on fire [yourself]0-i . " "[0-i] A most characteristic programme , [I]0-i must confess . But now tell [me]0-i ; when [you]0-i have set [your]0-i Thames on fire , and covered [yourself]0-i with laurels , and generally turned [the world]301-the world upside down , sha'n't [you]0-i allow [some humble and devoted beggarman]1155-some humble and devoted beggarman to share [[your]0-i kingdom]1156-your kingdom with [you]0-i ? [You]0-i might find it a little dull alone in [your]0-i glory , as [you]0-i are such [a sociable person]1157-a sociable person . " "[1157-a sociable person] Well , if [I]0-i do , of course [I]0-i shall let [some nice man]1158-some nice man share it with [me]0-i . " "[0-i] [I]0-i see . [You]0-i will stoop from [your]0-i solitary splendour and say to [the devoted beggarman]1159-the devoted beggarman , ' Allow [me]0-i to offer [you]0-i the post of [King Consort]1160-king consort ; it is a mere sinecure , and confers only the semblance and not the reality of power ; but [I]0-i hope [you]0-i will accept it , as [I]0-i have nothing better to give [you]0-i , and if [you]0-i are submissive and obedient [I]0-i will make [you]0-i as comfortable as [I]0-i can under the circumstances . ' " "[125-chris] Good gracious ! [I]0-i hope [I]0-i am too wise ever to talk to [a man in that way]1161-a man in that way . No , no , [Chris]125-chris ; [I]0-i shall find [some nice man , who has seen through [me]0-i all the time and who has n't been taken in by [me]0-i , as [the world]301-the world has]1162-some nice man , who has seen through me all the time and who has n't been taken in by me , as the world has ; and [I]0-i shall say to [him]1162-some nice man , who has seen through me all the time and who has n't been taken in by me , as the world has , ' By the way , here is a small fire and a few laurel leaves ; please warm [your]0-i hands at the one and wear the others in [your]0-i button - hole . ' That is the proper way in which [a woman]469-a woman should treat fame — merely as a decoration for [the man whom [she]469-a woman has chosen]1165-the man whom she has chosen . " "[1166-o noble judge] [O noble judge]1166-o noble judge ! [O excellent young woman]1167-o excellent young woman ! " exclaimed [Christopher]162-elisabeth . "[1166-o noble judge] But what are some of the wonderful things which [you]0-i are so anxious to teach ? " [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth 's mood changed at once , and [her]162-elisabeth face grew serious . "[0-i] [I]0-i want to teach [people]2982-people that [they]2982-people were sent into [the world]301-the world to be happy , and not to be miserable ; and that there is no virtue in turning [their]2982-people backs to the sunshine and choosing to walk in the shade . [I]0-i want to teach [people]2982-people that [the world]301-the world is beautiful , and that it is only a superficial view that finds it common and unclean . [I]0-i want to teach [people]2982-people that human nature is good and not evil , and that life is a glorious battlefield and not a sordid struggle . In short , [I]0-i want to teach [people]2982-people the dignity of [themselves]2982-people ; and there is no grander lesson . " "[0-i] Except , perhaps , the unworthiness of [themselves]2982-people , " suggested [Christopher]162-elisabeth . "[2982-people] No , no , [Chris]125-chris ; [you]125-chris are wrong to be so hard and cynical . Ca n't [you]125-chris understand how [I]0-i am longing to help [the men and women [I]0-i see around [me]0-i , who are dying for want of joy and beauty in [their]1174-the men and women i see around me , who are dying for want of joy and beauty in their lives lives]1174-the men and women i see around me , who are dying for want of joy and beauty in their lives ? It is the old struggle between Hellenism and Hebraism — between happiness and righteousness . [We]1175-we are sorely in need , here in [England]3-england to - day , of the Greek spirit of Pantheism , which found [God]105-god in life and art and nature , ' as well as in sorrow and renunciation and death . " "[105-god] But it is in sorrow and renunciation and death that [we]1175-we need [Him]105-god ; and [you]125-chris , who have always had everything [you]125-chris want , can not understand this : no more could [the Pagans]1176-the pagans and [the Royalists]1177-the royalists ; but [the early Christians]1178-the early christians and [the persecuted Puritans]1179-the persecuted puritans could . " "[1179-the persecuted puritans] Puritanism has much to answer for in [England]3-england , " said [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth ; "[186-puritanism] [we]1175-we have to thank [Puritanism]186-puritanism for teaching [men]445-men that only by hurting [themselves]445-men can [they]445-men please [[their]445-men Maker]1181-their maker , and that [God]105-god has given [them]445-men tastes and hopes and desires merely in order to mortify the same . And it is all false — utterly false . [The God of the Pagan]1182-the god of the pagan is surely [a more merciful Being]1183-a more merciful being than [the God of [the Puritan]1185-the puritan]1184-the god of the puritan . " "[1183-a more merciful being] A more indulgent Being , perhaps , but not necessarily [a more merciful one]1186-a more merciful one , [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth . [I]0-i disagree with [the Puritans]187-the puritans on many points , but [I]0-i can not help admitting that [their]187-the puritans conception of [God]105-god was a fine one , even though it erred on the side of severity . [The Pagan]1187-the pagan converted [the Godhead]1188-the godhead into flesh , remember ; but [the Puritan]188-the puritan exalted manhood into [God]105-god . " "[188-the puritan] Still , [I]0-i never could bear [the Puritans]1189-the puritans , " [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth went on ; "[1189-the puritans] [they]1189-the puritans turned [the England of [Queen Elizabeth]1191-queen elizabeth]1190-the england of queen elizabeth — [the most glorious England [the world]301-the world has ever known]1192-the most glorious england the world has ever known — into one enormous Nonconformist Conscience ; and [England]3-england has never been perfectly normal since . Besides , [they]1189-the puritans discovered that nature , and art , and human affection , which are really revelations of [God]105-god , were actually sins against [Him]105-god . As [I]0-i said before , [I]0-i can never forgive [the Puritans]1189-the puritans for eradicating the beauty from holiness , and for giving [man]603-man the spirit of heaviness in place of the garment of praise . " "[0-i] [I]0-i wonder if [Paganism]189-paganism helped [you]1196-you much when [you]1196-you were poor and ill and unhappy , and things in general had gone wrong with [you]1196-you . [I]0-i daresay it was very nice for [the cheerful , prosperous people]1197-the cheerful , prosperous people ; but how about those who had never got what [they]1198-they wanted out of life , and were never likely to get it ? " [Christopher]162-elisabeth , like [other people]2980-other people , looked at most matters from [his]0-i own individual standpoint ; and [his]0-i own individual standpoint was not at all a comfortable spot just then . "[172-the greeks] [The Greeks]172-the greeks suffered and died as did [the Jews]1199-the jews and [the Christians]190-the christians , " replied [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth , "[191-modern christianity] yet [they]1200-they were [a joyous and light - hearted race]1201-a joyous and light - hearted race . It is not sorrow that saddens [the world]301-the world , but rather [modern Christianity]191-modern christianity 's idealization of sorrow . [I]0-i do not believe [we]1203-we should be half as miserable as [we]1203-we are if [we]1203-we did not believe that there is virtue in misery , and that by disowning [our]1203-we mercies and discarding [our]1203-we blessings [we]1203-we are currying favour in the eyes of [the Being]1204-the being , Who , nevertheless , has showered those mercies and those blessings upon [us]1203-we . " Thus had [Alan Tremaine]161-alan 's influence gradually unmoored [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth from the old faiths in which [she]162-elisabeth had been brought up ; and [he]161-alan had done it so gradually that [the girl]629-the girl was quite unconscious of how far [she]162-elisabeth had drifted from [[her]162-elisabeth former anchorage]3671-her former anchorage . [He]161-alan was too well - bred ever to be blatant in [his]161-alan unbelief — [he]161-alan would as soon have thought of attacking [[a man]310-a man 's family]3673-a man 's family to [his]161-alan face as of attacking [his]161-alan creed ; but subtly and with infinite tact [he]161-alan endeavoured to prove that to adapt ancient revelations to modern requirements was merely putting new wine into old bottles and mending old garments with new cloth ; and [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth was as yet too young and inexperienced to see any fallacy in [his]161-alan carefully prepared arguments . [She]162-elisabeth had [nobody]409-nobody to help [her]162-elisabeth to resist [him]161-alan , [poor child]3675-poor child ! and [she]162-elisabeth was dazzled with the consciousness of intellectual power which [his]161-alan attitude of mind appeared to take for granted . [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth was cast in too stern a mould to have any sympathy or patience with the blind gropings of [an undisciplined young soul]3676-an undisciplined young soul ; and [Christopher]162-elisabeth — who generally understood and sympathized with all [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth 's difficulties and phases — was so jealous of [her]162-elisabeth obvious attachment to [Tremaine]161-alan , and so unhappy on account of it , that for the time being [the faithful friend]3677-the faithful friend was entirely swallowed up in [the irate lover]3678-the irate lover , sighing like one of [the Osierfield]102-elisabeth furnaces . Of course this was very unfair and tiresome of [him]161-alan — [nobody]409-nobody could deny that ; but it is sometimes trying to the amiability of [even the best of men]3680-even the best of men to realize that the purely mundane and undeserved accident of want of money can shut [them]3680-even the best of men off entirely from ever attaining to the best kind of happiness whereof [their]3680-even the best of men natures are capable — and especially when [they]3680-even the best of men know that [their]3680-even the best of men natures are capable of attaining and appreciating a very high standard of happiness indeed . It may not be right to be unsociable because [one]543-one is unhappy , but it is very human and most particularly masculine ; and [Christopher]162-elisabeth just then was both miserable and [a man]310-a man . There was much about [Alan]161-alan that was very attractive to [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth : [he]161-alan possessed a certain subtlety of thought and an almost feminine quickness of perception which appealed powerfully to [her]162-elisabeth imagination . [Imagination]192-imagination was [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth 's weak , as well as [her]162-elisabeth strong , point . [She]162-elisabeth was incapable of seeing [people]2982-people as [they]2982-people really were ; but erected a purely imaginary edifice of character on the foundations of such attributes as [her]162-elisabeth rapid intuition either rightly or wrongly perceived [them]2982-people to possess . As a rule , [she]162-elisabeth thought better of [[her]162-elisabeth friends]464-her friends than [they]464-her friends deserved — or , at any rate , [she]162-elisabeth recognised in [them]464-her friends that ideal which [they]464-her friends were capable of attaining , but whereto [they]464-her friends sometimes failed to attain . Life is apt to be a little hard on [the women of [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth 's type , who idealize [[their]3685-the women of elisabeth 's type , who idealize their fellows until the latter lose all semblance of reality fellows]966-their fellows until [the latter lose all semblance of reality]3687-the latter lose all semblance of reality]3685-the women of elisabeth 's type , who idealize their fellows until the latter lose all semblance of reality ; for experience , with its inevitable disillusionment , can not fail to put [[their]3685-the women of elisabeth 's type , who idealize their fellows until the latter lose all semblance of reality ideal lovers]3688-their ideal lovers and [friends]3544-friends far from [them]3685-the women of elisabeth 's type , who idealize their fellows until the latter lose all semblance of reality , and to hide [[their]3685-the women of elisabeth 's type , who idealize their fellows until the latter lose all semblance of reality etherealized acquaintances]3690-their etherealized acquaintances out of [their]3685-the women of elisabeth 's type , who idealize their fellows until the latter lose all semblance of reality sight ; and to give instead , to [the fond , trusting souls]3691-the fond , trusting souls , [half - hearted lovers]3692-half - hearted lovers , [semi - sincere friends]3693-semi - sincere friends , and [acquaintances who care for [them]3685-the women of elisabeth 's type , who idealize their fellows until the latter lose all semblance of reality only as [the world]301-the world can care]3694-acquaintances who care for them only as the world can care . [Poor imaginative women]3696-poor imaginative women — who dreamed that [you]3697-you had found [a perfect knight]3698-a perfect knight and [a faithful friend]3699-a faithful friend , and then discovered that these were only [an ordinary selfish man]3700-an ordinary selfish man and [woman]669-woman after all — life has many more such surprises in store for [you]3697-you ; and the surprises will shock [you]3697-you less and hurt [you]3697-you more as the years roll on ! But though life will have its surprises for [you]3697-you , death perchance will have none ; for when the secrets of all hearts are opened , and all thwarted desires are made known , it may be that [the ordinary selfish man]3702-the ordinary selfish man and [woman]669-woman will stand forth as [the perfect knight]3704-the perfect knight and faithful friend that [God]105-god intended [them]3705-them , and [you]3697-you believed [them]3705-them , and [they]3705-them tried yet failed to be ; and [you]3697-you will be satisfied at last when [you]3697-you see [[your]3697-you beloved ones]3706-your beloved ones wake up after [His]105-god likeness , and will smile as [you]3697-you say to [them]3706-your beloved ones , "[1204-the being] So it is really [you]1205-you after all . " Although [Tremaine]161-alan might be lacking in [his]161-alan duty toward [God]105-god , [he]161-alan fulfilled ( in the spirit if not in the letter ) [his]161-alan duty toward [[his]161-alan neighbour]3707-his neighbour ; and [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth was fairly dazzled by [his]161-alan many schemes for making life easier and happier to [the people who dwelt in the darkness of [the Black Country]18-the black country]3708-the people who dwelt in the darkness of the black country . It was while [he]161-alan was thus figuring as [[her]162-elisabeth ideal hero]3709-her ideal hero that [Elisabeth]162-elisabeth went to stay with [Felicia Herbert]154-felicia , near [a manufacturing town in [Yorkshire]51-yorkshire]3710-a manufacturing town in yorkshire . [Felicia]154-felicia had been once or twice to [the Willows]8-the willows , and was well acquainted with the physical and biographical characteristics of [the place]691-the place ; and [she]154-felicia cherished a profound admiration both for [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth and [Christopher Thornley]121-christopher . [Tremaine]161-alan [she]154-felicia had never met — [he]161-alan had been abroad each time that [she]154-felicia had visited [Sedgehill]1-sedgehill — but [she]154-felicia disapproved most heartily of [his]161-alan influence upon [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth , and of [his]161-alan views as set forth by [that young lady]498-that young lady . [Felicia]154-felicia had been brought up along extremely strict lines , and in a spirit of comfortable intolerance of all forms of religion not absolutely identical with [her]154-felicia own ; consequently , [a man with no form of religion at all]3713-a man with no form of religion at all was to [her]154-felicia a very terrible monster indeed . On the Sundays of [her]154-felicia early youth [she]154-felicia had perused a story treating of [an Unbeliever ( always spelled with a capital U]3714-an unbeliever ( always spelled with a capital u ) , and the punishments that were meted out to [the daughter of light who was unequally yoked with [him]161-alan]3715-the daughter of light who was unequally yoked with him ; and [she]154-felicia was imbued with a strong conviction that these same punishments were destined to fall upon [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's head , should [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth incline favourably to the ( at present ) hypothetical suit of [the master of the Moat House]3716-the master of the moat house . Thus it happened that when [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth came to [the Herberts ']3717-the herberts ' , full of girlish admiration for [Alan Tremaine]161-alan , [Felicia]154-felicia did [her]154-felicia best to ripen that admiration into love by abusing [Alan]161-alan in and out of season , and by endeavouring to prove that an attachment to [him]1206-he would be [a soul - destroyer of the most irreparable completeness]3718-a soul - destroyer of the most irreparable completeness . "[1205-you] It is no use talking to [me]0-i about [his]1206-he goodness , " [she]154-felicia said ; "[409-nobody] [nobody]409-nobody is good who is n't [a Christian]3073-a christian . " "[409-nobody] But [he]1206-he is good , " persisted [Elisabeth—"most]193-elisabeth—"most[1206-he] tremendously good . [The poor people]855-the poor people simply adore [him]1206-he , [he]1206-he does such a lot for [them]855-the poor people ; and [he]1206-he could n't have lovelier thoughts and higher ideals if [he]1206-he were [a girl]3047-a girl instead of [a man]310-a man . There must be different ways of goodness , [Felicia]154-felicia . " "[154-felicia] There are not different ways of goodness ; [mamma]1212-mamma says there are not , and it is very wicked to believe that there are . " "[154-felicia] Yes , [I]0-i am ; but [I]0-i have learned that true religion is a state of mind rather than a code of dogmas . " [Felicia]154-felicia looked uncomfortable . " "[102-elisabeth] But [you]154-felicia ought not to think things like that , [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth ; it is n't right to do so . " "[0-i] [I]0-i ca n't help thinking it . " [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth was very hard on [Christopher]121-christopher just then , and nothing that [Felicia]154-felicia could say succeeded in softening [her]154-felicia . [Felicia Herbert]154-felicia was [the eldest of [a large family]3723-a large family]3722-the eldest of a large family . [[Her]154-felicia parents]3724-her parents , though well - to - do , were not rich ; and it was the dream of [Mrs. Herbert]197-mrs. herbert 's life that [[her]197-mrs. herbert daughter]3164-her daughter 's beauty should bring about a great match . [She]154-felicia was [a good woman]3726-a good woman according to [her]154-felicia lights , and [a most excellent wife]3727-a most excellent wife and [mother]3502-mother ; but if [she]154-felicia had a weakness — and who ( except , of course , [one]543-one 's self ) is without one?—that weakness was social ambition . "[1243-you] [You]1243-you will understand , [[my]0-i dear]3103-my dear , " [she]154-felicia said confidentially to [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth , "[1243-you] that it would be the greatest comfort to [Mr. Herbert]198-mr. herbert and [myself]0-i to see [Felicia]154-felicia married to [a God - fearing man]1245-a god - fearing man ; and , of course , if [he]1245-a god - fearing man kept [[his]1245-a god - fearing man own carriage]1246-his own carriage as well [we]1247-we should be all the better satisfied . " "[0-i] [I]0-i do n't think that money really makes [people]2982-people happy , " replied [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth , strong in the unworldliness of [those who have never known what it is to do without anything that money can buy]3730-those who have never known what it is to do without anything that money can buy . "[0-i] Of course not , [[my]0-i dear]3103-my dear — of course not ; nothing but religion can bring true happiness . Whenever [I]0-i am tempted to be anxious about [[my]0-i children]3448-my children 's future , [I]0-i always check [myself]0-i by saying , ' [The Lord]2978-the lord will provide ; though [I]0-i can not sometimes help hoping that the provision will be an ample one as far as [Felicia]154-felicia is concerned , because [she]154-felicia is so extremely nice - looking . " "[154-felicia] [She]154-felicia is perfectly lovely ! " exclaimed [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth enthusiastically ; "[154-felicia] and [she]154-felicia gets lovelier and lovelier every time [I]0-i see [her]154-felicia . If [I]0-i were to change places with [all the rich men in [the world]301-the world]1252-all the rich men in the world , [I]0-i should never do anything but keep on marrying [Felicia]154-felicia . " "[0-i] Still , [she]154-felicia could only marry one of [you]1254-you , [[my]0-i dear]3103-my dear .
