[No girl]1258-no girl could be interested in [Christopher]121-christopher in that way . " "[1258-no girl] Why not , [[my]0-i dear]3103-my dear ? Is [he]121-christopher so unusually plain ? " "[121-christopher] Oh ! no ; [he]121-christopher is very good - looking ; but [he]121-christopher has a good head for figures and a poor eye for faces . In short , [he]121-christopher is [a sensible man]1260-a sensible man , and [girls]519-girls do n't fall in love with [sensible men]1262-sensible men . " "[0-i] [I]0-i think [you]1254-you are mistaken there ; [I]0-i do indeed . [I]0-i have known many instances of [women]446-women becoming sincerely attached to [sensible men]1262-sensible men . " "[1254-you] [You]1254-you do n't know how overpoweringly sensible [Christopher]121-christopher is . " "[121-christopher] And when [he]121-christopher goes for a walk with [a girl]3047-a girl , [he]121-christopher never talks nonsense to [her]3047-a girl , " continued [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth , "[121-christopher] but treats [her]3047-a girl exactly as if [she]3047-a girl were [[his]121-christopher maiden aunt]1267-his maiden aunt . " "[121-christopher] But why should [he]121-christopher talk nonsense to [her]3047-a girl ? It is a great waste of time to talk nonsense ; [I]0-i am not sure that it is not even a sin . Is [Mr. Thornley]199-felicia well off ? " "[199-felicia] No . [[His]121-christopher uncle]775-his uncle , [Mr. Smallwood]169-mr. smallwood , is [the general manager of [[our]1270-our works]1271-our works]1269-the general manager of our works ; and [Christopher]121-christopher has only [his]121-christopher salary as [sub - manager]1272-sub - manager , and what [[his]121-christopher uncle]775-his uncle may leave [him]121-christopher . " "[121-christopher] Still , [I]0-i think [we]1270-our can take that for granted , " said [Mrs. Herbert]197-mrs. herbert , smiling with pride at having seen [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's little joke , and feeling quite a wit [herself]102-elisabeth in consequence . One of the secrets of [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's popularity was that [she]102-elisabeth had a knack of impressing [the people with whom [she]102-elisabeth talked]3731-the people with whom she talked , not so much with a sense of [her]102-elisabeth cleverness as with a sense of [their]3731-the people with whom she talked own . [She]102-elisabeth not only talked well [herself]102-elisabeth , [she]102-elisabeth made [other people]2980-other people talk well also — a far more excellent gift . "[0-i] So , " [she]102-elisabeth went on , "[0-i] if [[his]121-christopher uncle]775-his uncle had n't adopted [him]121-christopher , [I]0-i suppose [Chris]125-chris would have starved to death when [he]121-christopher was [a child]3440-a child ; and that would have been extremely unpleasant for [him]121-christopher , [poor boy]1281-poor boy ! " "[0-i] Ah ! that would have been terrible , [[my]0-i dear]3103-my dear ! " exclaimed [Mrs. Herbert]197-mrs. herbert , so full of pity for [Christopher]121-christopher that [she]102-elisabeth was willing to give [him]121-christopher anything short of [[her]102-elisabeth firstborn]3733-her firstborn . [She]102-elisabeth was really [a kind - hearted woman]3734-a kind - hearted woman . [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth looked out of the window at the group of stunted shrubs with black - edged leaves which entitled [[Felicia]199-felicia 's home]3735-felicia 's home to be called [Wood Glen]52-wood glen . "[0-i] There is one thing to be said in favour of starvation , " [she]102-elisabeth said solemnly , "[0-i] it would keep one from getting stout , and stoutness is the cruellest curse of all . [I]0-i 'd rather be dead than stout any day . " "[0-i] [[My]0-i dear child]1283-my dear child , [you]1283-my dear child are talking nonsense . What would be the advantage of being thin if [you]1283-my dear child were not alive ? " "[1283-my dear child] When [you]1283-my dear child come to that , what would be the advantage of being alive if [you]1283-my dear child were n't thin ? " retorted [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth . "[1283-my dear child] The two cases are not parallel , [[my]0-i dear]3103-my dear ; [you]1283-my dear child see [you]1283-my dear child could n't be thin without being alive , but [you]1283-my dear child could be alive without being thin . " "[1283-my dear child] It is possible ; [I]0-i have come across such cases [myself]0-i , but [I]0-i devoutly trust [mine]0-i may never be one of them . As the hymn says , [I]0-i shall always be ' content to fill a little space . ' " "[0-i] Ah ! but [I]0-i think the hymn does n't mean it quite in that sense . [I]0-i believe the hymn refers rather to the greatness of one 's attainments and possessions than to [one]543-one 's personal bulk . " [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth opened [her]102-elisabeth eyes wide with an expression of childlike simplicity . "[1283-my dear child] Do [you]1283-my dear child really think so ? " "[1283-my dear child] [I]0-i do , [[my]0-i dear]3103-my dear . [You]1283-my dear child know one must not take poetry too literally ; [verse writers]1287-verse writers are allowed what is termed ' poetic license , ' and are rarely , if ever , quite accurate in [their]1287-verse writers statements . [I]0-i suppose it would be too difficult for [anybody]376-anybody to get both the truth and the rhyme to fit in , and so the truth has to be somewhat adapted . But about [Mr. Thornley]199-felicia , [[my]0-i love]3112-my love ; [you]1283-my dear child do n't think that [he]199-felicia and [Felicia]199-felicia are at all interested in [one another]3051-one another ? " "[1283-my dear child] Good gracious , no ! [I]0-i 'm sure [they]1291-they are not . If [they]1291-they had been , [I]0-i should have spotted it and talked about it ages ago . " "[0-i] [I]0-i hope [you]1283-my dear child are not given to talk about such things , even if [you]1283-my dear child do perceive them , " said [Mrs. Herbert]197-mrs. herbert , with reproof in [her]197-mrs. herbert tone ; "[0-i] talking scandal is a sad habit . " "[0-i] But it is n't scandal to say that [a man]310-a man is in love with [a woman]469-a woman — in fact , it is the very opposite . It is much worse scandal never to talk about [a woman]469-a woman in that way , because that means that [you]1283-my dear child think [she]469-a woman is either too old or too ugly to have [a lover]1295-a lover , and that is the worst scandal of all . [I]0-i always feel immensely tickled when [I]0-i hear [women]446-women pluming [themselves]446-women on the fact that [they]446-women never get talked about ; and [I]0-i long to say to [them]446-women , ' There is nothing to be proud of in that , [[my]0-i dears]1297-my dears ; it only means that [the world]301-the world is tacitly calling [you]446-women [stupid old frights]1299-stupid old frights . ' Why , [I]0-i 'd rather [people]2982-people found fault with [me]0-i than did not talk about [me]0-i at all . " "[0-i] Then [I]0-i am afraid [you]1283-my dear child are not ' content to fill a little space , ' " said [Mrs. Herbert]197-mrs. herbert severely . "[1283-my dear child] To tell [you]1283-my dear child the truth [I]0-i do n't think [I]0-i am , " replied [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth , with engaging frankness ; "[0-i] conceit is [my]0-i besetting sin and [I]0-i know it . Not stately , scornful , dignified pride , but downright , inflated , perky , puffed - up conceit . [I]0-i have often remarked upon it to [Christopher]121-christopher , and [he]121-christopher has always agreed with [me]0-i . " "[121-christopher] But , [[my]0-i dear]3103-my dear , the consciousness of a fault is surely one step toward its cure . " "[121-christopher] Not it , " replied [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth , shaking [her]102-elisabeth head ; "[121-christopher] [I]0-i 've always known [I]0-i am conceited , yet [I]0-i get conceiteder and conceiteder every year . Bless [you]1283-my dear child ! [I]0-i do n't want to ' fill a little space , ' and [I]0-i particularly do n't want ' a heart at leisure from itself ' ; [I]0-i think that is such a dull , old - maidish sort of thing to have — [I]0-i would n't have one for anything . [People who have hearts at leisure]1302-people who have hearts at leisure from [themselves]1302-people who have hearts at leisure always want to understudy [Providence]136-providence , [you]1283-my dear child will notice . " [Mrs. Herbert]197-mrs. herbert looked shocked . "[0-i] [[My]0-i dear]3103-my dear , what do [you]0-i mean ? That [their]1304-really good people motives are excellent [I]0-i admit ; [they]1304-really good people are not a bit selfish , and [they]1304-really good people interfere with [you]1283-my dear child for [your]1283-my dear child own good ; but [they]1304-really good people successfully accomplish as much incurable mischief in half an hour as it would take [half a dozen professional mischief - makers]1306-half a dozen professional mischief - makers at least a year to finish off satisfactorily . " "[0-i] [I]0-i do n't hold with [you]0-i there , [Mrs. Hankey]134-mrs. hankey ; it is dull work for the women who have [nobody to order 'em about and find fault with]1316-nobody to order 'em about and find fault with ['em]1317-'em . "[2978-the lord] [You]1328-you see , " continued [Mrs. Bateson]123-mrs. bateson , "[2978-the lord] there 's nothing helps [you]1328-you to understand the ways of [the Lord]2978-the lord like having children of [your]1328-you own . Why , afore [I]0-i was married , [I]0-i was for whipping [every child that was contrairy]1330-every child that was contrairy till it got good again ; but after [my]0-i Lucy [Ellen]111-lucy ellen was born , [I]0-i found that [her]111-lucy ellen contrairiness made [me]0-i sorry for [her]111-lucy ellen instead of angry with [her]111-lucy ellen , and [I]0-i knowed as [the poor little thing]1331-the poor little thing was feeling poorly or else [she]111-lucy ellen 'd never have been like that . So instead of punishing [her]111-lucy ellen , [I]0-i just comforted [her]111-lucy ellen ; and the more contradictious [she]111-lucy ellen got , the more [I]0-i knowed as [she]111-lucy ellen wanted comfort . " "[1334-you] [You]1334-you seem to have comfortable thoughts about things ; [I]0-i only hope as [you]1334-you are not encouraging false hopes and crying peace where there is no peace , " remarked [Mrs. Hankey]134-mrs. hankey severely . But [Mrs. Bateson]123-mrs. bateson was not affrighted . "[1334-you] Do n't [you]1334-you know how ashamed [you]1334-you feel when [folks]3106-folks think better of [you]1334-you than [you]1334-you deserve ? [I]0-i remember years ago , when [Caleb]127-caleb came a - courting [me]0-i , [I]0-i was minded once to throw [him]127-caleb over , because [he]127-caleb was full solemn to take [a young maid]1336-a young maid 's fancy . And when [I]0-i was debating within [myself]0-i whether [I]0-i 'd throw [him]127-caleb over or no , [he]127-caleb says to [me]0-i , ' [Kezia]126-kezia , [[my]0-i lass]1000-my lass , ' [he]127-caleb says , ' [I]0-i 'm not afeared as [ye'll]126-kezia give [me]0-i the slip , for all [your]126-kezia saucy ways ; [other folks]1338-other folks may think [you]126-kezia 're a bit flirty , but [I]0-i know [you]126-kezia better than [they]1338-other folks do , and [I]0-i trust [you]126-kezia with all [my]0-i heart . ' Do [you]126-kezia think [I]0-i could have disappointed [him]127-caleb after that , [Mrs. Hankey]134-mrs. hankey ? Not for [the whole world]3353-the whole world . But [I]0-i was that ashamed as never was , for even having thought of such a thing . Not [He]127-caleb , [Mrs. Hankey]134-mrs. hankey ; [I]0-i know [Him]127-caleb better than that . " "[0-i] [I]0-i only wish [I]0-i could see things in such a cheerful light as [you]126-kezia do . " "[126-kezia] It was only after [[my]0-i first baby]1345-my first baby was born that [I]0-i began to understand [the Lord]2978-the lord 's ways a bit . " This doctrine was too high for [Mrs. Hankey]134-mrs. hankey ; [she]134-mrs. hankey could not attain to it , so [she]134-mrs. hankey wisely took refuge in a side issue . "[0-i] It was fortunate for [you]126-kezia [[your]126-kezia eldest]1349-your eldest being [a girl]3047-a girl ; if [the Lord]2978-the lord had thought fit to give [me]0-i [a daughter]3195-a daughter instead of [three sons]1353-three sons , things might have been better with [me]0-i , " [she]134-mrs. hankey said , contentedly moving the burden of personal responsibility from [her]134-mrs. hankey own shoulders to [[her]134-mrs. hankey Maker]3744-her maker 's . "[2978-the lord] Do n't say that , [Mrs. Hankey]134-mrs. hankey . " "[126-kezia] [You]126-kezia do n't know what it is to live in [a house full of nothing but [men]445-men]1357-a house full of nothing but men , with not a soul to speak to about all the queer tricks [they]445-men 're at , many a time [I]0-i feel like [Robinson Crusoe]202-robinson crusoe on [a desert island]1359-a desert island among [a lot of savages]1360-a lot of savages . " "[202-robinson crusoe] And [I]0-i do n't blame [you]134-mrs. hankey , " agreed [Mrs. Bateson]123-mrs. bateson sympathetically ; "[0-i] for [my]0-i part [I]0-i do n't know what [I]0-i should have done when [Caleb]127-caleb and [the boys]439-the boys were troublesome if [I]0-i could n't have passed remarks on [their]445-men behaviour to [Lucy Ellen]111-lucy ellen ; [I]0-i missed [her]111-lucy ellen something terrible when first [she]111-lucy ellen was married for that simple reason . " "[1364-it] [It]1364-it does , [Mrs. Bateson]123-mrs. bateson ; [you]123-mrs. bateson never spoke a truer word . Many a time have [I]0-i wished for [a daughter]3195-a daughter , if it was but to close [my]0-i eyes ; but [the Lord]2978-the lord has seen fit to withhold [His]2978-the lord blessings from [me]0-i , and it is not for [me]0-i to complain : [His]2978-the lord ways not being as [our]1370-our ways , but often quite the reverse . " "[2978-the lord] That is so ; and [I]0-i wish as [He]2978-the lord 'd seen fit to mate [Miss Elisabeth]102-elisabeth with [Master Christopher]135-christopher , instead of letting [her]102-elisabeth keep company with [that Mr. Tremaine]161-alan . " [Mrs. Hankey]134-mrs. hankey shook [her]134-mrs. hankey head ominously . "[161-alan] [Mr. Tremaine]161-alan is one that has religious doubts . [Poor young man]1372-poor young man ! " "[2978-the lord] [I]0-i hear as [he]2978-the lord goes so far as to deny the existence of [a God]1373-a god , " continued [Mrs. Hankey]134-mrs. hankey . "[2978-the lord] All liver ! " repeated [Mrs. Bateson]123-mrs. bateson ; "[2978-the lord] it often takes [men]445-men like that ; when [they]445-men begin to doubt the inspiration of [the Scriptures]1375-the scriptures [you]1376-you know [they]445-men will be all the better for a dose of dandelion tea ; but when [they]445-men go on to deny the existence of [a God]1373-a god , there 's nothing for it but chamomile . And [I]0-i do n't believe as [the Lord]2978-the lord takes [their]445-men doubts any more seriously than [[their]445-men wives]3574-their wives take ['em]1380-'em . [He]2978-the lord knows as well as [we]1381-we do that the poor things need pity more than blame , and dosing more than converting ; for [He]2978-the lord gave ['em]1382-'em [their]1382-'em livers , and [we]1381-we only have to bear with [them]1382-'em and return thanks to [Him]2978-the lord for having made [ours]1381-we of a different pattern . " "[2978-the lord] And what do [the women as have doubts]1383-the women as have doubts need , [I]0-i should like to know ? " "[3236-a husband] [A husband]3236-a husband and [children]553-children is the best cure for [them]1383-the women as have doubts . Why , when [a woman]469-a woman has [a husband]3236-a husband and [children]553-children to look after , and washes at [home]399-home , [she]469-a woman has no time , bless [you]1390-you ! to be teaching [the Lord]2978-the lord [His]2978-the lord business ; [she]469-a woman has enough to do minding [her]469-a woman own . " "[469-a woman] [Cousin Maria]100-cousin maria , do [you]100-cousin maria like [Alan Tremaine]161-alan ? " asked [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth , not long after [her]102-elisabeth return from [Yorkshire]51-yorkshire . "[100-cousin maria] Like [him]161-alan , [[my]0-i dear]3103-my dear ? [I]0-i neither like nor dislike persons with whom [I]0-i have as little in common as [I]0-i have with [Mr. Tremaine]161-alan . But [he]161-alan strikes [me]0-i as [a young man of parts]1393-a young man of parts , and [his]161-alan manners are admirable . " "[0-i] [I]0-i was n't thinking about [his]161-alan manners , [I]0-i was thinking about [his]161-alan views , " said [the girl]629-the girl , walking across [the room]3736-the room and looking through the window at [the valley]3747-the valley smiling in the light of the summer morning ; "[0-i] do n't [you]0-i think [they]1394-they are very broad and enlightened ? " "[0-i] [I]0-i daresay [they]1394-they are . [Young persons of superior intelligence]1395-young persons of superior intelligence are frequently dazzled by [their]1395-young persons of superior intelligence own brilliance at first , and consider that [they]1395-young persons of superior intelligence were sent into [the world]301-the world specially to confute the law and [the prophets]1397-the prophets . As [they]1395-young persons of superior intelligence grow older [they]1395-young persons of superior intelligence learn better . " [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth began playing with the blind - cord . "[161-alan] [I]0-i think [he]161-alan is awfully clever , " [she]102-elisabeth remarked . "[161-alan] [[My]0-i dear]3103-my dear , how often must [I]0-i beg [you]3103-my dear not to use that word awfully , except in its correct sense ? Remember that [we]1399-we hold the English tongue in trust — it belongs to [the nation]1400-the nation and not to [us]1399-we — and [we]1399-we have no more right to profane [England]3-england 's language by the introduction of coined words and slang expressions than [we]1399-we have to disendow [[her]1401-her institutions]1402-her institutions or to pollute [[her]1401-her rivers]1403-her rivers . " "[3103-my dear] All right ; [I]0-i 'll try not to forget again . But [you]3103-my dear really do think [Alan]161-alan is clever , do n't [you]3103-my dear ? " "[0-i] And [he]161-alan is aw — [I]0-i mean frightfully well off . " [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth looked sternly at [the speaker]3748-the speaker . "[161-alan] Never again let [me]0-i hear [you]3103-my dear refer to the income of persons about whom [you]3103-my dear are speaking , [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth ; it is a form of ill - breeding which [I]0-i can not for a moment tolerate in [[my]0-i house]1407-my house . That money is a convenience to [the possessor of it]1408-the possessor of it , [I]0-i do not attempt to deny ; but that the presence or the absence of it should be counted as a matter of any moment ( except to [the man]3356-the man [himself]3356-the man ) , presupposes a standpoint of such vulgarity that it is impossible for [me]0-i to discuss it . And even [the man]3356-the man [himself]3356-the man should never talk about it ; [he]3356-the man should merely silently recognise the fact , and regulate [his]3356-the man plan of life accordingly . " "[3356-the man] Still , [I]0-i have heard [quite nice people]1411-quite nice people sometimes say that [they]1411-quite nice people can not afford things , " argued [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth . [[Your]0-i quite nice people]1414-your quite nice people would have been still nicer had [they]1414-your quite nice people realized that to talk about [one]543-one 's poverty — though not so bad as talking about one 's wealth — is only one degree better ; and [that perfect gentle - people]1416-that perfect gentle - people would refer neither to [the one]1343-the one nor to the other . " "[0-i] [I]0-i see . " [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's tone was subdued . "[0-i] [I]0-i once knew [a woman]469-a woman , " continued [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth , "[469-a woman] who , by that accident of wealth , which is of no interest to [anybody]376-anybody but [the possessor]1420-the possessor , was enabled to keep [a butler]1421-a butler and [two footmen]1422-two footmen ; but in speaking of [[her]469-a woman household]1423-her household to [a friend]1424-a friend , who was less richly endowed with worldly goods than [herself]469-a woman , [she]469-a woman referred to [these three functionaries]1425-these three functionaries as ' [[my]0-i parlourmaid]1426-my parlourmaid , ' for fear of appearing to be conscious of [her]469-a woman own superiority in this respect . Now [this woman]942-this woman , though kind - hearted , was distinctly vulgar . " "[942-this woman] But [you]1428-you have always taught [me]0-i that it is good manners to keep out of sight any point on which [you]1428-you have the advantage over [the people [you]1428-you are talking to]1429-the people you are talking to , " [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth persisted . "[1428-you] [You]1428-you have told [me]0-i hundreds of times that [I]0-i must never show off [my]0-i knowledge after [other people]2980-other people have displayed [their]2980-other people ignorance ; and that [I]0-i must not even be obtrusively polite after [they]2980-other people have been obviously rude . Those are [your]1428-you very words , [Cousin Maria]100-cousin maria : [you]1428-you see [I]0-i can give chapter and verse . " "[0-i] And [I]0-i meant what [I]0-i said , [[my]0-i dear]3103-my dear . Wider knowledge and higher breeding are signs of actual superiority , and therefore should never be flaunted . The vulgarity in [the woman [I]0-i am speaking about]1432-the woman i am speaking about lay in imagining that there is any superiority in having more money than [another person]3077-another person : there is not . To hide the difference proved that [she]1432-the woman i am speaking about thought there was a difference , and this proved that [her]1432-the woman i am speaking about standpoint was an essentially plebeian one . There was no difference at all , save one of convenience ; the same sort of difference there is between [people who have hot water laid on all over [[their]1434-their houses]1435-their houses and [those who have to carry it]1436-those who have to carry it [upstairs]1437-upstairs . And [who would be so trivial and commonplace as to talk about that]1438-who would be so trivial and commonplace as to talk about that ? " [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth , seeing that [[her]102-elisabeth cousin]451-her cousin]3749-people who have hot water laid on all over their houses and those who have to carry it upstairs . and who would be so trivial and commonplace as to talk about that ? " elisabeth , seeing that her cousin was in the right , wisely changed the subject . "[1439-the bishop of merchester] [The Bishop of [Merchester]53-merchester]1439-the bishop of merchester is preaching at [St. Peter 's Church]54-st. peter 's church , in [Silverhampton]245-lady silverhampton , on [St. Peter]203-st. peter 's Day , and [I]0-i have asked [Alan Tremaine]161-alan to drive [me]0-i over in [his]161-alan dog - cart to hear [him]161-alan . " Although [she]102-elisabeth had strayed from the old paths of dogma and doctrine , [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth could not eradicate the inborn Methodist nature which hungers and thirsts after righteousness as set forth in sermons . [Her]629-the girl trust was not misplaced . "[161-alan] It is [our]1441-our weekevening service , [[my]0-i dear]3103-my dear , with the prayer - meeting after . Did [you]0-i forget ? " [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth endeavoured to simulate the sudden awakening of a dormant memory . "[0-i] So it is ! " "[0-i] [I]0-i see no reason why [you]0-i should not go into [Silverhampton]245-lady silverhampton to hear [the Bishop]1444-the bishop , " said [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth kindly . " So it came to pass , one never - to - be - forgotten summer afternoon , that [Alan Tremaine]161-alan drove [Elisabeth Farringdon]102-elisabeth into [Silverhampton]245-lady silverhampton to hear [the Bishop of [Merchester]53-merchester]1439-the bishop of merchester preach . As soon as [she]102-elisabeth was safely tucked up in [the dog - cart]3756-the dog - cart , with no way of escape , [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth saw a look in [Alan]161-alan 's eyes which told [her]102-elisabeth that [he]161-alan meant to make love to [her]102-elisabeth ; so with that old , old feminine instinct , which made [the prehistoric woman]3757-the prehistoric woman take to [her]3757-the prehistoric woman heels when [the prehistoric man]3758-the prehistoric man began to run after [her]102-elisabeth , [this daughter of the nineteenth century]3759-this daughter of the nineteenth century took refuge in an armour of flippancy , which is the best shield yet invented for resisting [Cupid]204-cupid 's darts . It was a glorious afternoon — one of those afternoons which advertise to [all the world]3760-all the world how excellent was [the lotus - eaters]3761-the lotus - eaters ' method of dividing time ; and although [the woods]3637-the woods had exchanged the fresh variety of spring for the dark green sameness of summer , [the fields]3328-the fields were gay with haymakers , and [the world]301-the world still seemed full of joyous and abundant life . "[0-i] Let 's go [the country]3528-the country way , " [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth had said at starting ; "[0-i] and then [we]1449-we can come back by [the town]314-the town . " So [the two]340-the two drove by [Badgering Woods]47-badgering woods , and across [the wide common]3766-the wide common ; and as [they]340-the two went [they]340-the two saw and felt that [the world]301-the world was very good . [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth was highly sensitive to the influences of nature , and , left to [herself]102-elisabeth , would have leaned toward sentiment on such an afternoon as this ; but [she]102-elisabeth had seen that look in [Alan]161-alan 's eyes , and that was enough for [her]102-elisabeth . "[1451-you] Do [you]1451-you know , " began [Tremaine]161-alan , getting to work , "[1451-you] that [I]0-i have been doing nothing lately but thinking about [you]1451-you ? And [I]0-i have come to the conclusion that what appeals so much to [me]0-i is [your]1451-you strength . The sweetness which attracts [some men]3406-some men has no charm for [me]0-i ; [I]0-i am one of [the men who above all things admire and reverence [a strong woman]1454-a strong woman]1453-the men who above all things admire and reverence a strong woman , though [I]0-i know that [the sweet and clinging woman]1455-the sweet and clinging woman is to some the ideal of feminine perfection . " "[1456-different men] Exactly ; there is a Latin proverb , something about tots and sentences , which embodies that idea , " suggested [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth , with a nervous , girlish laugh . [Alan]161-alan did not smile ; [he]0-i made it a rule never to encourage flippancy in [women]446-women . "[1456-different men] It is hardly kind of [you]1451-you to laugh at [me]0-i when [I]0-i am speaking seriously , " [he]0-i said , "[1451-you] and it would serve [you]1451-you right if [I]0-i turned [my]0-i horse 's head round and refused to let [you]1451-you hear [your]1451-you Bishop . " "[0-i] Oh ! do n't begin heaping coals of fire on [people]2982-people 's head , [Mr. Tremaine]161-alan ; it is a dangerous habit , and [those who indulge in it]1458-those who indulge in it always get [their]1458-those who indulge in it fingers burned in the end — just as [they]1458-those who indulge in it do when [they]1458-those who indulge in it play with edged tools , or do something ( [I]0-i forget what ) with [their]1458-those who indulge in it own petard . " There was a moment 's silence , and then [Alan]161-alan said — "[1458-those who indulge in it] It makes [me]0-i very unhappy when [you]1451-you are in a mood like this ; [I]0-i do not understand it , and it seems to raise up an impassable barrier between [us]1459-us . " "[0-i] Please do n't be unhappy about a little thing like that ; wait till [you]1451-you break a front tooth , or lose [your]1451-you collar - stud , or have some other real trouble to cry over . But now [you]1451-you are making a trouble out of nothing , and [I]0-i have no patience with [people who make troubles out of nothing]1460-people who make troubles out of nothing ; it seems to [me]0-i like getting one 's boots spoiled by a watering - cart when it is dry weather ; and that is a thing which makes [me]0-i most frightfully angry . " "[0-i] Do many things make [you]1451-you angry , [I]0-i wonder ? " "[0-i] Some things and [some people]1461-some people . " "[0-i] Tell [me]0-i what sort of [people]2982-people make [[a woman]469-a woman of [your]1451-you type]1464-a woman of your type angry . " [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth fell into the trap ; [she]102-elisabeth could never resist the opportunity of discussing [herself]102-elisabeth from an outside point of view . If [Alan]161-alan had said [you]1451-you , [she]102-elisabeth would have snubbed [him]161-alan at once ; but the well - chosen words , [a woman of [your]1451-you type]1464-a woman of your type , completely carried [her]102-elisabeth away . [She]102-elisabeth was not [an egotist]3770-an egotist ; [she]102-elisabeth was only intensely interested in [herself]102-elisabeth as the single specimen of humanity which [she]102-elisabeth was able to study exhaustively . "[0-i] [I]0-i think [the people who make]1465-the people who make [me]0-i angry are [the unresponsive people]1466-the unresponsive people , " [she]102-elisabeth replied thoughtfully ; "[1466-the unresponsive people] [the people who do not put [their]1467-the people who do not put their minds into the same key as mine when i am talking to them minds into the same key as [mine]0-i when [I]0-i am talking to [them]1467-the people who do not put their minds into the same key as mine when i am talking to them]1467-the people who do not put their minds into the same key as mine when i am talking to them . Do n't [you]1468-you know the sort ? When [you]1468-you discuss a thing from one standpoint [they]1467-the people who do not put their minds into the same key as mine when i am talking to them persist in discussing it from another ; and as soon as [you]1468-you try to see it from [their]1467-the people who do not put their minds into the same key as mine when i am talking to them point of view , [they]1467-the people who do not put their minds into the same key as mine when i am talking to them fly off to a third . It is n't so much that [they]1467-the people who do not put their minds into the same key as mine when i am talking to them differ from [you]1468-you — that [you]1468-you would not mind ; there is a certain harmony in difference which is more effective than its unison of perfect agreement — but [they]1467-the people who do not put their minds into the same key as mine when i am talking to them sing the same tune in another key , and the discords are excruciating . Then [the people who argue]1469-the people who argue make [me]0-i angry ; [those who argue about trifles]1470-those who argue about trifles , [I]0-i mean . " "[1469-the people who argue] Ah ! [All [you]1468-you women]1471-all you women are alike in that ; [you]1468-you love discussion , and hate argument . The cause of which is that [you]1468-you decide things by instinct rather than by reason , and that therefore — although [you]1468-you know [you]1468-you are right — [you]1468-you can not possibly prove it . " "[0-i] Then , " [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth continued , "[0-i] [I]0-i get very angry with [the people who will bother about non - essentials]1472-the people who will bother about non - essentials ; who , when [you]1468-you have got hold of the vital centre of a question , stray off to side issues . [They]1472-the people who will bother about non - essentials are first - cousins of [the people who talk in different keys]1473-the people who talk in different keys . " "[0-i] [I]0-i should have said [they]1472-the people who will bother about non - essentials were the same . " "[1472-the people who will bother about non - essentials] Well , perhaps [they]1472-the people who will bother about non - essentials are ; [I]0-i believe [you]0-i are right . [Christopher Thornley]121-christopher is one of that sort ; when [you]1468-you are discussing one side of a thing with [him]121-christopher , [you]1468-you 'll find [him]121-christopher playing bo - peep with [you]1468-you round the other ; and [you]1468-you never can get [him]121-christopher into the right mood at the right time . [He]121-christopher makes [me]0-i simply furious sometimes . Do [you]0-i know , [I]0-i think if [I]0-i were a dog [I]0-i should often bite [Christopher]121-christopher ? " [Alan]161-alan smiled faintly at this ; jokes at [Christopher]121-christopher 's expense were naturally more humorous than jokes at [his]161-alan own . "[121-christopher] And what [other sorts of people]1474-other sorts of people make [you]0-i angry ? " [he]0-i asked . "[121-christopher] [I]0-i 'm afraid [the people who make [me]0-i angriest of all]1475-the people who make me angriest of all are [the people who wo n't do what [I]0-i tell [them]1476-the people who wo n't do what i tell them]1476-the people who wo n't do what i tell them . [They]1476-the people who wo n't do what i tell them really madden [me]0-i . " And [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth began to laugh . "[1476-the people who wo n't do what i tell them] [I]0-i 've got a horribly strong will , [you]0-i see , and if [people]2982-people go against it , [I]0-i want [them]2982-people to be sent to [the dentist]1478-the dentist 's every morning , and to [the photographer]1479-the photographer 's every afternoon , for the rest of [their]2982-people lives . Now [Christopher]121-christopher is one of the worst of those ; [I]0-i ca n't make [him]121-christopher do what [I]0-i want just because [I]0-i want it ; [he]121-christopher always wishes to know why [I]0-i want it , and that is so silly and tiresome of [him]121-christopher , because nine times out of ten [I]0-i do n't know [myself]0-i . " "[0-i] Very trying ! " "[121-christopher] [Christopher]121-christopher certainly has the knack of making [me]0-i angrier than [anybody else [I]0-i ever met]1480-anybody else i ever met , " said [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth thoughtfully . "[121-christopher] [I]0-i wonder why it is ? [I]0-i suppose it must be because [I]0-i have known [him]121-christopher for so long . [I]0-i ca n't see any other reason . [I]0-i am generally such [an easy - going , good - tempered girl]1481-an easy - going , good - tempered girl ; but when [Christopher]121-christopher begins to argue and dictate and contradict , [the Furies]1482-the furies simply are n't in it with [me]0-i . " "[1482-the furies] [The excellent Thornley]121-christopher certainly has [his]121-christopher limitations . " [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's eyes flashed . [She]102-elisabeth did not mind finding fault with [Christopher]121-christopher [herself]102-elisabeth ; in fact , [she]102-elisabeth found such fault - finding absolutely necessary to [her]102-elisabeth well - being ; but [she]102-elisabeth resented any attempt on the part of another to usurp this , [her]102-elisabeth peculiar prerogative . "[121-christopher] [He]121-christopher is very good , all the same , " [she]102-elisabeth said , "[121-christopher] and extremely clever ; and [he]121-christopher is [[my]0-i greatest friend]1483-my greatest friend . " But [Alan]161-alan was bored by [Christopher]121-christopher as a subject of conversation , so [he]161-alan changed [him]121-christopher for [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's self . "[121-christopher] How loyal [you]0-i are ! " [he]161-alan exclaimed with admiration ; "[121-christopher] it is indeed a patent of nobility to be counted among [[your]0-i friends]1484-your friends . " [The girl]629-the girl , having just been guilty of disloyalty , was naturally delighted at this compliment . "[1485-you] [You]1485-you always understand and appreciate [me]0-i , " [she]629-the girl said gratefully , unconscious of the fact that it was [Alan]161-alan 's lack of understanding and appreciation which had aroused [her]629-the girl gratitude just then . Perfect comprehension — untempered by perfect love — would be a terrible thing ; mercifully for [[us]3772-us poor mortals]3773-us poor mortals it does not exist . [Alan]161-alan went on : "[1485-you] Because [I]0-i possess this patent of nobility , [I]0-i am going to presume upon [my]0-i privileges and ask [you]0-i to help [me]0-i in [my]0-i life - work ; and [my]0-i life - work , as [you]0-i know , is to ameliorate the condition of [the poor]853-the poor , and to carry to some extent the burdens which [they]853-the poor are bound to bear . " [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth looked up at [him]161-alan , [her]102-elisabeth face full of interest ; no appeal to [her]102-elisabeth pity was ever made in vain . If [people]2982-people expected [her]102-elisabeth to admire [them]2982-people , [they]2982-people were frequently disappointed ; if [they]2982-people wished [her]102-elisabeth to fear [them]2982-people , [their]2982-people wish was absolutely denied ; but if [they]2982-people only wanted [her]102-elisabeth to be sorry for [them]2982-people , [they]2982-people were abundantly satisfied , sympathy being the keynote of [her]102-elisabeth character . [She]102-elisabeth was too fastidious often to admire ; [she]102-elisabeth was too strong ever to fear ; but [her]102-elisabeth tenderness was unfailing toward those who had once appealed to [her]102-elisabeth pity , and whose weakness had for once allowed itself to rest upon [her]102-elisabeth strength . Therefore [Alan]161-alan 's desire to help [the poor]853-the poor , and to make [them]853-the poor happier , struck the dominant chord in [her]102-elisabeth nature ; but unfortunately when [she]102-elisabeth raised [her]102-elisabeth eyes , full of sympathetic sympathy , to [his]161-alan , [she]102-elisabeth encountered that look in the latter which had frightened [her]102-elisabeth at the beginning of the excursion ; so [she]102-elisabeth again clothed [herself]102-elisabeth in [her]102-elisabeth garment of flippancy , and hardened [her]102-elisabeth heart as the nether millstone . In blissful unconsciousness [Alan]161-alan continued — "[0-i] Society is just now passing through a transition stage . The interests of capital and labour are at war with [each other]3364-each other ; [the rich]879-the rich and [the poor]853-the poor are as two armies made ready for battle , and the question is , What can [we]1490-we do to bridge over the gulf between the classes , and to induce [them]1491-them each to work for , instead of against , the other ? It is these transition stages which have proved the most difficult epochs in [the world]301-the world 's history . " "[0-i] [I]0-i hate transition stages and revolutions , they are so unsettling . It seems to [me]0-i they are just like the day when [[your]1493-you room]1494-your room is cleaned ; and that is the most uncomfortable day in the whole week . Do n't [you]1493-you know it ? [You]1493-you go [upstairs]1437-upstairs in the accustomed way , fearing nothing ; but when [you]1493-you open the door [you]1493-you find the air dark with dust and the floor with tea - leaves , and nothing looking as it ought to look . Prone on [its]1496-its face on the bed , covered with a winding - sheet , lies [your]1493-you overthrown looking - glass ; and underneath it , in a shapeless mass , are huddled together all the things that [you]1493-you hold dearest upon [earth]614-earth . [You]1493-you thrust in [your]1493-you hand to get something that [you]1493-you want , and it is a pure chance whether [your]1493-you Bible or [your]1493-you button - hook rises to the surface . And it seems to [me]0-i that transition periods are just like that . " "[1493-you] How volatile [you]1493-you are ! One minute [you]1493-you are so serious and the next so frivolous that [I]0-i fail to follow [you]1493-you . [I]0-i often think that [you]1493-you must have some foreign blood in [your]1493-you veins , [you]1493-you are so utterly different from [the typical , stolid , shy , self - conscious English - woman]1498-the typical , stolid , shy , self - conscious english - woman . " "[0-i] [I]0-i hope [you]1493-you do n't think [I]0-i was made in [Germany]28-germany , like cheap china and [imitation Astrakhan]1499-imitation astrakhan . " "[1493-you] Heaven forbid ! [The Germans]205-the germans are more stolid and serious than [the English]173-the english . But [you]1493-you must have [a Celtic ancestor]1500-a celtic ancestor in [you]1493-you somewhere . Have n't [you]1493-you ? " "[1493-you] Well , to tell [you]1493-you the truth , [[my]0-i great - grandmother]1501-my great - grandmother was [a Manxwoman]1502-a manxwoman ; but [we]1503-we are ashamed to talk much about [her]1501-my great - grandmother , because it sounds as if [she]1501-my great - grandmother 'd had no tail . " "[1501-my great - grandmother] Then [you]1493-you must have inherited [your]1493-you temperament from [her]1501-my great - grandmother . But now [I]0-i want to talk to [you]1493-you seriously about doing something for [the men who work in [the coal - pits]1505-the coal - pits]1504-the men who work in the coal - pits , and who — more even than the rest of [[their]1504-the men who work in the coal - pits class]1506-their class — are shut out from the joy and beauty of [the world]301-the world . [Their]1504-the men who work in the coal - pits lives not only are made hideous , but are also shortened , by the nature of [their]1504-the men who work in the coal - pits toil . Do [you]1493-you know what the average life of [a miner]1508-a miner is ? " "[1493-you] Of course [I]0-i do : twenty - one years . " [Alan]161-alan frowned ; [he]161-alan disapproved of jokes even more than of [creeds]3776-creeds , and understood [them]3777-them equally . "[0-i] [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth , [you]1493-you are not behaving fairly to [me]0-i . [You]1493-you know what [I]0-i mean well enough , but [you]1493-you wilfully misunderstand [my]0-i words for the sake of laughing at them . But [I]0-i will make [you]1493-you listen , all the same . [I]0-i want to know if [you]1493-you will help [me]0-i in [my]0-i work by becoming [[my]0-i wife]1113-my wife ; and [I]0-i think that even [you]1493-you can not help answering that question seriously . " The laughter vanished from [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's face , as if it had been wiped out with a sponge . "[0-i] Oh ! [I]0-i — [I]0-i do n't know , " [she]102-elisabeth murmured lamely . "[0-i] Then [you]1493-you must find out . To [me]0-i it seems that [you]1493-you are [the one woman in [all the world]3760-all the world who was made for [me]0-i]1510-the one woman in all the world who was made for me . [Your]1493-you personality attracted [me]0-i the first moment that [I]0-i met [you]1493-you ; and [our]1512-our subsequent companionship has proved that [our]1512-our minds habitually run in the same grooves , and that [we]1512-our naturally look at things from the same standpoint . That is so , is it not ? " "[1493-you] Yes . " "[1493-you] The only serious difference between [us]1512-our seemed to be the difference of faith . [You]1493-you had been trained in the doctrines of one of the strictest sects , while [I]0-i had outgrown all dogmas and thrown aside all recognised forms of religion . So strong were [my]0-i feelings on this point , that [I]0-i would not have married [any woman who still clung to the worn - out and ( by [me]0-i ) disused traditions]1513-any woman who still clung to the worn - out and ( by me ) disused traditions ; but [I]0-i fancy that [I]0-i have succeeded in converting [you]1493-you to [my]0-i views , and that [our]1512-our ideas upon religion are now practically identical . Is not that so ? " [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth thought for a moment . "[1493-you] Yes , " [she]102-elisabeth answered slowly ; "[1493-you] [you]1493-you have taught [me]0-i that Christianity , like all the other old religions , has had its day ; and that [the world]301-the world is now ready for a new dispensation . " "[1493-you] Exactly ; and for a dispensation which shall unite the pure ethics of [the Christian]3095-the christian to the joyous vitality of [the Greek]206-the greek , eliminating alike the melancholy of the one and the sensualism of the other . [You]1493-you agree with [me]0-i in this , do [you]1493-you not ? " "[1493-you] [You]1493-you know that [I]0-i do . " "[1493-you] [I]0-i am glad , because — as [I]0-i said before — [I]0-i could not bear to marry [any woman who did not see eye to eye with [me]0-i on these vital matters]1516-any woman who did not see eye to eye with me on these vital matters . [I]0-i love [you]1493-you very dearly , [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth , and it would be a great grief to [me]0-i if any question of opinion or conviction came between [us]1517-us ; yet [I]0-i do not believe that [two people]1518-two people could possibly be happy together — however much [they]1518-two people might love [each other]3364-each other — if [they]1518-two people were not one with [each other]3364-each other on subjects such as these . " [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth was silent ; [she]102-elisabeth was too much excited to speak . [Her]102-elisabeth heart was thumping like the great hammer at [the Osierfield]102-elisabeth , and [she]102-elisabeth was trembling all over . So [she]102-elisabeth held [her]102-elisabeth peace as [they]1517-us drove up [the principal street of Silverhampton]3778-the principal street of silverhampton and across [the King 's Square]3779-the king 's square to [the lych - gate of [St. Peter 's Church]54-st. peter 's church]3780-the lych - gate of st. peter 's church ; but [Alan]161-alan , looking into the tell - tale face [he]161-alan knew so well , was quite content . Yet as [she]102-elisabeth sat beside [Alan]161-alan in [St. Peter 's Church]54-st. peter 's church that summer evening , and thought upon what [she]102-elisabeth had just done , a great sadness filled [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's soul . The sun shone brightly through the western window , and wrote mystic messages upon the gray stone walls ; but the lights of the east window shone pale and cold in the distant apse , where the Figure of [the Crucified]3781-the crucified gleamed white upon a foundation of emerald . And as [she]102-elisabeth looked at the Figure , which [the world]301-the world has wept over and worshipped for nineteen centuries , [she]102-elisabeth realized that this was the Symbol of all that [she]102-elisabeth was giving up and leaving behind [her]102-elisabeth — the Sign of that religion of love and sorrow which [men]445-men call Christianity . [She]102-elisabeth felt that wisdom must be justified of [[her]102-elisabeth children]3784-her children , and not least of [her]102-elisabeth , [Elisabeth Farringdon]102-elisabeth ; nevertheless , [she]102-elisabeth mourned for the myth which had once made life seem fair , and death even fairer . Although [she]102-elisabeth had outgrown [her]102-elisabeth belief in it , its beauty had still power to touch [her]102-elisabeth heart , if not to convince [her]102-elisabeth intellect ; and [she]102-elisabeth sighed as [she]102-elisabeth recalled all that it had once meant , and how it had appeared to be the one satisfactory solution to the problems which weary and perplex [mankind]3785-mankind . Now [she]102-elisabeth must face all the problems over again in the grim twilight of dawning science , with no longer a Star of Bethlehem to show where the answer might be found ; and [her]102-elisabeth spirit quailed at the pitiless prospect . [She]102-elisabeth had never understood before how much that Symbol of eternal love and vicarious suffering had been to [her]102-elisabeth , nor how puzzling would be the path through [the wilderness]3028-the wilderness if there were no Crucifix at life 's cross - roads to show [the traveller]734-the traveller which way to go ; and [her]102-elisabeth heart grew heavier as [she]102-elisabeth took part in [the sacred office of Evensong]3788-the sacred office of evensong , and thought how beautiful it all would be if only it were true . [She]102-elisabeth longed to be [a little child]3789-a little child again — [a child to whom the things which are not seen are as the things which are seen]3790-a child to whom the things which are not seen are as the things which are seen , and the things which are not as the things which are ; and [she]102-elisabeth could have cried with homesickness when [she]102-elisabeth remembered how firmly [she]102-elisabeth had once believed that the shadow which hung over [the Osierfield]102-elisabeth was a pillar of cloud by day and a pillar of fire by night , to testify that [God]105-god was still watching over [[His]105-god people]345-his people , as in the days of old . Now [she]102-elisabeth knew that the pillar was only the smoke and the flame of human industries ; and the knowledge brought a load of sadness , as it seemed to typify that there was no longer any help for [the world]301-the world but in itself . When [the Bishop]1444-the bishop ascended the pulpit , [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth recalled [her]102-elisabeth wandering thoughts and set [herself]102-elisabeth to listen . [No one who possesses a drop of Nonconformist blood]3794-no one who possesses a drop of nonconformist blood can ever succeed in not listening to a sermon , even if it be a poor one ; and [the Bishop of [Merchester]53-merchester]1439-the bishop of merchester was [one of [the finest preachers of [his]1439-the bishop of merchester day]3797-the finest preachers of his day]3796-one of the finest preachers of his day . [His]1439-the bishop of merchester text was , "[1521-thou] Blessed art [thou]1521-thou , [Simon Barjona]207-simon barjona : for flesh and blood hath not revealed it unto [thee]1521-thou " ; and [he]1439-the bishop of merchester endeavoured to set forth how it is only [God]105-god who can teach [men]445-men about [God]105-god , and how flesh and blood can never show [us]445-men [the Christ]176-christ until [He]176-christ chooses to reveal [Himself]176-christ . At first [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth listened only with [her]102-elisabeth mind , expecting an intellectual treat and nothing more ; but as [he]1439-the bishop of merchester went on , and showed how the Call comes in strange places and at strange times , and how when it comes there is no resisting it , [her]102-elisabeth heart began to burn within [her]102-elisabeth ; and [she]102-elisabeth recognised [the preacher]797-the preacher , not only as [a man of divers gifts and great powers]3800-a man of divers gifts and great powers , but as [the ambassador of [Christ]176-christ sent direct to [her]102-elisabeth soul]3801-the ambassador of christ sent direct to her soul . Then slowly [her]102-elisabeth eyes were opened , and [she]102-elisabeth knew that the Figure in the east window was no Sign of an imaginary renunciation , no Symbol of a worn - out creed , but the portrait of [a living Person]3802-a living person , Whose Voice was calling [her]102-elisabeth , and Whose Love was constraining [her]102-elisabeth , and Whose Power was enfolding [her]102-elisabeth and would not let [her]102-elisabeth go . With the certainty that is too absolute for proof , [she]102-elisabeth knew in Whom [she]102-elisabeth now believed ; and [she]102-elisabeth knew , further , that it was not [her]102-elisabeth own mind nor [the preacher]797-the preacher 's words that had suddenly shown [her]102-elisabeth the truth — flesh and blood had not revealed it to [her]102-elisabeth , but [Christ]176-christ [Himself]176-christ . When the service was over , [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth came out into the sunlight with a strange , new , exultant feeling , such as [she]102-elisabeth had never felt before . [She]102-elisabeth stood in [the old churchyard]3804-the old churchyard , waiting for [Alan]161-alan to bring round [the dog - cart]3756-the dog - cart , and watching the sun set beyond [the distant hills]545-the distant hills ; and [she]102-elisabeth was conscious — how [she]102-elisabeth could not explain — that the sunset was different from any other sunset that [she]102-elisabeth had ever seen . [She]102-elisabeth had always loved nature with an intense love ; but now there seemed a richer gold in the parting sunbeams — a sweeter mystery behind [the far - off hills]3807-the far - off hills — because of that Figure in the east window . It was as if [she]102-elisabeth saw again [a land which [she]102-elisabeth had always loved]3808-a land which she had always loved , and now learned for the first time that it belonged to [some one who was dear to [her]102-elisabeth]3809-some one who was dear to her ; a new sense of ownership mingled with the old delight , and gave an added interest to the smallest detail . Then [she]102-elisabeth and [Alan]161-alan turned [their]3810-their backs to the sunset , and drove along [the bleak high - road]3811-the bleak high - road toward [Sedgehill]1-sedgehill , where the reflection of the blast - furnaces — [that weird aurora borealis of [the Black Country]18-the black country]3812-that weird aurora borealis of the black country — was already beginning to pulsate against the darkening sky . And here again [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth realized that for [her]102-elisabeth the old things had passed away , and all things had become new . [She]102-elisabeth felt that [her]102-elisabeth childish dream was true , and that the crimson light was indeed a pillar of fire showing that [the Lord]2978-the lord was in the midst of [[His]2978-the lord people]345-his people ; but [she]102-elisabeth went further now than [she]102-elisabeth had gone in [her]102-elisabeth day - dreams , and knew that all the lights and shadows of life are but pillars of cloud and of fire , forthtelling the same truth to [all who have seeing eyes and understanding hearts]3815-all who have seeing eyes and understanding hearts . Suddenly the silence was broken by [Alan]161-alan . "[0-i] [I]0-i have been thinking about [you]1522-you during the service , and building all sorts of castles in the air which [you]1522-you and [I]0-i are going to inhabit together . But [we]1523-us must not let the old faiths hamper [us]1523-us , [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth ; if [we]1523-us do , [our]1523-us powers will be impaired by prejudices , and [our]1523-us usefulness will be limited by traditions . " "[0-i] [I]0-i have something to say to [you]0-i , " [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth replied , and [her]102-elisabeth eyes shone like stars in the twilight ; "[0-i] [you]0-i wo n't understand it , but [I]0-i must say it all the same . In [church]1322-church to - night , for the first time in [my]0-i life , [I]0-i heard [God]105-god speaking to [me]0-i ; and [I]0-i found out that religion is no string of dogmas , but just [His]105-god calling [us]1523-us by name . " [Tremaine]161-alan looked at [her]102-elisabeth pityingly . "[105-god] [You]102-elisabeth are overtired and overwrought by the heat , and the excitement of the sermon has been too much for [you]102-elisabeth . But [you]102-elisabeth will be all right again to - morrow , never fear . " "[0-i] [I]0-i knew [you]102-elisabeth would n't understand , and [I]0-i ca n't explain it to [you]102-elisabeth ; but it has suddenly all become quite clear to [me]0-i — all the things that [I]0-i have puzzled over since [I]0-i was [a little child]3789-a little child ; and [I]0-i know now that religion is not [our]1523-us attitude toward [God]105-god , but [His]105-god attitude toward [us]1523-us . " "[102-elisabeth] Why , [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth , [you]102-elisabeth are saying over again all the old formulas that [you]102-elisabeth and [I]0-i have refuted so often . " "[102-elisabeth] [I]0-i know [I]0-i am ; but [I]0-i never really believed in them till now . [I]0-i ca n't argue with [you]102-elisabeth , [Alan]161-alan — [I'm]0-i not clever enough — and besides , the best things in [the world]301-the world can never be proved by argument . But [I]0-i want [you]102-elisabeth to understand that the Power which [you]102-elisabeth call Christianity is stronger than human wills , or human strength , or even human love ; and now that it has once laid hold upon [me]0-i , it will never let [me]0-i go . " [Alan]161-alan 's face grew pale with anger . "[0-i] [I]0-i see ; [your]102-elisabeth old associations have been too strong for [you]102-elisabeth . " "[1527-his] It is n't [my]0-i old associations , or [my]0-i early training , or anything belonging to [me]0-i . It is n't [me]0-i at all . It is just [His]1527-his Voice calling [me]0-i . Ca n't [you]102-elisabeth understand , [Alan]161-alan ? [It]1528-it is not [I]0-i who am doing it all — it is [He]1527-his . " There was a short silence , and then [Tremaine]161-alan said — "[1527-his] But [I]0-i thought [you]102-elisabeth loved [me]0-i ? " "[0-i] [I]0-i thought so too , but perhaps [I]0-i was wrong ; [I]0-i do n't know . All [I]0-i know is that this new feeling is stronger than any feeling [I]0-i ever had before ; and that [I]0-i can not give up [my]0-i religion , whatever it may cost [me]0-i . " "[0-i] [I]0-i will not marry [a woman who believes in the old faith]1529-a woman who believes in the old faith . " "[0-i] And [I]0-i will not marry [a man who does not]1530-a man who does not . " [Alan]161-alan 's voice grew hard . "[0-i] [I]0-i do n't believe [you]102-elisabeth ever loved [me]0-i , " [he]0-i complained . "[0-i] [I]0-i do n't know . [I]0-i thought [I]0-i did ; but perhaps [I]0-i knew as little about love as [you]102-elisabeth know about religion . Perhaps [I]0-i shall find a real love some day which will be as different from [my]0-i friendship for [you]102-elisabeth as this new knowledge is different from the religion that [Cousin Maria]100-cousin maria taught [me]0-i . [I]0-i 'm very sorry , but [I]0-i can never marry [you]102-elisabeth now . " "[0-i] [You]102-elisabeth would have given up [your]102-elisabeth religion fast enough if [you]102-elisabeth had really cared for [me]0-i , " sneered [Tremaine]161-alan . [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth pondered for a moment , with the old contraction of [her]102-elisabeth eyebrows . "[102-elisabeth] [I]0-i do n't think so , because , as [I]0-i told [you]102-elisabeth before , it is n't really [my]0-i doing at all . It is n't that [I]0-i wo n't give up [my]0-i religion — it is [my]0-i religion that wo n't give up [me]0-i . Supposing that [a blind man]1531-a blind man wanted to marry [me]0-i on condition that [I]0-i would believe , as [he]1531-a blind man did , that [the world]301-the world is dark : [I]0-i could n't believe it , however much [I]0-i loved [him]1531-a blind man . [You]102-elisabeth ca n't not know what [you]102-elisabeth have once known , and [you]102-elisabeth ca n't not have seen what [you]102-elisabeth have seen , however much [you]102-elisabeth may wish to do so , or however much [other people]2980-other people may wish it . " "[102-elisabeth] [You]102-elisabeth are [a regular woman]1534-a regular woman , in spite of all [your]102-elisabeth cleverness , and [I]0-i was a fool to imagine that [you]102-elisabeth would prove more intelligent in the long run than the rest of [your]102-elisabeth conventional and superstitious sex . " "[0-i] Please forgive [me]0-i for hurting [you]102-elisabeth , " besought [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth . "[0-i] It is not only that [you]102-elisabeth have hurt [me]0-i , but [I]0-i am so disappointed in [you]102-elisabeth ; [you]102-elisabeth seemed so different from [other women]1535-other women , and now [I]0-i find the difference was merely a surface one . " "[0-i] [I]0-i am so sorry , " [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth still pleaded . [Tremaine]161-alan laughed bitterly . "[0-i] [You]102-elisabeth are disappointed in [yourself]102-elisabeth , [I]0-i should imagine . [You]102-elisabeth posed as being so broad and modern and enlightened , and yet [you]102-elisabeth have found worn - out dogmas and hackneyed creeds too strong for [you]102-elisabeth . " [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth smiled to [herself]102-elisabeth . "[102-elisabeth] No ; but [I]0-i have found [the Christ]1536-the christ , " [she]102-elisabeth answered softly . After having been weighed in [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's balance and found wanting , [Alan Tremaine]161-alan went abroad for a season , and [Sedgehill]201-sedgehill knew [him]161-alan no more until the following spring . During that time [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth possessed [her]102-elisabeth soul and grew into [a true woman]3816-a true woman — [a woman with no smallness or meanness in [her]102-elisabeth nature]3817-a woman with no smallness or meanness in her nature , but with certain feminine weaknesses which made [her]102-elisabeth all the more lovable to [those people who understood [her]102-elisabeth , and all the more incongruous and irritating to [those who did not]3819-those who did not]3818-those people who understood her , and all the more incongruous and irritating to those who did not . [Christopher]121-christopher , too , rested in an oasis of happiness just then . [He]121-christopher was an adept in the study of [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth , and [he]121-christopher knew perfectly well what had passed between [her]102-elisabeth and [Alan]161-alan , although [she]102-elisabeth flattered [herself]102-elisabeth that [she]102-elisabeth had kept [him]121-christopher completely in the dark on the subject . But [Christopher]121-christopher was always ready to dance to [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's piping , except when it happened to be on red - hot iron ; even then [he]121-christopher tried to obey [her]102-elisabeth bidding , and it was hardly [his]121-christopher fault if [he]121-christopher failed . [Christopher Thornley]121-christopher was one of [those people whose temperament and surroundings are at war with each other]3820-those people whose temperament and surroundings are at war with each other . [Such people]3821-such people are not few in [this world]3177-this world , though [they]3821-such people [themselves]3821-such people are frequently quite unaware of the fact ; nevertheless , there is always an element of tragedy in [their]3821-such people lot . By nature [he]121-christopher was romantic and passionate and chivalrous , endowed with an enthusiastic admiration for beauty and an ardent longing for all forms of joyousness ; and [he]121-christopher had been trained in a school of thought where all merely human joys and attractions are counted as unimportant if not sinful , and where wisdom and righteousness are held to be the two only ends of life . Perhaps in a former existence — or in the person of [some remote ancestor]3823-some remote ancestor — [Christopher]121-christopher had been [a knightly and devoted cavalier , ready to lay down [his]121-christopher life for Church and [king]3825-king]3824-a knightly and devoted cavalier , ready to lay down his life for church and king , and in the meantime spending [his]121-christopher days in writing odes to [[his]121-christopher mistress]3826-his mistress 's eyebrow ; and now [he]121-christopher had been born into a strict Puritan atmosphere , where principles rather than [persons]1112-persons commanded [men]445-men 's loyalty , and where romance was held to be a temptation of the flesh if not a snare of the devil . [He]121-christopher possessed a great capacity for happiness , and for enjoyment of all kinds ; consequently the dull routine of business was more distasteful to [him]121-christopher than to [a man of coarser fibre and less fastidious tastes]3829-a man of coarser fibre and less fastidious tastes . [Christopher]121-christopher was one of [the people who are specially fitted by nature to appreciate to the full all the refinements and accessories of wealth and culture]3830-the people who are specially fitted by nature to appreciate to the full all the refinements and accessories of wealth and culture ; therefore [his]121-christopher position at [the Osierfield]102-elisabeth was more trying to [him]121-christopher than it would have been to [nine men out of every ten]3831-nine men out of every ten . When spring came back again , [Alan Tremaine]161-alan came with [it]3832-it to [the Moat House]34-the moat house ; and at the same time [Felicia Herbert]154-felicia arrived on a visit to [the Willows]8-the willows . [Alan]161-alan had enough of [the woman]3411-the woman in [his]161-alan nature to decide that — [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth not being meant for [him]161-alan — [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth was not worth the having ; but , although [she]102-elisabeth had not filled [his]161-alan life so completely as to make it unendurable without [her]102-elisabeth , [she]102-elisabeth had occupied [his]161-alan thoughts sufficiently to make feminine society and sympathy thenceforth a necessity of [his]161-alan being . So it came to pass that when [he]161-alan met [Felicia]154-felicia and saw that [she]154-felicia was fair , [he]161-alan straightway elected [her]154-felicia to the office which [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth had created and then declined to fill ; and because human nature — and especially young human nature — is stronger even than early training or old associations , [Felicia]154-felicia fell in love with [him]161-alan in return , in spite of ( possibly because of ) [her]154-felicia former violent prejudice against [him]161-alan . To expect [a person]3040-a person to be [a monster]3835-a monster and then to find [he]3040-a person is [a man]310-a man , has very much the same effect as expecting [a person]3040-a person to be [a man]310-a man and finding [him]3040-a person [a fairy prince]3358-a fairy prince ; [we]3840-we accord [him]161-alan [our]3840-we admiration for being so much better than [our]3840-we fancy painted [him]161-alan , and [we]3840-we crave [his]161-alan forgiveness for having allowed it to paint [him]161-alan in such false colours . Then [we]3840-we long to make some reparation to [him]161-alan for [our]3840-we unjust judgment ; and — if [we]3840-we happen to be [women]446-women — this reparation frequently takes the form of ordering [his]161-alan dinner for the rest of [his]161-alan dining days , and of giving [him]161-alan the right to pay [[our]3840-we dressmakers]3842-our dressmakers ' bills until such time as [we]3840-we cease to be troubled with [them]3842-our dressmakers . Consequently that particular year the spring seemed to have come specially for the benefit of [Alan]161-alan and [Felicia]154-felicia . For [them]3843-them [the woods]3637-the woods were carpeted with daffodils , and [the meadows]3845-the meadows were decked in living green ; for [them]3843-them [the mountains]3846-the mountains and hills broke forth into singing , and the trees of [the field]3847-the field clapped [their]3843-them hands . [Most men]3848-most men and [women]446-women have known one spring - time such as this in [their]3848-most men lives , whereof all the other spring - times were but images and types ; and , maybe , even that one spring - time was but an image and a type of the great New Year 's Day which shall be Time 's to - morrow . But while [these two]3850-these two were wandering together in fairyland , [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth felt distinctly left out in the cold . [Felicia]154-felicia was [[her]102-elisabeth friend]692-her friend — [Alan]161-alan had been [[her]102-elisabeth lover]779-her lover ; and now [they]3843-them had drifted off into [a strange new country]3853-a strange new country , and had shut the door in [her]102-elisabeth face . There was no place for [her]102-elisabeth in [this fairyland of [theirs]3843-them]3854-this fairyland of theirs ; [they]3843-them did not want [her]102-elisabeth any longer ; and although [she]102-elisabeth was too large - hearted for petty jealousies , [she]102-elisabeth could not stifle that pang of soreness with which most of [us]3855-us are acquainted , when [[our]3855-us fellow - travellers]3856-our fellow - travellers slip off by pairs into [Eden]55-eden , and leave [us]3855-us to walk alone upon [the dusty highway]3857-the dusty highway . [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth could no more help [flirting]3858-flirting than [some people]1461-some people can help stammering . It was a pity , no doubt ; but it would have been absurd to blame [her]102-elisabeth for it . [She]102-elisabeth had not the slightest intention of breaking [anybody]376-anybody 's heart ; [she]102-elisabeth did not take [herself]102-elisabeth seriously enough to imagine such a contingency possible ; but the desire to charm was so strong within [her]102-elisabeth that [she]102-elisabeth could not resist it ; and [she]102-elisabeth took as much trouble to win the admiration of [women]446-women as of [men]445-men . Therefore , [Alan]161-alan and [Felicia]154-felicia having done with [her]102-elisabeth , for the time being , [she]102-elisabeth turned [her]102-elisabeth attention to [Christopher]121-christopher ; and although [he]121-christopher fully comprehended the cause , [he]121-christopher none the less enjoyed the effect . [He]121-christopher cherished no illusions concerning [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth , for the which [he]121-christopher was perhaps to be pitied ; since from love which is founded upon an illusion , there may be an awakening ; but for love which sees its objects as they are , and still goes on loving [them]3863-them , there is no conceivable cure either in [this world]3177-this world or [the world]301-the world to come . "[1536-the christ] [I]0-i 'm not jealous by nature , and [I]0-i think it is horrid to be dog - in - the - mangerish , " [she]102-elisabeth remarked to [him]121-christopher one sunny afternoon , when [Alan]161-alan and [Felicia]154-felicia had gone off together to [Badgering Woods]47-badgering woods and left [her]102-elisabeth all alone , until [Christopher]121-christopher happened to drop in about tea - time . [He]121-christopher had a way of appearing upon the scene when [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth needed [him]121-christopher , and of effacing [himself]121-christopher when [she]102-elisabeth did not . [He]121-christopher also had a way of smoothing down all the little faults and trials and difficulties which beset [her]102-elisabeth path , and of making for [her]102-elisabeth the rough places plain . When [people]2982-people put religious things in a horrid light , it makes [you]1606-you feel as if [they]2982-people were telling unkind and untrue tales about [[your]1606-you dearest friends]1617-your dearest friends . " "[2982-people] What does [the good woman]1618-the good woman say that makes ' [[my]0-i lady]1619-my lady Tongue ' so furious ? " "[1618-the good woman] Well , [she]1618-the good woman is always saying [one]543-one must give up this and give up that , and deny [one]543-one 's self here and deny [one]543-one 's self there , for the sake of religion ; and [I]0-i do n't believe that religion means that sort of giving up at all . Of course , [God]105-god is pleased when [we]1623-us do what [He]105-god wishes [us]1623-us to do , because [He]105-god knows it is the best for [us]1623-us ; but [I]0-i do n't believe [He]105-god wants [us]1623-us to do things when [we]1623-us hate doing them , just to please [Him]105-god . " "[105-god] Perhaps not . Still , if [one]543-one does a thing one does n't like doing , to please [another person]3077-another person , [one]543-one often ends by enjoying the doing of the thing . And even if [one]543-one never enjoys it , the thing has still to be done . " "[543-one] Well , if [you]1628-you were awfully fond of [anybody]376-anybody , should [you]1628-you want [them]376-anybody to spend [their]376-anybody time with [you]1628-you , and do what [you]1628-you were doing , when [you]1628-you knew all the time that [they]376-anybody did n't like being with [you]1628-you , but were dying to be with [some one else]1630-some one else ? " "[1628-you] Certainly not . " "[1628-you] Of course [you]1628-you would n't , " [the girl]629-the girl went on ; "[1628-you] [you]1628-you would wish [the person [you]1628-you loved]1632-the person you loved to be happy with [you]1628-you , and to want to be with [you]1628-you as much as [you]1628-you wanted to be with [them]1632-the person you loved ; and if [they]1632-the person you loved did n't really care to be with [you]1628-you , [you]1628-you would n't thank [them]1632-the person you loved for unselfishness in the matter . So if [an ordinary man]1633-an ordinary man like [you]1628-you does n't care for mere unselfishness from [the people [you]1628-you are really fond of]1634-the people you are really fond of , do [you]1628-you think that what is n't good enough for [you]1628-you is good enough for [God]105-god ? " "[1628-you] No . But [I]0-i still might want [the people [I]0-i was fond of]1635-the people i was fond of to be unselfish , not for [my]0-i own sake but for [theirs]1635-the people i was fond of . The more [one]543-one loves [a person]3040-a person , the more [one]543-one wishes [that person]3078-that person to be worthy of love ; and though [we]1640-we do n't love [people]2982-people because [they]2982-people are perfect , [we]1640-we want [them]2982-people to be perfect because [we]1640-we love [them]2982-people , do n't [you]1628-you see ? " "[1628-you] [You]1628-you are n't a very good instance , [Chris]125-chris , because , [you]1628-you see , [you]1628-you are rather [a reserved , cold - hearted person]1642-a reserved , cold - hearted person , and not at all affectionate ; but still [you]1628-you are fond of [people]2982-people in [your]1628-you own way . " "[1628-you] Yes ; [I]0-i am fond of [one or two people]1644-one or two people — but in [my]0-i own way , as [you]1628-you say , " [Christopher]121-christopher replied quietly . "[0-i] And even [you]1628-you understand that forced and artificial devotion is n't worth having . " "[1628-you] Yes ; even [I]0-i understand as much as that . " "[1628-you] So [you]1628-you will see that unselfishness and renunciation and things of that sort are only second - best things after all , and that there is nothing of the kind between people who really love [each other]3364-each other , because [their]3364-each other two wills are merged in one , and [each]1646-each finds [his]1646-each own happiness in the happiness of the other . And [I]0-i do n't believe that [God]105-god wants [us]1647-us to give up [our]1647-us wills to [His]105-god in a ' [Thy]1648-thy way not mine ' kind of way ; [I]0-i believe [He]105-god wants the same mind to be in [us]1647-us that was in [Christ Jesus]176-christ , so that [He]105-god and [we]1647-us shall be wishing for the same things . " "[102-elisabeth] Wise [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth , [I]0-i believe that [you]0-i are right . " "[102-elisabeth] And [you]1628-you 'll see how right [I]0-i am , when [you]1628-you really care very much for [somebody]901-somebody [yourself]1628-you . " [Christopher]121-christopher smiled sadly . "[543-one] Does n't it ? [I]0-i should have thought that it taught [one]543-one a good deal . " [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth stroked [his]121-christopher sleeve affectionately . "[0-i] [I]0-i am so sorry . " [Christopher]121-christopher winced ; it was when [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth was affectionate that [he]121-christopher found [his]121-christopher enforced silence most hard to bear . How [he]121-christopher could have made [her]102-elisabeth love [him]121-christopher if [he]121-christopher had tried , [he]121-christopher thought ; and how could [he]121-christopher find the heart to make [her]102-elisabeth love [him]121-christopher as long as [he]121-christopher and [she]102-elisabeth were alike dependent upon [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth 's bounty , and [they]3875-they had neither anything of [their]3875-they own ? "[0-i] By [Jove]209-jove ! " [he]0-i said to [himself]0-i , looking into the gray eyes that were so full of sympathy just then , "[209-jove] what [an ass]810-an ass [the man]3356-the man was to talk to [such a woman]1663-such a woman as this about art and philosophy and high - falutin ' of that sort ! " But what [he]0-i said to [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth was , "[1663-such a woman] There is n't much the matter with [my]0-i head — nothing for [you]1664-you to worry about , [I]0-i can assure [you]1664-you . " "[161-alan] [I]0-i used to believe in [Alan]161-alan , " [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth confessed ; "[161-alan] but [I]0-i do n't so much now . " "[0-i] [He]161-alan never did make love to [me]0-i , so [I]0-i always had an inkling of the truth that [his]161-alan sentiments were a little over [his]161-alan own head . " "[0-i] And yet [you]0-i were right . It seems to [me]0-i that [you]0-i are always right , [Chris]125-chris . " "[0-i] No — not always ; but more often than [you]0-i are , perhaps , " replied [Christopher]121-christopher , in rather a husky voice , but with a very kindly smile . "[0-i] [I]0-i am older , [you]0-i see , for one thing ; and [I]0-i have had a harder time of it for another , and some of the idealism has been knocked out of [me]0-i . " "[0-i] But the nice thing about [you]0-i is that though [you]0-i always know when [I]0-i am wrong or foolish , [you]0-i never seem to despise [me]0-i for it . " Despise [her]3883-her ? [Christopher]121-christopher laughed at the word ; and yet [women]446-women were supposed to have such keen perceptions . "[0-i] [I]0-i do n't care whether [you]0-i are wise or foolish , " [he]0-i said , "[0-i] as long as [you]0-i are [you]0-i . That is all that matters to [me]0-i . " "[0-i] And [you]0-i really think [I]0-i am nice ? " "[0-i] [I]0-i do n't see how [you]0-i could well be nicer . " "[0-i] Oh ! [you]0-i do n't know what [I]0-i could do if [I]0-i tried . [You]0-i underrate [my]0-i powers ; [you]0-i always did . [You]0-i seem to take things as they are . " "[0-i] Well , [I]0-i have to , [you]0-i see ; and what must be must . " "[0-i] Simple natures like [yours]0-i are very soothing to complex natures like [mine]0-i . When [I]0-i 've lived [my]0-i life and worn [myself]0-i out with trying to get the utmost [I]0-i can out of everything , [I]0-i shall spend the first three thousand years of eternity sitting quite still upon a fixed star without speaking , with [my]0-i legs dangling into space , and looking at [you]0-i . " "[0-i] Say two thousand years ; [you]0-i 'd never be able to sit still without speaking for more than two thousand years at the outside .
