" [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth laughed again , and looked through the trees to [the fields beyond]3885-the fields beyond . [Friends]3544-friends were much more comfortable than [lovers]456-lovers , [she]102-elisabeth said to [herself]102-elisabeth ; [Alan]161-alan in [his]161-alan palmiest days had never been half so soothing to [her]102-elisabeth as [Christopher]121-christopher was now . [She]102-elisabeth wondered why [poets]3888-poets and [people of that kind]3015-people of that kind made so much of love and so little of friendship , since the latter was obviously the more lasting and satisfactory of [the two]340-the two . Somehow the mere presence of [Christopher]121-christopher had quite cured the sore feeling that [Alan]161-alan and [Felicia]154-felicia had left behind [them]340-the two when [they]340-the two started for [their]340-the two walk without even asking [her]102-elisabeth to go with [them]340-the two ; and [she]102-elisabeth was once more sure of the fact that [she]102-elisabeth was necessary to [somebody]901-somebody — a certainty without which [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth could not live . So [her]102-elisabeth imagination took heart of grace again , and began drawing plans for [extensive castles in [Spain]56-spain]3892-extensive castles in spain , and arranging social campaigns wherein [she]102-elisabeth [herself]102-elisabeth should be crowned with triumph . [She]102-elisabeth decided that half the delight of winning life 's prizes and meeting [its fairy princes]3893-its fairy princes would be the telling [Christopher]121-christopher all about [them]340-the two afterward ; for [her]102-elisabeth belief in [his]121-christopher exhaustless sympathy was boundless . "[1667-the angels] A penny for [your]1669-your thoughts , " [he]121-christopher said , after [she]102-elisabeth had been silent for some moments . Look at them now ! " "[123-mrs. bateson] It does look rather like that , [I]0-i admit . " And [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth went to meet [the lovers]3894-the lovers with no longer any little cobwebs of jealousy hiding in the dark corners of [her]102-elisabeth heart , [Christopher]121-christopher 's hand having swept [them]3894-the lovers all away ; [he]121-christopher had a wonderful power of exterminating the little foxes which would otherwise have spoiled [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's vines ; and again [she]102-elisabeth said to [herself]102-elisabeth how much better a thing was friendship than love , since [Alan]161-alan had always expected [her]102-elisabeth to be interested in [his]121-christopher concerns , while [Christopher]121-christopher , on the contrary , was always interested in [hers]102-elisabeth . It was not long after this that [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth was told by [Felicia]154-felicia of [the latter]524-the latter 's engagement to [Alan Tremaine]161-alan ; and [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth was amazed at the rapidity with which [Felicia]154-felicia had assimilated [[her]154-felicia lover]779-her lover 's views on all subjects . [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth had expected that [[her]102-elisabeth friend]692-her friend would finally sacrifice [her]692-her friend opinions on the altar of [her]692-her friend feelings ; [she]102-elisabeth was already old enough to be prepared for that ; but [she]102-elisabeth had anticipated a fierce warfare in the soul of [Felicia]154-felicia between the directly opposing principles of [[this young lady]3898-this young lady 's mother]3899-this young lady 's mother and [lover]3900-lover . To [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's surprise , this civil war never took place . [Felicia]154-felicia accepted [Alan]161-alan 's doubts as unquestioningly as [she]154-felicia had formerly accepted [Mrs. Herbert]197-mrs. herbert 's beliefs ; and as [she]154-felicia loved [the former]626-the former more devotedly than [she]154-felicia had ever loved [the latter]524-the latter , [she]154-felicia was more devout and fervid in [her]154-felicia agnosticism than [she]154-felicia had ever been in [her]154-felicia faith . [She]154-felicia had believed , because [[her]154-felicia mother]479-her mother ordered [her]154-felicia to believe ; [she]154-felicia doubted , because [Alan]161-alan desired [her]154-felicia to doubt ; [her]154-felicia belief and unbelief being equally the outcome of [her]154-felicia affections rather than of [her]154-felicia convictions . [Mrs. Herbert]197-mrs. herbert likewise looked leniently upon [Alan]161-alan 's want of orthodoxy , and at this [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth was not surprised . Possibly there are [not many of [us]3905-us who do not — in the private and confidential depths of [our]3905-us evil hearts]3904-not many of us who do not — in the private and confidential depths of our evil hearts — regard [earth]614-earth in the hand as worth more than heaven in the bush , so to speak ; at any rate , [[Felicia]154-felicia 's mother]3907-felicia 's mother was not one of the bright exceptions ; and — from a purely commercial point of view — a saving faith does not go so far as a spending income , and it is no use pretending that it does . So [Mrs. Herbert]197-mrs. herbert smiled upon [[her]197-mrs. herbert daughter]3164-her daughter 's engagement ; but compromised with that accommodating conscience of [hers]197-mrs. herbert by always speaking of [[her]197-mrs. herbert prospective son - in - law]3909-her prospective son - in - law as "[161-alan] poor [Alan]161-alan , " just as if [she]197-mrs. herbert really believed , as [she]197-mrs. herbert professed [she]197-mrs. herbert did , that the death of the body and the death of the soul are conditions equally to be deplored . "[161-alan] [You]1674-you see , [[my]0-i dear]3103-my dear , " [she]197-mrs. herbert said to [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth , who came to stay at [Wood Glen]52-wood glen for [Felicia]154-felicia 's marriage , which took place in the early summer , "[161-alan] it is such a comfort to [Mr. Herbert]198-mr. herbert and [myself]0-i to know that [[our]1676-we dear child]1677-our dear child is so comfortably provided for . " [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth , remembering that [she]102-elisabeth had once been fascinated by [the master of the Moat House]3716-the master of the moat house , was merciful . " "[161-alan] [He]161-alan has , [[my]0-i love]3112-my love . "[161-alan] And [he]161-alan is really very philanthropic , " [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth continued ; "[161-alan] [he]161-alan has done no end of things for [the work - people]1681-the work - people at [the Osierfield]102-elisabeth . It is a pity that [his]161-alan faith is second - rate , considering that [his]161-alan works are first - class . " "[1683-the elect] Ah ! It is often [those who seem to be the farthest from [the kingdom]1685-the kingdom that are in truth the nearest to it]1684-those who seem to be the farthest from the kingdom that are in truth the nearest to it . " [Mrs. Herbert]197-mrs. herbert had dismissed [a kitchen - maid]3912-a kitchen - maid , only the week before , for declining to attend [her]197-mrs. herbert Bible - class , and walking out with [a young man]3913-a young man instead . "[0-i] Still , [I]0-i am sorry that [Alan]161-alan has all those queer views , " [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth persisted ; "[0-i] [he]161-alan really would be a splendid sort of person if [he]161-alan were only [a Christian]3073-a christian ; and it seems such a pity that — with all [his]161-alan learning — [he]161-alan has n't learned the one thing that really matters . " "[0-i] [[My]0-i love]3112-my love , [I]0-i am ashamed to find [you]3112-my love so censorious ; it is a sad fault , especially in [the young]371-the young . [I]0-i would advise [you]3112-my love to turn to the thirteenth of First Corinthians , and see for [yourself]3112-my love how excellent a gift is charity — the greatest of all , according to [[our]1689-our dear]1690-our dear [Saint Paul]129-saint paul . " [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth sighed . [She]102-elisabeth had long ago become acquainted with [Mrs. Herbert]197-mrs. herbert 's custom of keeping religion as a thing apart , and of treating it from an "[129-saint paul] in - another - department - if - [you]1691-you - please " point of view ; and [she]102-elisabeth felt that [Tremaine]161-alan 's open agnosticism was almost better — and certainly more sincere — than this . But [Mrs. Herbert]197-mrs. herbert was utterly unconscious of any secret fault on [her]197-mrs. herbert own part , and continued to purr contentedly to [herself]197-mrs. herbert . "[154-felicia] [Felicia]154-felicia , [dear child]1692-dear child ! will certainly take an excellent position . [She]154-felicia will be in [county society]1693-county society , the very thing which [I]0-i have always desired for [her]154-felicia ; and [she]154-felicia will enter it , not on sufferance , but as one of [themselves]1694-themselves . [I]0-i can not tell [you]1691-you what a pleasure it is to [Mr. Herbert]198-mr. herbert and [myself]0-i to think of [[our]1695-our beloved daughter]1696-our beloved daughter as [a regular county lady]1697-a regular county lady ; it quite makes up for all the little self - denials that [we]1695-our suffered in order to give [her]154-felicia a good education and to render [her]154-felicia fit to take [her]154-felicia place in [society]1698-society . [I]0-i should n't be surprised if [she]154-felicia were even presented at [Court]1699-court . " And [the mother]3914-the mother 's cup of happiness ran over at the mere thought of such honour and glory . [Felicia]154-felicia , too , was radiantly happy . In the first place , [she]154-felicia was very much in love ; in the second , [her]154-felicia world was praising [her]154-felicia for doing well to [herself]154-felicia . "[0-i] [I]0-i can not think how [a clever man like [Alan]161-alan]1700-a clever man like alan ever fell in love with [such a stupid creature as [me]0-i]1701-such a stupid creature as me , " [she]154-felicia said to [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth , not long before the wedding . "[161-alan] Ca n't [you]0-i ? Well , [I]0-i can . [I]0-i do n't wonder at [any man]1066-any man 's falling in love with [you]0-i , [darling]1703-darling , [you]0-i are so dear and pretty and altogether adorable . " "[0-i] But then [Alan]161-alan is so different from [other men]3643-other men . " [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth was too well - mannered to smile at this ; but [she]102-elisabeth made a note of it to report to [Christopher]121-christopher afterward . [She]102-elisabeth knew that [he]121-christopher would understand how funny it was . "[0-i] [I]0-i am simply amazed at [my]0-i own happiness , " [Felicia]154-felicia continued ; "[0-i] and [I]0-i am so dreadfully afraid that [he]161-alan will be disappointed in [me]0-i when [he]161-alan gets to know [me]0-i better , and will find out that [I]0-i am not half good enough for [him]161-alan — which [I]0-i am not . " "[154-felicia] What nonsense ! Why , there is n't [a man]310-a man living that would really be good enough for [you]0-i , [Felicia]154-felicia . " "[102-elisabeth] [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth ! When [I]0-i hear [Alan]161-alan talking , [I]0-i wonder how [he]161-alan can put up with silly little [me]0-i at all . [You]102-elisabeth see , [I]0-i never was clever — not even as clever as [you]102-elisabeth are ; and [you]102-elisabeth , of course , are n't a millionth part as clever as [Alan]161-alan . And then [he]161-alan has such grand thoughts , too ; [he]161-alan is always wanting to help [other people]2980-other people , and to make [them]2980-other people happier . [I]0-i feel that as long as [I]0-i live [I]0-i never can be half grateful enough to [him]161-alan for the honour [he]161-alan has done [me]0-i in wanting [me]0-i for [[his]161-alan wife]3146-his wife . " [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth shrugged [her]102-elisabeth shoulders ; the honours that have been within [our]3915-our reach are never quite so wonderful as those that have not . So [Alan]161-alan and [Felicia]154-felicia were married with much rejoicing and ringing of bells ; and [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth found it very pleasant to have [[her]102-elisabeth old schoolfellow]3916-her old schoolfellow settled at [the Moat House]762-the moat house . In fact so thoroughly did [she]102-elisabeth throw [herself]102-elisabeth into the interests of [[Felicia]154-felicia 's new home]3918-felicia 's new home , that [she]102-elisabeth ceased to feel [her]102-elisabeth need of [Christopher]121-christopher , and consequently neglected [him]121-christopher somewhat . It was only when [others]3096-others failed [her]102-elisabeth that [he]121-christopher was at a premium ; when [she]102-elisabeth found [she]102-elisabeth could do without [him]121-christopher , [she]102-elisabeth did . As for [him]121-christopher , [he]121-christopher loyally refrained from blaming [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth , even in [his]121-christopher heart , and cursed [Fate]122-fate instead ; which really was unfair of [him]121-christopher , considering that in this matter [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth , and not [Fate]122-fate , was entirely to blame . But [Christopher]121-christopher was always ready to find excuses for [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth , whatever [she]102-elisabeth might do ; and this , it must be confessed , required no mean order of ingenuity just then . [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth was as yet young enough to think lightly of the gifts that were bestowed upon [her]102-elisabeth freely and with no trouble on [her]102-elisabeth part , such as bread and air and sunshine and the like ; it was reserved for [her]102-elisabeth to learn later that the things [one]543-one takes for granted are the best thing life has to offer . It must also be remembered , for [her]102-elisabeth justification , that [Christopher]121-christopher had never told [her]102-elisabeth that [he]121-christopher loved [her]102-elisabeth "[0-i] more than reason " ; and it is difficult for [women]446-women to believe that [any man]1066-any man loves [them]446-women until [he]121-christopher has told [them]446-women so , just as it is difficult for [them]446-women to believe that [a train]3923-a train is going direct to [the place appointed to [it]3923-a train in [Bradshaw]58-bradshaw]3924-the place appointed to it in bradshaw , until [they]446-women have been verbally assured upon the point by [two guards]3925-two guards , [six porters]3926-six porters , and [a newspaper boy]3927-a newspaper boy . Nevertheless , [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's ignorance — though perhaps excusable , considering [her]102-elisabeth sex — was anything but bliss to poor [Christopher]121-christopher , and [her]102-elisabeth good - natured carelessness hurt [him]121-christopher none the less for [her]102-elisabeth not knowing that it hurt [him]121-christopher . When [Felicia]154-felicia had been married about three months [[her]154-felicia mother]479-her mother came to stay with [her]154-felicia at [the Moat House]762-the moat house ; and [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth smiled to [herself]102-elisabeth — and to [Christopher]121-christopher — as [she]102-elisabeth pictured [the worthy woman]3930-the worthy woman 's delight in [[her]102-elisabeth daughter]3164-her daughter 's new surroundings . "[1708-she] [She]1708-she 'll extol all [Felicia]154-felicia 's belongings as exhaustively as if [she]1708-she were [the Benedicite]1709-the benedicite , " [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth said , "[1708-she] and [she]1708-she 'll enumerate them as carefully as if [she]1708-she were sending [them]1710-them to the wash . [You]1711-you 'll find there wo n't be a single one omitted — not even [the second footman]1712-the second footman or the soft - water cistern . [Mrs. Herbert]197-mrs. herbert is one who battens on details , and [she]197-mrs. herbert never spares [[her]197-mrs. herbert hearers]1713-her hearers a single item . " "[197-mrs. herbert] It is distinctly naughty of [you]1711-you , " [Christopher]121-christopher replied , with the smile that was always ready for [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's feeblest sallies , "[1711-you] to draw the good soul out for the express purpose of laughing at [her]154-felicia . [I]0-i am ashamed of [you]1711-you , [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth . " "[1711-you] Draw [her]154-felicia out , [[my]0-i dear boy]1714-my dear boy ! [You]1711-you do n't know what [you]1711-you are talking about . The most elementary knowledge of [Mrs. Herbert]197-mrs. herbert would teach [you]1711-you that [she]154-felicia requires nothing in the shape of drawing out . [You]1711-you have but to mention the word ' dinner , ' and the secret sins of [[her]154-felicia cook]1715-her cook are retailed to [you]1711-you in chronological order ; [you]1711-you have but to whisper the word ' clothes , ' and the iniquities of [her]154-felicia dressmaker 's bill are laid bare before [your]1711-you eyes . Should the conversation glance upon [Mr. Herbert]198-mr. herbert , [his]198-mr. herbert complete biography becomes [your]1711-you own possession ; and should the passing thought of childhood appear above [her]154-felicia mental horizon , [she]154-felicia tells [you]1711-you all about [[her]154-felicia own children]1716-her own children as graphically as if [she]154-felicia were editing a new edition of The Pillars of [the House]596-the house . And yet [you]1711-you talk of drawing [her]154-felicia out ! [I]0-i am afraid [you]1711-you have no perceptions , [Christopher]121-christopher . " "[121-christopher] Possibly not ; [everybody]3055-everybody does n't have perceptions . [I]0-i am frequently struck with [clever people]1719-clever people 's lack of [them]1720-them . " "[0-i] Well , [I]0-i 'm off , " replied [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth , whipping up [her]102-elisabeth pony , "[0-i] to hear [Mrs. Herbert]197-mrs. herbert 's outpourings on [Felicia]154-felicia 's happiness ; when [I]0-i come back [I]0-i expect [I]0-i shall be able to write another poem on ' How does the water come down at [Lodore'—with]59-lodore'—with a difference . " And [Christopher]121-christopher — who had met [her]102-elisabeth in [the High Street]719-the high street — smiled after [the retreating figure]3933-the retreating figure in sheer delight at [her]102-elisabeth . How fresh and bright and spontaneous [she]102-elisabeth was , [he]121-christopher thought , and how charmingly ignorant of the things which [she]102-elisabeth prided [herself]102-elisabeth upon understanding so profoundly ! [He]121-christopher laughed aloud as [he]121-christopher recalled how very wise [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth considered [herself]102-elisabeth . And then [he]121-christopher wondered if life would teach [her]102-elisabeth to be less sure of [her]102-elisabeth own buoyant strength , and less certain of [her]102-elisabeth ultimate success in everything [she]102-elisabeth undertook ; and , if it did , [he]121-christopher felt that [he]121-christopher should have an ugly account to settle with life . [He]121-christopher was willing for [Fate]122-fate to knock [him]121-christopher about as much and as hardly as [she]102-elisabeth pleased , provided [she]102-elisabeth would let [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth alone , and allow [the girl]629-the girl to go on believing in [herself]102-elisabeth and enjoying [herself]102-elisabeth as [she]102-elisabeth was so abundantly capable of doing . By this time [Christopher]121-christopher was enough of [a philosopher]3935-a philosopher to think that it did not really matter much in the long run whether [he]121-christopher were happy or unhappy ; but [he]121-christopher was not yet able to regard the thought of [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's unhappiness as anything but a catastrophe of the most insupportable magnitude ; which showed that [he]121-christopher had not yet sufficient philosophy to go round . When [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth arrived at [the Moat House]762-the moat house [she]102-elisabeth found [Mrs. Herbert]197-mrs. herbert alone , [Felicia]154-felicia having gone out driving with [[her]154-felicia husband]490-her husband ; and , to [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's surprise , there was no sign of the jubilation which [she]102-elisabeth had anticipated . On the contrary , [Mrs. Herbert]197-mrs. herbert was subdued and tired - looking . "[0-i] [I]0-i am so glad to see [you]1721-you , [[my]0-i dear]3103-my dear , " [she]197-mrs. herbert said , kissing [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth ; "[0-i] it is lonely in [this big house]1723-this big house all by [myself]0-i . " "[0-i] It is always rather lonely to be in state , " [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth replied , returning [her]102-elisabeth salute . "[0-i] [I]0-i wonder if [kings]1724-they find it lonely all by [themselves]1724-they in pleasures and [palaces]1725-palaces . [I]0-i expect [they]1724-they do , but [they]1724-they put up with the loneliness for the sake of the stateliness ; and [you]1721-you could hardly find [a statelier house than this to be lonely in]1726-a statelier house than this to be lonely in , if [you]1721-you tried . " "[1724-they] Yes ; it is [a beautiful place]1727-a beautiful place , " agreed [Mrs. Herbert]197-mrs. herbert listlessly . [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth wondered what was wrong , but [she]102-elisabeth did not ask ; [she]102-elisabeth knew that [Mrs. Herbert]197-mrs. herbert would confide in [her]102-elisabeth very soon . [People]2982-people very rarely were reserved with [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth ; [she]102-elisabeth was often amazed at the rapidity with which [they]2982-people opened [their]2982-people inmost hearts to [her]102-elisabeth . Probably this accounted in some measure for [her]102-elisabeth slowness in understanding [Christopher]121-christopher , who had made it a point of honour not to open [his]121-christopher inmost heart to [her]102-elisabeth . "[1724-they] Do n't [the woods]3637-the woods look lovely ? " [she]102-elisabeth said cheerfully , pretending not to notice anything . "[0-i] [I]0-i ca n't help seeing that the trees are beautiful with their gilt leaves , but it goes against [my]0-i principles to own it , because [I]0-i do so hate the autumn . [I]0-i wish [we]1729-we could change [our]1729-we four seasons for two springs and two summers . [I]0-i am so happy in the summer , and still happier in the spring looking forward to it ; but [I]0-i am wretched in the winter because [I]0-i am cold , and still wretcheder in the autumn thinking that [I]0-i 'm going to be even colder . " "[0-i] Yes ; [the woods]3637-the woods are pretty — very pretty indeed . " "[0-i] [I]0-i am so glad [you]0-i have come while the leaves are still on . [I]0-i wanted [you]0-i to see [[Felicia]154-felicia 's home]3735-felicia 's home at its very best ; and , at its best , [it]3735-felicia 's home is [a home that [any woman]820-any woman might be proud of]1732-a home that any woman might be proud of . " [Mrs. Herbert]197-mrs. herbert 's lip trembled . "[197-mrs. herbert] [It]3735-felicia 's home is indeed [a most beautiful home]1734-a most beautiful home , and [I]0-i am sure [Felicia]154-felicia has everything to make [her]154-felicia happy . " "[154-felicia] And [she]154-felicia is happy , [Mrs. Herbert]197-mrs. herbert ; [I]0-i do n't think [I]0-i ever saw [anybody]376-anybody so perfectly happy as [Felicia]154-felicia is now . [I]0-i 'm afraid [I]0-i could never be quite as satisfied with any impossible ideal of [a husband]3236-a husband as [she]154-felicia is with [Alan]161-alan ; [I]0-i should want to quarrel with [him]161-alan just for the fun of the thing , and to find out [his]161-alan faults for the pleasure of correcting [them]1737-them . [A man as faultless as [Alan]161-alan]1738-a man as faultless as alan — [I]0-i mean as faultless as [Felicia]154-felicia considers [Alan]161-alan — would bore [me]0-i ; but [he]161-alan suits [her]154-felicia down to the ground . " But even then [Mrs. Herbert]197-mrs. herbert did not smile ; instead of that [her]197-mrs. herbert light blue eyes filled with tears . "[161-alan] Oh ! " For all [her]197-mrs. herbert high spirits , [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth generally recognised tragedy when [she]197-mrs. herbert met it face to face ; and [she]197-mrs. herbert knew that [she]197-mrs. herbert was meeting it now . So [she]197-mrs. herbert spoke very gently — "[154-felicia] [[My]0-i dear]3103-my dear [Mrs. Herbert]197-mrs. herbert , whatever do [you]197-mrs. herbert mean ? [I]0-i am sure [you]197-mrs. herbert are not very strong , and so [your]197-mrs. herbert nerves are out of joint , and make [you]197-mrs. herbert imagine things . " "[197-mrs. herbert] No , [[my]0-i love]3112-my love ; it is no imagination on [my]0-i part . [I]0-i only wish it were . Who can know [Felicia]154-felicia as well as [[her]154-felicia mother]479-her mother knows [her]154-felicia — [[her]154-felicia mother who has worshipped [her]154-felicia and toiled for [her]154-felicia ever since [she]154-felicia was [a little baby]1744-a little baby]1743-her mother who has worshipped her and toiled for her ever since she was a little baby ? And [I]0-i , who can read [her]154-felicia through and through , feel that [she]154-felicia is ashamed of [me]0-i . " And the tears overflowed , and rolled down [Mrs. Herbert]197-mrs. herbert 's faded cheeks . [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's heart swelled with an immense pity , for [her]102-elisabeth quick insight told [her]102-elisabeth that [Mrs. Herbert]197-mrs. herbert was not mistaken ; but all [she]102-elisabeth said was — "[0-i] [I]0-i think [you]0-i are making mountains out of molehills . [Lots of [girls]519-girls]1745-lots of girls lose [their]1745-lots of girls heads a bit when first [they]1745-lots of girls are married , and seem to regard marriage as a special invention and prerogative of [their]1745-lots of girls own , which entitles [them]1745-lots of girls to give [themselves]1745-lots of girls air ad libitum ; but [they]1745-lots of girls soon grow out of it . " [Mrs. Herbert]197-mrs. herbert shook [her]197-mrs. herbert head sorrowfully ; [her]197-mrs. herbert tongue was loosed and [she]197-mrs. herbert spake plain . "[1745-lots of girls] Oh ! it is n't like that with [Felicia]154-felicia ; [I]0-i should think nothing of that . [I]0-i remember when first [I]0-i was married [I]0-i thought that [no unmarried woman]1747-no unmarried woman knew anything , and that [no married woman]1748-no married woman knew anything but [myself]0-i ; but , as [you]1749-you say , [I]0-i soon grew out of that . Why , [I]0-i was quite ready , after [I]0-i had been married a couple of months , to teach [[my]0-i dear mother]1750-my dear mother all about housekeeping ; and finely [she]1750-my dear mother laughed at [me]0-i for it . But [Felicia]154-felicia does n't trouble to teach [me]0-i anything ; [she]154-felicia thinks it is n't worth while . " "[154-felicia] Oh ! [I]0-i can not believe that [Felicia]154-felicia is like that . [You]1749-you must be mistaken . " "[1749-you] Mistaken in [[my]0-i own child]1751-my own child , whom [I]0-i carried in [my]0-i arms as [a little baby]1744-a little baby ? No , [[my]0-i dear]3103-my dear ; there are some things about which [mothers]1754-mothers can never be mistaken , God help [them]1754-mothers ! Do [you]1755-you think [I]0-i did not understand when [the carriage]3457-the carriage came round to - day to take [her]154-felicia and [Alan]161-alan to return [Lady Patchingham]210-lady patchingham 's visit , and [Felicia]154-felicia said , ' [Mamma]1212-mamma wo n't go with [us]1758-us to - day , [[Alan]161-alan dear]1759-alan dear , because the wind is in [the east]1760-the east , and it always gives [her]154-felicia a cold to drive in [an open carriage]1761-an open carriage when the wind is in the east ' ? Oh ! [I]0-i saw plain enough that [she]154-felicia did n't want [me]0-i to go with [them]1758-us to [Lady Patchingham]210-lady patchingham 's ; but [I]0-i only thanked [her]154-felicia and said [I]0-i would rather stay [indoors]1762-indoors , as it would be safer for [me]0-i . When [they]1758-us had started [I]0-i went out and looked at the weather - cock for [myself]0-i ; it pointed southwest . " And the big tears rolled down faster than ever . [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth did not know what to say ; so [she]102-elisabeth wisely said nothing , but took [Mrs. Herbert]197-mrs. herbert 's hand in [hers]102-elisabeth and stroked it . " "[105-god] Well , [[my]0-i love]3112-my love , [I]0-i can not say ; it is not for [us]1766-us to inquire into the counsels of [the Almighty]843-the almighty . But [I]0-i did it for the best ; [I]0-i did , indeed . [I]0-i did so want [Felicia]154-felicia to be happy . " "[0-i] [I]0-i am sure [you]0-i did . " "[0-i] [You]1769-you see , all [my]0-i life [I]0-i had taken an inferior position socially , and the iron of it had entered into [my]0-i soul . [I]0-i daresay it was sinful of [me]0-i , but [I]0-i used to mind so dreadfully when [[my]0-i husband]1770-my husband and [I]0-i were always asked to second - rate parties , and introduced to [second - rate people]1771-second - rate people ; and [I]0-i longed and prayed that [[my]0-i darling]1772-my darling [Felicia]154-felicia should be spared the misery and the humiliation which [I]0-i had had to undergo . [You]1769-you wo n't understand it , [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth . [People in a good position]1773-people in a good position never do ; but to be alternately snubbed and patronized all one 's life , as [I]0-i have been , makes social intercourse one long - drawn - out agony to [a sensitive woman]1774-a sensitive woman . So [I]0-i prayed — how [I]0-i prayed!—that [[my]0-i beautiful daughter]1775-my beautiful daughter should never suffer as [I]0-i have done . " [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's eyes filled with tears ; and [Mrs. Herbert]197-mrs. herbert , encouraged by [her]197-mrs. herbert unspoken sympathy , proceeded — "[1776-grand people] [Grand people]1776-grand people are so cruel , [[my]0-i dear]3103-my dear . [I]0-i daresay [they]1776-grand people do n't mean to be ; but [they]1776-grand people are . And though [I]0-i had borne it for [myself]0-i , [I]0-i felt [I]0-i could not bear it for [Felicia]154-felicia . [I]0-i thought it would kill [me]0-i to see [fine ladies]1778-fine ladies overlook [her]154-felicia as [they]1778-fine ladies had so often overlooked [me]0-i . So when [Alan]161-alan wanted to marry [her]154-felicia , and make [her]154-felicia into [a fine lady]1779-a fine lady [herself]154-felicia , [I]0-i was overwhelmed with joy ; and [I]0-i felt [I]0-i no longer minded what [I]0-i had gone through , now that [I]0-i knew [no one]3126-no one would ever dare to be rude to [[my]0-i beautiful daughter]1775-my beautiful daughter . Now [I]0-i see [I]0-i was wrong to set earthly blessings before spiritual ones ; but [I]0-i think [you]1782-you understand how [I]0-i felt , [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth . " "[102-elisabeth] Yes , [I]0-i understand ; and [God]105-god understands too . " "[105-god] Then do n't [you]1782-you think [He]105-god is punishing [me]0-i , [[my]0-i dear]3103-my dear ? " "[1782-you] No ; [I]0-i think [He]105-god is training [Felicia]154-felicia — and perhaps [you]1782-you too , dear [Mrs. Herbert]197-mrs. herbert . " "[197-mrs. herbert] Oh ! [She]154-felicia was [such a beautiful baby that [the people in [the street]293-the street]1786-the people in the street]1785-such a beautiful baby that the people in the street used to stop [the nurse]1788-the nurse to ask whose child [she]154-felicia was ; and when [she]154-felicia grew older [she]154-felicia never gave [us]1789-us a moment 's trouble or anxiety . Then [we]1789-us pinched and pared in order to be able to afford to send [her]154-felicia to [Fox How]25-fox how ; and when [her]154-felicia education was finished there was n't [a more perfect lady in [the land]3580-the land than [[our]1789-us Felicia]1792-our felicia]1790-a more perfect lady in the land than our felicia . " And [Mrs. Herbert]197-mrs. herbert covered [her]197-mrs. herbert face with [her]197-mrs. herbert hands and burst out into bitter sobs . "[0-i] [[My]0-i poor dear]1796-my poor dear , [you]1796-my poor dear are doing [Him]1797-he an injustice , [you]1796-my poor dear are , indeed . [I]0-i am sure [He]1797-he minds even more than [you]1796-my poor dear do that [Felicia]154-felicia is still so ignorant and foolish , and [He]1797-he is training [her]154-felicia in [His]1797-he own way . But [He]1797-he is n't doing it to punish [you]1796-my poor dear , [dear]1798-dear ; believe [me]0-i , [He]1797-he is n't . Why , even [the ordinary human beings who are fond of [us]1800-we]1799-the ordinary human beings who are fond of us want to cure [our]1800-we faults and not to punish [them]1801-they , " [she]154-felicia continued , as the memory of [Christopher]121-christopher 's unfailing patience with [her]154-felicia suddenly came into [her]154-felicia mind , and [she]154-felicia recalled how often [she]154-felicia had hurt [him]121-christopher , and how readily [he]121-christopher had always forgiven [her]154-felicia ; "[1801-they] [they]1801-they are sorry when [we]1800-we do wrong , but [they]1801-they are even sorrier when [we]1800-we suffer for it . And do [you]1802-you think [God]105-god loves [us]1800-we less than [they]1801-they do , and is quicker to punish and slower to forgive ? " So does the love of [the brother whom [we]1800-we have seen]3939-the brother whom we have seen help [us]1800-we in some measure to understand the love of [the God Whom [we]1800-we have not seen]3940-the god whom we have not seen ; for which [we]1800-we owe [the brother]3941-the brother eternal thanks . "[3103-my dear] [[My]0-i dear]3103-my dear , " said [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth , when [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth came down one morning to breakfast , "[3103-my dear] there is sad news to - day . " [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth was never late in a morning . [She]102-elisabeth regarded early rising as a virtue on a par with faith and charity ; while to appear at the breakfast - table after the breakfast itself had already appeared thereon was , in [her]102-elisabeth eyes , as the sin of witchcraft . "[3103-my dear] What is the matter ? " asked [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth , somewhat breathlessly . [She]102-elisabeth had run [downstairs]3942-downstairs at full speed in order to enter [the dining - room]3943-the dining - room before the dishes , completing [her]102-elisabeth toilet as [she]102-elisabeth fled ; and [she]102-elisabeth had only beaten the bacon by a neck . "[3103-my dear] [Richard Smallwood]104-richard smallwood has had a paralytic stroke . [Christopher]121-christopher sent up word the first thing this morning . " "[121-christopher] Oh ! [I]0-i am so sorry . [Mr. Smallwood]169-mr. smallwood is such [a dear old man]1804-a dear old man , and used to be so kind to [Christopher]121-christopher and [me]0-i when [we]1805-we were little . " "[0-i] [I]0-i am very sorry , too , [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth . [I]0-i have known [Richard Smallwood]104-richard smallwood all [my]0-i life , and [he]104-richard smallwood was [a valued friend of [[my]0-i dear father]1807-my dear father 's]1806-a valued friend of my dear father 's , as well as being [his]104-richard smallwood right hand in all matters of business . Both [[my]0-i father]1808-my father and [uncle]349-uncle thought very highly of [Richard]104-richard smallwood 's opinion , and considered that [they]1810-they owed much of [their]1810-they commercial success to [his]104-richard smallwood advice and assistance . " "[121-christopher] [Poor Christopher]121-christopher ! [I]0-i wonder if [he]121-christopher will mind much ? " "[0-i] Of course [he]121-christopher will mind , [[my]0-i dear]3103-my dear . What [a strange child]1812-a strange child [you]3103-my dear are , and what peculiar things [you]3103-my dear say ! [Mr. Smallwood]169-mr. smallwood is [[Christopher]121-christopher 's only living relative]1813-christopher 's only living relative , and when anything happens to [him]121-christopher [Christopher]121-christopher will be entirely alone in [the world]301-the world . It is sad for [any one]639-any one to be quite alone ; and especially for [young people , who have a natural craving for companionship and sympathy]1816-young people , who have a natural craving for companionship and sympathy . " [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth sighed . [She]102-elisabeth had spent most of [her]102-elisabeth life in [the wilderness]3028-the wilderness and on [the mountain - tops]3945-the mountain - tops , and [she]102-elisabeth knew how cold was the climate and how dreary the prospect there . [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's eyes filled with tears , and [her]102-elisabeth heart swelled with a strange new feeling [she]102-elisabeth had never felt before . For the first time in [her]102-elisabeth life [Christopher]121-christopher ( unconsciously on [his]121-christopher part ) made a direct appeal to [her]102-elisabeth pity , and [her]102-elisabeth heart responded to the appeal . [His]121-christopher perspective , from [her]102-elisabeth point of view , was suddenly changed ; [he]121-christopher was no longer [the kindly , easy - going comrade with whom [she]102-elisabeth had laughed and quarrelled and made it up again ever since [she]102-elisabeth could remember , and with whom [she]102-elisabeth was on a footing of such familiar intimacy]3946-the kindly , easy - going comrade with whom she had laughed and quarrelled and made it up again ever since she could remember , and with whom she was on a footing of such familiar intimacy ; instead , [he]121-christopher had become [a man standing in the shadow of a great sorrow]3947-a man standing in the shadow of a great sorrow , whose solitary grief commanded [her]102-elisabeth respect and at the same time claimed [her]102-elisabeth tenderness . All through breakfast , and the prayers which followed , [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's thoughts ran on this new [Christopher]121-christopher , who was so much more interesting and yet so much farther off than [the old one]674-the old one . [She]102-elisabeth wondered how [he]121-christopher would look and what [he]121-christopher would say when next [she]102-elisabeth saw [him]121-christopher ; and [she]102-elisabeth longed to see [him]121-christopher again , and yet felt frightened at the thought of doing so . At prayers that morning [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth read the lament of [David]212-david over [Saul]213-saul and [Jonathan]214-jonathan ; and while the words of undying pathos sounded in [her]102-elisabeth ears , [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth wondered whether [Christopher]121-christopher would mourn as [David]212-david did if [[his]121-christopher uncle]775-his uncle were to die , and whether [he]121-christopher would let [her]102-elisabeth comfort [him]121-christopher . When prayers were over , [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth bade [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth accompany [her]102-elisabeth to [Mr. Smallwood]169-mr. smallwood 's ; and all the way there [the girl]629-the girl 's heart was beating so fast that it almost choked [her]102-elisabeth , with mingled fear of and tenderness for [this new Christopher who had taken the place of [[her]102-elisabeth old playmate]3952-her old playmate]3951-this new christopher who had taken the place of her old playmate . As [they]3953-they sat waiting for [him]121-christopher in [the oak - panelled dining - room]3954-the oak - panelled dining - room , a fresh wave of pity swept over [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth as [she]102-elisabeth realized for the first time — though [she]102-elisabeth had sat there over and over again — what [a cheerless home]3955-a cheerless home this was in which to spend [one]543-one 's childhood and youth , and how pluckily [Christopher]121-christopher had always made the best of things , and had never confessed — even to [her]102-elisabeth — what a dreary lot was [his]121-christopher . Then [he]121-christopher came [downstairs]3942-downstairs ; and as [she]102-elisabeth heard [his]121-christopher familiar footstep crossing [the hall]3059-the hall [her]102-elisabeth heart beat faster than ever , and there was a mist before [her]102-elisabeth eyes ; but when [he]121-christopher entered [the room]3736-the room and shook hands , first with [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth and then with [her]102-elisabeth , [she]102-elisabeth was quite surprised to see that [he]121-christopher looked very much as [he]121-christopher always looked , only [his]121-christopher face was pale and [his]121-christopher eyes heavy for want of sleep ; and [his]121-christopher smile was as kind as ever as it lighted upon [her]102-elisabeth . "[1817-you] It is very good of [you]1817-you to come to [me]0-i so quickly , " [he]121-christopher said , addressing [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth but looking at [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth . "[1817-you] Not at all , [Christopher]121-christopher , " replied [Miss Maria]156-miss maria ; "[121-christopher] those who have [friends]3544-friends must show [themselves]3544-friends friendly , and [[your]121-christopher uncle]1819-your uncle has certainly proved [himself]1819-your uncle of the sort that sticketh closer than [a brother]3257-a brother . [No son]1821-no son could have done more for [[my]0-i father]1808-my father — [no brother]1823-no brother could have done more for [me]0-i — than [he]1808-my father has done ; and therefore [his]1808-my father affliction is [my]0-i affliction , and [his]1808-my father loss is [my]0-i loss . " "[0-i] [You]0-i are very kind . " And [Christopher]121-christopher 's voice shook a little . [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth did not speak . [She]102-elisabeth was struggling with a feeling of uncontrollable shyness which completely tied [her]102-elisabeth usually fluent tongue . "[0-i] Is [he]1808-my father very ill ? " [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth asked . "[0-i] Yes , " [Christopher]121-christopher replied , "[0-i] [I]0-i 'm afraid it 's a bad job altogether . [The doctor]1824-the doctor thinks [he]1808-my father will last only a few days ; but if [he]1808-my father lives [he]1808-my father will never regain the use of [his]1808-my father speech or of [his]1808-my father brain ; and [I]0-i do n't know that life under such conditions is a boon to be desired . " "[0-i] [I]0-i do not think it is . Yet [[we]1825-we poor mortals]1826-we poor mortals long to keep [[our]1825-we beloved ones]1827-our beloved ones with [us]1825-we , even though it is but the semblance of [their]1827-our beloved ones former selves that remain . " [Christopher]121-christopher did not answer . There suddenly rushed over [him]121-christopher the memory of all that [[his]121-christopher uncle]775-his uncle had been to [him]121-christopher , and of how [that uncle]777-that uncle still treated [him]121-christopher as [a little child]3789-a little child ; and with it came the consciousness that , when [[his]121-christopher uncle]775-his uncle was gone , [nobody]409-nobody would ever treat [him]121-christopher as [a little child]3789-a little child any more . Life is somewhat dreary when the time comes for [us]3966-us to be grown - up to [everybody]3055-everybody ; so [Christopher]121-christopher looked ( and did not see ) out of the window , instead of speaking . "[1829-he] Of course , " [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth continued , "[1829-he] [you]1828-you will take [his]1829-he place , should [he]1829-he be — as [I]0-i fear is inevitable — unable to resume work at [the Osierfield]102-elisabeth ; and [I]0-i have such a high opinion of [you]1828-you , [Christopher]121-christopher , that [I]0-i have no doubt [you]1828-you will do [[your]1828-you uncle]1819-your uncle 's work as well as [he]1829-he has done it , and there could not be higher praise . Nevertheless , it saddens [me]0-i to know that another of the old landmarks has been swept away , and that now [I]0-i only am left of what used to be [the Osierfield]102-elisabeth forty years ago . The work may be done as well by the new hands and brains as by [the old ones]1831-the old ones ; but after one has crossed [the summit of [the mountain]1833-the mountain]1832-the summit of the mountain and begun to go downhill , it is sorry work exchanging old lamps for new . The new lamps may give brighter light , perchance ; but their light is too strong for tired old eyes ; and [we]1834-we grow homesick for the things to which [we]1834-we are accustomed . " And [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth took off [her]102-elisabeth spectacles and wiped them . There was silence for a few seconds , while [Christopher]121-christopher manfully struggled with [his]121-christopher feelings and [Miss Maria]156-miss maria decorously gave vent to [hers]156-miss maria . [Christopher]121-christopher was vexed with [himself]121-christopher for so nearly breaking down before [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth , and throwing the shadow of [his]121-christopher sorrow across the sunshine of [her]102-elisabeth path . [He]121-christopher did not know that [the mother]3914-the mother - heart in [her]102-elisabeth was yearning over [him]121-christopher with a tenderness almost too powerful to be resisted , and that [his]121-christopher weakness was constraining [her]102-elisabeth as [his]121-christopher strength had never done . [He]121-christopher was rather surprised that [she]102-elisabeth did not speak to [him]121-christopher ; but with the patient simplicity of [a strong man]3969-a strong man [he]121-christopher accepted [her]102-elisabeth behaviour without questioning it . [Her]102-elisabeth mere presence in [the room]3736-the room somehow changed everything , and made [him]121-christopher feel that [no world which contained [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth]3971-no world which contained elisabeth could ever be [an entirely sorrowful world]3972-an entirely sorrowful world . Of course [he]121-christopher knew nothing about the new Christopher which had suddenly arisen above [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's horizon ; [he]121-christopher was far too masculine to understand that [his]121-christopher own pathos could be pathetic , or [his]121-christopher own suffering dramatic . It is only [women]446-women — or [[men]445-men who have much of [the woman]3411-the woman in [their]445-men composition]3975-men who have much of the woman in their composition — who can say : [The thoroughly manly man]3977-the thoroughly manly man is incapable of seeing the picturesque effect of [his]3977-the thoroughly manly man own misery . So [Christopher]121-christopher pulled [himself]121-christopher together and tried to talk of trivial things ; and [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth , having walked through [the dark valley]297-the dark valley [herself]102-elisabeth , knew the comfort of the commonplace therein , and fell in with [his]121-christopher mood , discussing [nurses]3979-nurses and remedies and domestic arrangements and the like . [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth , however , was distinctly disappointed in [Christopher]121-christopher , because [he]121-christopher could bring [himself]121-christopher down to dwell upon these trifling matters when [the Angel of Death]3980-the angel of death had crossed the lintel of [his]121-christopher doorway only last night , and was still hovering round with overshadowing wings . It was just like [him]121-christopher , [she]102-elisabeth said to [herself]102-elisabeth , to give [his]121-christopher attention to surface details , and to miss the deeper thing . [She]102-elisabeth had yet to learn that it was because [he]121-christopher felt so much , and not because [he]121-christopher felt so little , that [Christopher]121-christopher found it hard to utter the inmost thoughts of [his]121-christopher heart . But when [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth had made every possible arrangement for [Mr. Smallwood]169-mr. smallwood 's comfort , and [they]3981-they rose to leave , [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's heart smote [her]102-elisabeth for [her]102-elisabeth passing impatience ; so [she]102-elisabeth lingered behind after [[her]102-elisabeth cousin]451-her cousin had left [the room]3736-the room , and , slipping [her]102-elisabeth hand into [Christopher]121-christopher 's , [she]102-elisabeth whispered — "[125-chris] [Chris]125-chris , [dear]1798-dear , [I]0-i 'm so dreadfully sorry ! " It was a poor little speech for [the usually eloquent Elisabeth]102-elisabeth to make ; in cold blood [she]102-elisabeth [herself]102-elisabeth would have been ashamed of it ; but [Christopher]121-christopher was quite content . For a second [he]121-christopher forgot that [he]121-christopher had decided not to let [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth know that [he]121-christopher loved [her]102-elisabeth until [he]121-christopher was in a position to marry [her]102-elisabeth , and [he]121-christopher very nearly took [her]102-elisabeth in [his]121-christopher strong arms and kissed [her]102-elisabeth there and then ; but before [he]121-christopher had time to do this , [[his]121-christopher good angel]3984-his good angel ( or perhaps [his]121-christopher bad one , for it is often difficult to ascertain how [one]543-one 's two guardian spirits divide [their]3986-their work ) reminded [him]121-christopher that it was [his]121-christopher duty to leave [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth free to live [her]102-elisabeth own life , unhampered by the knowledge of a love which might possibly find no fulfilment in this world where money is considered the one thing needful ; so [he]121-christopher merely returned the pressure of [her]102-elisabeth hand , and said in a queer , strained sort of voice — "[125-chris] Thanks awfully , [dear]1798-dear . It is n't half so rough on [a fellow]1837-a fellow when [he]1837-a fellow knows [you]1798-dear are sorry . " And [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth also was content . Contrary to [the doctor]1824-the doctor 's expectations , [Richard Smallwood]104-richard smallwood did not die : [he]104-richard smallwood had lost all power of thought or speech , and never regained them , but lived on for years a living corpse ; and the burden of [his]104-richard smallwood illness lay heavily on [Christopher]121-christopher 's young shoulders . Life was specially dark to poor [Christopher]121-christopher just then . [[His]121-christopher uncle]775-his uncle 's utter break - down effectually closed the door on all chances of escape from the drudgery of [the Osierfield]102-elisabeth to a higher and wider sphere ; for , until now , [he]121-christopher had continued to hope against hope that [he]121-christopher might induce [that uncle]777-that uncle to start [him]121-christopher in some other walk of life , where the winning of [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth would enter into the region of practical politics . But now all chance of this was over ; [Richard Smallwood]104-richard smallwood was beyond the reach of the entreaties and arguments which hitherto [he]104-richard smallwood had so firmly resisted . There was nothing left for [Christopher]121-christopher to do but to step into [[his]121-christopher uncle]775-his uncle 's shoes , and try to make the best of [his]121-christopher life as [general manager of [the Osierfield]102-elisabeth]3991-general manager of the osierfield , handicapped still further by the charge of [that uncle]777-that uncle , which made it impossible for [him]104-richard smallwood to dream of bringing [home]399-home [a wife]311-a wife to [the big old house in [the High Street]9-the high street]3995-the big old house in the high street . There was only one drop of sweetness in the bitterness of [his]121-christopher cup — one ray of light in the darkness of [his]121-christopher outlook ; and that was the consciousness that [he]121-christopher could still go on seeing and loving and serving [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth , although [he]121-christopher might never be able to tell [her]102-elisabeth [he]121-christopher was doing so . [He]121-christopher hoped that [she]102-elisabeth would understand ; but here [he]121-christopher was too sanguine ; [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth was as yet incapable of comprehending any emotion until [she]102-elisabeth had seen it reduced to a prescription . So [Christopher]121-christopher lived on in [the gloomy house]3996-the gloomy house , and looked after [[his]121-christopher uncle]775-his uncle as tenderly as [a mother]1277-a mother looks after [a sick child]3999-a sick child . To all intents and purposes [Richard]104-richard smallwood was [a child]3440-a child again ; [he]104-richard smallwood could not speak or think , but [he]104-richard smallwood still loved [[his]104-richard smallwood nephew]4001-his nephew , the only one of [his]104-richard smallwood own flesh and blood ; and [he]104-richard smallwood smiled like [a child]3440-a child every time that [Christopher]121-christopher came into [[his]104-richard smallwood room]4003-his room , and cried like [a child]3440-a child ever ; time that [Christopher]121-christopher went away . [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth was very sorry for [Christopher]121-christopher at first , and very tender toward [him]121-christopher ; but after a time the coldness , which [he]121-christopher felt it [his]121-christopher duty to show toward [her]102-elisabeth in the changed state of affairs , had its natural effect , and [she]102-elisabeth decided that it was foolish to waste [her]102-elisabeth sympathy upon [any one who obviously needed and valued it so little]4005-any one who obviously needed and valued it so little . Moreover , [she]102-elisabeth had not forgotten that strange , new feeling which disturbed [her]102-elisabeth heart the morning after [Mr. Smallwood]169-mr. smallwood was taken ill ; and [she]102-elisabeth experienced , half unconsciously , a thoroughly feminine resentment against [the man who had called into being such an emotion , and then apparently had found no use for it]4006-the man who had called into being such an emotion , and then apparently had found no use for it . So [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth in [her]102-elisabeth heart of hearts was at war with [Christopher]121-christopher — that slumbering , smouldering sort of warfare which is ready to break out into fire and battle at the slightest provocation ; and this state of affairs did not tend to make life any the easier for [him]121-christopher . [He]121-christopher felt [he]121-christopher could have cheerfully borne it all if only [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth had been kind and had understood ; but [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth did not understand [him]121-christopher in the least , and was consequently unkind — far more unkind than [she]102-elisabeth , in [her]102-elisabeth careless , light - hearted philosophy , dreamed of . [She]102-elisabeth , too , had [her]102-elisabeth disappointments to bear just then . [The artist]393-the artist - soul in [her]102-elisabeth had grown up , and was crying out for expression ; and [she]102-elisabeth vainly prayed [[her]102-elisabeth cousin]451-her cousin to let [her]102-elisabeth go to [the Slade School]1140-the slade school , and there learn to develop the power that was in [her]102-elisabeth . But [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth belonged to [the generation which regarded art purely as a recreation]4010-the generation which regarded art purely as a recreation — such as fancy - work , croquet , and the like — and [she]102-elisabeth considered that [young women]4011-young women should be trained for the more serious things of life ; by which [she]102-elisabeth meant the ordering of suitable dinners for [the rich]879-the rich and the manufacturing of seemly garments for [the poor]853-the poor . So [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth had to endure the agony which none but [an artist]567-an artist can know — the agony of being dumb when one has an angel - whispered secret to tell forth — of being bound hand and foot when [one]543-one has a God - sent message to write upon the wall . Now and then [Miss Maria]156-miss maria took [[her]156-miss maria young cousin]4016-her young cousin up to [town]4017-town for a few weeks , and thus [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth came to have a bowing acquaintanceship with [London]15-london ; but of [London]15-london as [an ever - fascinating , never - wearying friend]4018-an ever - fascinating , never - wearying friend [she]102-elisabeth knew nothing . There are people who tell [us]4019-us that "[1837-a fellow] [London]15-london is delightful in the season , " and that "[1837-a fellow] [the country]3528-the country is very pretty in the summer , " and [we]4019-us smile at [them]4020-them as [a man]310-a man would smile at [those who said that [[his]310-a man mother]771-his mother was "[1839-a pleasant person] [a pleasant person]1839-a pleasant person , " or [his]310-a man heart 's dearest "[1840-a charming girl] [a charming girl]1840-a charming girl]4022-those who said that his mother was " a pleasant person , " or his heart 's dearest " a charming girl . " [Those who know [London]15-london and [the country]3528-the country , as [London]15-london and [the country]3528-the country deserve to be known]4024-those who know london and the country , as london and the country deserve to be known , do not talk in this way , for [they]4024-those who know london and the country , as london and the country deserve to be known have learned that there is no end to the wonder or the interest or the mystery of either . The year following [Richard Smallwood]104-richard smallwood 's break - down , a new interest came into [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's life . [A son and heir]4027-a son and heir was born at [the Moat House]34-the moat house ; and [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth was one of [the women who are predestined to the worship of [babies]4029-babies]4028-the women who are predestined to the worship of babies . Very tightly did the tiny fingers twine themselves round [her]102-elisabeth somewhat empty heart ; for [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth was meant to love much , and at present [her]102-elisabeth supply of the article was greatly in excess of the demand made upon it . So [she]102-elisabeth poured the surplus — which [no one else]592-no one else seemed to need — upon [the innocent head of [[Felicia]154-felicia 's baby]4032-felicia 's baby]4031-the innocent head of felicia 's baby ; and [she]102-elisabeth found that [the baby]4033-the baby never misjudged [her]102-elisabeth nor disappointed [her]102-elisabeth , as [older people]4034-older people seemed so apt to do . [One of [[her]102-elisabeth most devout fellow - worshippers]4036-her most devout fellow - worshippers]4035-one of her most devout fellow - worshippers was [Mrs. Herbert]197-mrs. herbert , who derived comfort from the fact that [little Willie]215-willie was not ashamed of [her]197-mrs. herbert as [[little Willie]215-willie 's mother]4037-little willie 's mother was ; so — like [many [a disappointed woman]4039-a disappointed woman before [them]4040-them]4038-many a disappointed woman before them — both [Mrs. Herbert]197-mrs. herbert and [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth discovered the healing power which lies in the touch of [a baby]480-a baby 's hand . [Felicia]154-felicia loved [the child]2988-the child , too , in [her]154-felicia way ; but [she]154-felicia was of [the type of woman to whom [the husband]952-the husband is always dearer than [the children]443-the children]4043-the type of woman to whom the husband is always dearer than the children . But [Alan]161-alan 's cup was filled to overflowing , and [he]161-alan loved [[his]161-alan son]3384-his son as [he]161-alan loved [his]161-alan own soul . One of [Christopher]121-christopher 's expedients for hiding the meditations of [his]121-christopher heart from [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's curious eyes was the discussion with [her]102-elisabeth of what [people]2982-people call "[1840-a charming girl] general subjects " ; and this tried [her]102-elisabeth temper to the utmost . [She]102-elisabeth regarded it as a sign of superficiality to talk of superficial things ; and [she]102-elisabeth hardly ever went in to dinner with [a man]310-a man without arriving at the discussion of abstract love and the second entrée simultaneously . It had never yet dawned upon [her]102-elisabeth that as a rule it is because one has not experienced a feeling that [one]543-one is able to describe it ; [she]102-elisabeth reasoned in the contrary direction , and came to the conclusion that [those persons]4050-those persons have no hearts at all whose sleeves are unadorned with the same . Therefore it was intolerable to [her]102-elisabeth when [Christopher]121-christopher — who had played with [her]102-elisabeth as [a child]3440-a child , and had once very nearly made [her]102-elisabeth grow up into [a woman]469-a woman — talked to [her]102-elisabeth about the contents of the newspapers . "[0-i] [I]0-i never look at the papers , " [she]102-elisabeth answered crossly one day , in reply to some unexceptionable and uninteresting comment of [his]121-christopher upon such history as was just then in the raw material ; "[0-i] [I]0-i hate [them]1841-them . " "[0-i] Why do [you]0-i hate [them]1841-them ? " [Christopher]121-christopher was surprised at [her]102-elisabeth vehemence . "[0-i] Because there is cholera in [the South of]1842-the south of [France]60-france , and [I]0-i never look at the papers when there is cholera about , it frightens [me]0-i so . " [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth had all the pity of [a thoroughly healthy person]4053-a thoroughly healthy person for the suffering that could not touch [her]102-elisabeth , and the unreasoning terror of [a thoroughly healthy person]4053-a thoroughly healthy person for the suffering which could . "[0-i] But there is nothing to frighten [you]0-i in that , " said [Christopher]121-christopher , in [his]121-christopher most comforting tone ; "[0-i] [France]60-france is such a beastly dirty hole that [they]60-france are bound to have diseases going on there , such as could never trouble clean , local - boarded , old [England]3-england . And then it 's so far away , too . [I]0-i 'd never worry about that , if [I]0-i were [you]0-i . " "[0-i] Would n't [you]0-i ? " [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth was at war with [him]121-christopher , but [she]102-elisabeth was not insensible to the consolation [he]121-christopher never failed to afford [her]102-elisabeth when things went wrong . "[0-i] [Good gracious]1239-good gracious , no ! [England]3-england is so well looked after , with [county councils]1844-county councils and such , that even if an epidemic came [here]3308-here [they]60-france 'd stamp it out like [one o'clock]1846-one o'clock . Do n't frighten [yourself]0-i with bogeys , [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth , there 's [a good girl]3190-a good girl ! " "[3190-a good girl] [I]0-i feel just the same about newspapers now that [I]0-i used to feel about [Lalla Rookh]61-lalla rookh , " said [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth confidentially . [Christopher]121-christopher was puzzled . "[0-i] [I]0-i 'm afraid [I]0-i do n't see quite the connection , but [I]0-i have no doubt it is there , like [Mrs. Wilfer]216-mrs. wilfer 's petticoat . " "[216-mrs. wilfer] In [Cousin Maria]100-cousin maria 's copy of [Lalla Rookh]61-lalla rookh there is a most awful picture of [the Veiled Prophet of Khorassan]217-the veiled prophet of khorassan ; and when [I]0-i was little [I]0-i went nearly mad with terror of that picture . [I]0-i used to go and look at it when [nobody]409-nobody was about , and it frightened [me]0-i more and more every time . " "[0-i] Why on earth did n't [you]0-i tell [me]0-i about it ? " "[0-i] [I]0-i do n't know . [I]0-i felt [I]0-i would n't tell [anybody]376-anybody for worlds , but must keep it a ghastly secret . Sometimes [I]0-i used to hide the book , and try to forget where [I]0-i 'd hidden it . But [I]0-i never could forget , and in the end [I]0-i always went and found it , and peeped at the picture and nearly died of terror . The mere outside of the book had a horrible fascination for [me]0-i . [I]0-i used to look at it all the time [I]0-i was in [the drawing - room]1850-the drawing - room , and then pretend [I]0-i was n't looking at it ; yet if [the housemaid]1851-the housemaid had moved it an inch in dusting the table where it lay , [I]0-i always knew . " "[1851-the housemaid] [Poor little silly child]1852-poor little silly child ! If only [you]0-i 'd have told [me]0-i , [I]0-i 'd have asked [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth to put it away where [you]0-i could n't get at it . " "[102-elisabeth] But [I]0-i could n't have told [you]0-i , [Chris]125-chris — [I]0-i could n't have told [anybody]376-anybody . There seemed to be some terrible bond between that dreadful book and [me]0-i which [I]0-i was bound to keep secret . Of course it does n't frighten [me]0-i any longer , though [I]0-i shall always hate it ; but the newspapers frighten [me]0-i just in the same way when there are horrible things in them . " "[102-elisabeth] Why , [Betty]102-elisabeth , [I]0-i am ashamed of [you]0-i ! [They]1855-they always make the worst of things in newspapers in order to sell them . " "[1855-they] Oh ! then [you]0-i think things are n't as bad as newspapers say ? " "[1855-they] Nothing like ; but [they]1855-they must write something for [people]2982-people to read , and the more sensational it is the better [people]2982-people like it . " [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth was comforted ; and [she]102-elisabeth never knew that [Christopher]121-christopher did not leave [the house]596-the house that day without asking [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth if , for a few weeks , the daily paper might be delivered at the works and sent up to [the Willows]8-the willows afterward , as [he]121-christopher wanted to see the trade - reports the first thing in the morning . This was done ; and sometimes [Christopher]121-christopher remembered to send the papers on to [the house]596-the house , and sometimes [he]121-christopher did not . On these latter occasions [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth severely reproved [him]121-christopher , and told [him]121-christopher that [he]121-christopher would never be as capable a man as [[his]121-christopher uncle]775-his uncle had been , if [he]121-christopher did not endeavour to cultivate [his]121-christopher memory ; whereat [Chris]125-chris was inwardly tickled , but was outwardly very penitent and apologetic , promising to try to be less forgetful in future . And [he]121-christopher kept [his]121-christopher word ; for not once — while the epidemic in [the South of [France]60-france]4058-the south of france lasted — did [he]121-christopher forget to forget to send the newspaper up to [the Willows]8-the willows when there was anything in it calculated to alarm [the most timid reader]4059-the most timid reader . "[1855-they] [Cousin Maria]100-cousin maria , " said [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth , a few days after this , "[100-cousin maria] [I]0-i hear that [[Coulson]218-coulson 's circus]1858-coulson 's circus is coming to [Burlingham]62-burlingham , and [I]0-i want to go and see it . " [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth looked up over the tops of [her]102-elisabeth gold - rimmed spectacles . "[0-i] Do [you]0-i , [[my]0-i dear]3103-my dear ? Well , [I]0-i see no reason why [you]0-i should not . [I]0-i have been brought up to disapprove of [theatres]1860-theatres , and [I]0-i always shall disapprove of them ; but [I]0-i confess [I]0-i have never seen any harm in going to [a circus]1861-a circus . " It is always interesting to note where [people]2982-people draw the line between right and wrong in dealing with forms of amusement ; and it is doubtful whether two separate lines are ever quite identical in their curves . "[121-christopher] [Christopher]121-christopher could take [me]0-i , " [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth continued ; "[121-christopher] and if [he]121-christopher could n't , [I]0-i 'm sure [Alan]161-alan would . " "[161-alan] [I]0-i should prefer [you]0-i to go with [Christopher]121-christopher , [[my]0-i dear]3103-my dear ; [he]121-christopher is more thoughtful and dependable than [Alan Tremaine]161-alan . " [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth laughed [[her]102-elisabeth cousin]451-her cousin to scorn . [She]102-elisabeth did not want [anybody]376-anybody to take care of [her]102-elisabeth , [she]102-elisabeth thought ; [she]102-elisabeth was perfectly able to take care of [herself]102-elisabeth . But [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth belonged to a time when [single women of forty]4063-single women of forty were supposed to require careful supervision ; and [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth was but four - and - twenty . [Christopher]121-christopher , when consulted , fell into the arrangement with alacrity ; and it was arranged for [him]121-christopher to take [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth over to [Burlingham]62-burlingham on the one day that [Coulson]218-coulson 's circus was on exhibition there . [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth looked forward to the treat like [a child]3440-a child ; for [she]102-elisabeth was by nature extremely fond of pleasure , and by circumstance little accustomed to it . Great then was [her]102-elisabeth disappointment when the morning of the day arrived , to receive a short note from [Christopher]121-christopher saying that [he]121-christopher was extremely sorry to inconvenience [her]102-elisabeth , but that [his]121-christopher business engagements made it impossible for [him]121-christopher to take [her]102-elisabeth to [Burlingham]62-burlingham that day ; and adding various apologies and hopes that [she]102-elisabeth would not be too angry with [him]121-christopher . [She]102-elisabeth had so few treats that [her]102-elisabeth disappointment at losing [one]543-one was really acute for the moment ; but what hurt [her]102-elisabeth far more than the disappointment was the consciousness that [Chris]125-chris had obeyed the calls of business rather than [her]102-elisabeth behest — had thought less of [her]102-elisabeth pleasure than of the claims of [the Osierfield]102-elisabeth . All [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's pride ( or was it [her]102-elisabeth vanity ? ) rose up in arms at the slight which [Christopher]121-christopher had thus put upon [her]102-elisabeth ; and [she]102-elisabeth felt angrier with [him]121-christopher than [she]102-elisabeth had ever felt with [anybody]376-anybody in [her]102-elisabeth life before . [She]102-elisabeth began to pour out the vials of [her]102-elisabeth wrath in the presence of [Miss Farringdon]102-elisabeth ; but [that good lady]4067-that good lady was so much pleased to find [a young man who cared more for business than for pleasure]4068-a young man who cared more for business than for pleasure , or even for [a young woman]4069-a young woman , that [she]4067-that good lady accorded [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth but scant sympathy . So [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth possessed [her]102-elisabeth wounded soul in extreme impatience , until such time as [the offender]4070-the offender [himself]4070-the offender should appear upon the scene , ready to receive those vials which had been specially prepared for [his]4070-the offender destruction . [He]0-i duly appeared about tea - time , and found [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth consuming the smoke of [her]102-elisabeth anger in [the garden]3284-the garden . "[0-i] [I]0-i hope [you]1863-you are not very angry with [me]0-i , " [he]0-i began in a humble tone , sitting down beside [her]102-elisabeth on the old rustic seat ; "[1863-you] but [I]0-i found [myself]0-i obliged to disappoint [you]1863-you as soon as [I]0-i got to the works this morning ; and [I]0-i am sure [you]1863-you know [me]0-i well enough to understand that it was n't [my]0-i fault , and that [I]0-i could n't help [myself]0-i . " [Christopher]121-christopher was startled . "[102-elisabeth] [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth , [you]0-i do n't mean that ; [you]0-i know [you]0-i do n't . " "[0-i] Yes ; [I]0-i do . It was just like [you]0-i to care more for the business than [you]0-i did for [me]0-i , and never to mind about [my]0-i disappointment as long as that nasty old ironworks was satisfied . [I]0-i tell [you]0-i [I]0-i hate [you]0-i , and [I]0-i hate the works , and [I]0-i hate everything connected with [you]0-i . " [Christopher]121-christopher looked utterly astonished . [He]121-christopher had no idea , [he]121-christopher said to [himself]121-christopher , that [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth cared so much about going to [[Coulson]218-coulson 's circus]1858-coulson 's circus ; and [he]121-christopher could not see anything in the frustration of a day 's excursion to account for such a storm of indignation as this . "[0-i] And it was just like [you]0-i , " [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth went on , "[0-i] not to let [me]0-i know till the last minute , when it was too late for anything to be done . " "[310-a man] Then [I]0-i repent it in dust and ashes , and shall rely upon [your]0-i more sedate and serious mind to correct this tendency in [me]0-i . "[0-i] [[My]0-i dear child]1283-my dear child , [I]0-i seem to make what is called ' a corner ' in vices ; but even [I]0-i can not reconcile the conflicting ones . " Then [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's anger settled down into the quiet stage . " For a second the misery on [his]121-christopher face penetrated the thunder - clouds of [Elisabeth]102-elisabeth 's indignation . "[0-i] Wo n't [you]0-i have some tea before [you]0-i go ? " [she]102-elisabeth asked . It seemed brutal — even to [her]102-elisabeth outraged feelings — to send [so old a friend]4074-so old a friend empty away . [Christopher]121-christopher 's smile was very bitter as [he]121-christopher answered . "[102-elisabeth] No , thank [you]102-elisabeth .
